title: Neptune's Lair/The Opening of the Cerebral Gate
label: Tresor
description: Out of print for some 15 and 13 years respectively, Drexciya’s first full-length album statement Neptune’s Lair and Transllusion’s debut The Opening of the Cerebral Gate have finally been re-pressed, the latter with bonus tracks never before available on vinyl.

title: Trick
label: Kobalt
description: Bloc Party vocalist Kele Okereke’s second solo album represents an even more headlong dive into dance music than 2010’s The Boxer. On it, he’s swapped aggression for subtlety, embracing  lush, seedy big-room house music.

title: Otherness
label: Mom & Pop
description: Kindness' Adam Bainbridge is a member of a group of voracious, industrious artists who consider themselves "pop." The project's latest album, Otherness, isn't just less immediate than other pop music; it's less self-aware, and way less fun. Robyn, Kelela, and others contribute.

title: 24 Hour Revenge Therapy
label: Blackball
description: The reissue of Jawbreaker's 1993 classic serves as a reminder that, regardless of how it's framed or reframed, the music on 24 Hour Revenge Therapy offers some of the best examples of punk music crammed with emotion. These are life-changing songs that still give goosebumps. It's curious to see how this sound's been picked up and softened by the bands that came after—there's echoes of it, certainly, but nobody's nailed Jawbreaker's snarling mixture of tender and tough since.

title: Salt EP
label: Sacred Bones
description: Upon first encountering Institute's debut EP for Sacred Bones, Salt, you could be forgiven for mistaking it for a recording from the 1980s. Here, the Austin, Texas band improves on the deathrock-indebted sound outlined on their earliest releases.

title: We Come From the Same Place
label: Slumberland
description: The title of Allo Darlin's third album sums up the comforts of the music within nicely: it’s a warm, deeply rooted, familiar statement indicative of a real, earned connection. Lead singer Elizabeth Morris' world-building lyricism culminates in frank, tightly written kernels of wisdom that sneak up on you and take your breath away.

title: Trouble
label: Editions Mego
description: Kevin Drumm has been known to wield an iron fist on his recordings, but the Chicago noise artist's latest may punish you in different, and sneakier, ways. Trouble is so quiet that it requres some effort just to listen to it, and part of that effort might involve just sitting still.

title: No Energy
label: Numero Group
description: The latest box set in Numero Group's exhaustivedocumentation of Unwound covers 1995’s The Future of What and 1996’s career-defining Repetition, as well as an assortment of live cuts and B-sides from the era. At this point, they were still straddling their punk roots and their experimental side with ease.

title: Bestial Burden
label: Sacred Bones
description: The sense of control Margaret Chardiet wields over her nasty, fire-breathing music provides a sense of structure that makes this very out-there music easy to grasp for those outside of noise music circles. Her work is marked by a push-and-push-harder tension between pummeling rhythms, swaths of power-electronics static, and her impressive, chilling howl.

title: Meatbodies
label: In the Red
description: As the touring guitarist for Mikal Cronin and the bassist in Fuzz, Meatbodies' Chad Ubovich is in the orbit of Ty Segall and Thee Oh Sees. He brings serious guitar chops to his own band but also knows how to switch things up, incorporating psychedelic tinges and a heavy bottom end. Segall contributes on drums.

title: As If We Never Won
label: Warner Music Group
description: Andreas Kleerup might turn out to have been the Zelig of late-'00s Swedish dance-pop, considering his collaborations with Robyn, Lykke Li, Neneh Cherry, and the Tough Alliance. He returns with a mini-album of his trademark synth pop that's heavy on guests.

title: Festival of the Dead
label: Blackest Ever Black
description: As Cut Hands, former Whitehouse provocateur William Bennett creates heavily percussive tracks inspired by the music of the African diaspora and delivers them at ear-splitting volume. His latest builds on what came before in tiny increments, and it's even placid at times.

title: Hi Scores EP
label: Skam
description: Boards of Canada's first significant release, 1996's Hi Scores EP, has been remastered from the original tapes and reissued. The duo's tonal tendencies were already well developed: all six tracks feature their trademark four-bar chord progressions and cycling contrapuntal melodies. But Hi Scores might be most exciting for the way it breaks from their later work.

title: Hell Can Wait EP
label: Def Jam
description: Hell Can Wait is a debut for rapper Vince Staples, but it’s really a refinement, the end result of a years long search for the right producer. His jump to Def Jam is a case study in the enduring merit of good old-fashioned artist development.

title: Goats
label: Other Music
description: Greek lute player George Xylouris meets Dirty Three drummer Jim White on an album that moves between  Indian, Eastern European, African, Middle Eastern, Western, and Mediterranean modes. There is jazz and punk here along with dashes of bluegrass, klezmer, and folk and yet it’s all conveyed seamlessly.

title: Absolutely Free
label: Lefse
description: The Absolutely Free nucleus of Matt King, Moshe Rozenberg, and Mike Claxton previously played with Toronto contorto-punk outfit DD/MM/YYYY. Their self-titled debut LP is an easy, enchanting front-to-back listen, the songs locking together to form a smoothly contoured album arc.

title: I'll Be the Tornado
description: Like their most accomplished peers, Dads are synthesists, honoring their influences without rehashing them and making an unspoken argument that late-'90s emo was never meant to be quarantined outside of “proper” punk or indie rock. Their new album is as accomplished and confident as a band can sound while sorting their shit out in public.

title: No One Is Lost
label: ATO
description: The latest from the Canadian band finds them having fun and adding more danceable beats to the equation. It’s a more extroverted record that touches on the artisanal indie genres one has come to expect from this band.

title: ...And Star Power
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Foxygen seemed to pack a career’s worth of triumphs and travesties into the last two years. *...*And Star Power translates all the exhilaration and exhaustion the band has experienced into an unwieldy 24-song splatter that often sounds like a band at war with itself.

title: Negative Qualities
label: Hot Charity
description: Canadian post-hardcore rabble-rousers Single Mothers' debut LP might be 2014's most aptly-titled album. An airing of grievances in full-length form, Negative Qualities takes all comers: from starry-eyed barflies to farmer's market-shopping Saturn drivers, nobody comes out of Negative Qualities looking too hot.

title: Killing Season EP
label: Hyperdub
description: The recent passing of Hyperdub vocalist, rapper, and poet Stephen Gordon, aka Spaceape, was a saddening shock. The five-song EP Killing Season, his last work with Hyperdub boss Kode9, addresses his physical condition and his ways of not only coping with cancer, but extrapolating his own state of health to the sense of unease and trepidation that everybody stares down sooner or later.

title: Give My Love to London
label: Easy Sound
description: Marianne Faithfull's latest is her best and most daring album of this century, featuring some of her heaviest and most haunting performances. Roger Waters, Nick Cave, Anna Calvi, Portishead's Adrian Utley, and others collaborate.

title: Heartleap
label: Fat Cat
description: Vashti Bunyan says that her third full-length album, Heartleap, will also be her last. If things turn out like she says, Bunyan goes out on a high note here: Heartleap is a subtle and beautiful album with a simmering intensity, a perfect match of her hushed delivery and sharply observed vignettes that move between memories, dreams, and moments of quiet wonder.

title: Rips
label: Merge
description: The debut album from Mary Timony's new band is the record of the summer, albeit one that's arrived two months too late—a collection of perfectly lean power-pop tunes that evoke Tom Petty and the Runaways while conjuring the unruly energy of contemporary mid-fi bashers like Thee Oh Sees.

title: Dark Space III I
label: Avantgarde
description: Dark Space III I is Swiss band Darkspace's latest album, six years after Dark Space III. The new record represents an apt continuation of their signature style, cementing them as one of the most daring and underrated names in black metal.

title: Lily-O
label: Nonesuch
description: Recorded in Reykjavik with producer Valgeir Sigurðsson (Björk, Bonnie “Prince” Billy), Sam Amidon's new album was mostly captured in single takes, the band playing together in the studio and indulging only minimal overdubs. Rather than producing a more urgent album or at least one that sounds rawer or wilder in its performances, Lily-O too often sounds distracted by small flourishes.

title: Aquarius
label: RCA
description: Aquarius is the major label debut of Los Angeles R&B singer/songwriter Tinashe, after a string of buzz-building mixtapes and the summer-smash "2 On". The album is an anomaly in an age of major label standardization: a debut done unmistakably on Tinashe’s own terms. Clams Casino, Dev Hynes, Future, A$AP Rocky, and others contribute.

title: Wonder Where We Land
label: Young Turks
description: SBTRKT's self-titled debut showed a lot of promise, but the producer's sophomore effort messes with the formula and piles on the guest appearances. Jessie Ware, Sampha, Raury, Ezra Koenig, and others contribute.

title: Plowing Into the Field of Love
label: Matador
description: Plowing Into the Field of Love finds Iceage growing up on their own terms. Here, they make a radical shift away from their hack-and-slash past and towards what is, for them, unexplored territory—morose piano balladeering, sprightly country-rock figures, distinctly Irish-sounding drinking anthems.

title: Doomgrass
label: The End
description: Former Xasthur frontman Scott Conner's been making bluegrass-influenced music for a bit now as Nocturnal Poisoning. The title of his first record in three years under the moniker suggests an illustrative portmanteau of doom metal and bluegrass, but the results are embarrassing.

title: Familiar
label: Blast First Petite
description: After befalling tragic loss and geographical displacement, Excepter's first record in four years should be the sound of the experimental outfit falling apart. But Familiar turns out to be one of the most focused efforts in this idiosyncratic band’s 12-year history.

title: V for Vaselines
label: Rosary
description: With no back catalog left to plunder and the comeback-LP angle already played, the Vaselines have effectively returned with the 20th-anniversary reissue of an album that never existed. V for Vaselines is surprisingly the band’s punchiest, most polished effort to date.

title: Dubnobasswithmyheadman (20th Anniversary Remaster)
label: Interscope
description: The path Underworld took to get to Dubnobasswithmyheadman, their extraordinary “first” album in the second phase of the band, was full of dashed hopes and improbable left turns. This five-disc reissue serves as a reminder of why the record is a key release in both that journey and the planet-sized thinking of EDM, which plays out as a further manifestation of its ideas.

title: Taiga
label: Mute
description: Nika Rosa Danilova's Zola Jesus project has always been ambitious, and Taiga is her boldest reach yet for the pop stratosphere. Ironically, the album's strongest moments come when Danilova's sights aren't set on pop music.

title: Inspiral Carpets
label: Cherry Red
description: The latest iteration of Madchester-era rockers Inspiral Carpets features original lead singer Stephen Holt, and their first album in 20 years is their first proper studio full-length with Holt at the helm, too.

title: Mended With Gold
label: Saddle Creek
description: The Rural Alberta Advantage's third album doubles down on their secret weapon—drummer Paul Banwatt—and it is, by a wide margin, their boldest and most ambitiously recorded album.

title: Way Out Weather
label: Paradise of Bachelors
description: Steve Gunn's latest record is the fully formed pinnacle of his career. With a full band and plenty of instrumentation behind him, the care he puts into every nook and cranny of a song is evident. It’s lush but without lacquer, detailed without being dense.

title: Playland
label: Warner Music Group
description: It's hard to imagine that the least satisfying thing Johnny Marr could ever do would be launching a solo career, yet here we are with Playland, the second official solo album by the former Smiths guitarist. The oppressive truth lurking behind almost every tired lick and lazy lyric of Playland is that Marr can, and has, done so much better.

title: Our Love
label: Merge
description: Dan Snaith's sixth album as Caribou is his most overtly personal record to date, one that’s remarkable for its intimacy, openheartedness, and joy derived from basic human connection. Owen Pallett and Jessy Lanza contribute.

title: Shallow
label: Sub Pop
description: Pissed Jeans frontman Matt Korvette’s uncanny superpower—to turn the drudgery of everyday life into the stuff of absurdist theater—has become honed over the years, but it was already strong on Pissed Jeans' first album, Shallow, which is getting the reissue treatment from Sub Pop.

title: In the Orbit of Ra
label: Strut
description: Longtime Sun Ra reedman Marshall Allen’s well-curated In the Orbit of Ra covers as much ground (or, rather, space) as any one set can. Ra alights on almost all aspects of its bandleader’s multidimensional sound and presents a coherent trajectory through it, alternating between otherworldly explorations and earthbound beats.

title: Cosmic Logic
label: Weird World
description: In the wake of the 2012 breakthrough LP Lucifer, Peaking Lights are now at the point where their humble recording project has become a full-fledged career, one that requires regularly breaking out of their cocoon. Cosmic Logic heralds a dramatic aesthetic shift where a once-mystical entity emerged as an extroverted force, as the band hardens their liquefied sound into more modular shapes and promotes vocals from textural detail to featured attraction.

title: A World Lit Only By Fire
label: Avalanche
description: A World Lit Only by Fire is Godflesh’s first album in 13 years. As a whole, the record represents music converted into motion—kinetic and mechanical, inexorable and inhuman. Godflesh, never a forgiving band, has never sounded so relentless.

title: You're Dead!
label: Warp
description: Flying Lotus' fifth album has the stated theme of the one thing every single human has in common, and just about every conceivable style of music is prone to address: the inevitability and condition of death, and how mysterious it really is. Kendrick Lamar, Snoop Dogg, Thundercat, and others contribute.

title: War God
label: Lit City Trax
description: Marvin Ramalepe, who produces as DJ Spoko, grew up in a northern township in South Africa, and similar to other artists from disadvantaged places, he has distinguished himself by inventing a world. War God, which follows the Ghost Town EP on True Panther, is his first album available in the West, a 20-track tour of Ramalepe's distinct, tireless style.

title: Luke James
label: Island
description: After a string of promising mixtapes and singles, as well as an opening slot touring with Beyoncé, Harlem-residing R&B singer Luke James' debut album sets the table for a career with unlimited potential.

title: Social Rust
label: Northern Spy
description: For five years, PC Worship have been the sort of amorphous New York ensemble that can only be defined by a series of question marks. Social Rust finds the band evolving into their most realized semblance of a "rock band" yet, collaging decades of downtown New York dissonance while sludging into the future.

title: Tha Tour Part 1
label: self-released
description: On paper, pairing recent Young Money signees Rich Homie Quan and Young Thug together for a 84-minute release seems like a half-baked idea. Along with label head Birdman, though, the duo have put together one of the finest mixtapes of the year.

title: Art Official Age/PlectrumElectrum
label: Warner Bros.
description: Prince is back on Warner Brothers more than two decades after his bitter departure from the label, and he has two new albums in tow: one solo record, and one credited to his all-female backing band 3rdEyeGirl.

title: a toothpaste suburb
label: Hellfyre Club
description: Hellfyre Club associate milo's debut LP does just as much to play up the commonalities milo has with his labelmates (and his place in the underground hip-hop world) as it does to show off just who he is himself. He possesses a heavy-lidded deadpan flow that calmly lets the punchlines deliver themselves.

title: Radio Rewrite
label: Nonesuch
description: The minimalist composer's latest album features a piece that takes inspiration from Radiohead songs, along with a recording of Reich's 1987 classic Electric Counterpoint, performed by Radiohead guitarist Jonny Greenwood.

title: Work
label: Other People
description: Work is the second compilation from Nicolas Jaar's label Other People. The comp collects a group of seemingly disparate artists unified by a preference for music that sounds like it’s being made just around the corner, in the places where clarity gives over to darkness.

title: London Scene/Shakara/Gentleman/Afrodisiac/Zombie/Upside Down/I.T.T.
label: Knitting Factory
description: Fela: Vinyl Box Set 3 collects seven recently reissued Fela Kuti LPs selected by Brian Eno, one of Kuti's most eloquently spoken champions. There are really no bad Fela Kuti records, so a boxed set isn’t a bad way to absorb his music.

title: Everything Will Be Alright in the End
label: Republic
description: Weezer's ninth studio album features contributions from Best Coast's Bethany Cosentino, along with Blue Album producer Ric Ocasek's return to the soundboard helm. The album is one of Weezer's most enjoyable in recent memory.

title: Time To Die
label: Spinefarm
description: The latest effort from England’s reigning doom entities Electric Wizard deserves every accolade thrown its way. Following their last disappointing effort, Time to Die holds its listeners close, inviting us into a warped echo chamber of horrors filled with eldritch evil.

title: House Masters
label: Defected
description: Kenny "Dope" Gonzalez and "Little" Louie Vega have assembled this four-disc retrospective to acquaint youngsters with overlooked bits of their discography as well as some of their best-known records. Gonzalez and Vega built their career on being a beat factory, but the most enduring work of the years when they dominated the dance floor came from the times their studio was an experimental lab instead.

title: Balance Problems
label: New Amsterdam
description: Classical music sextet yMusic's Balance Problems functions on its own accord and can be enjoyed without signifiers or prerequisite understanding of any musical formula. Sufjan Stevens and Nico Muhly contribute compositions, and Son Lux's Ryan Lott produces.

title: Shallow
label: Lefse
description: Charlotte Loseth's third album as Sea Oleena builds an ambient narrative that's shy enough to drift right past on cursory listens. Loseth exploits the dynamics inherent in the imagery of darkness versus light, mountains versus seas, forests versus fields.

title: Tomorrow's Modern Boxes
label: self-released
description: Thom Yorke's solo album, his first since The Eraser, was released last Friday as a paid BitTorrent download. Here, the line between man and machine has blurred to the point of disappearing, as Yorke’s vocals blend seamlessly with glitchy textures and stuttering beats.

title: Queen of the Clouds
label: Island
description: 26-year-old Swedish singer and songwriter Tove Nilsson's debut album showcases her foibles and off-kilter perspective on heartbreak. She offers shape and personality to a record that might otherwise be written off as too slick or inert, or indistinguishable from a host of peers making competent, spacious, and downcast pop music.

title: Savage Imagination
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Japanese shibuya-kei artist Takako Minekawa and former Ponytail guitarist Dustin Wong's second album is a jubilant, uplifting work, taking on several shades of happiness as it turns through its 45 minutes. There’s plenty of repetition, but it’s a deceptively complex work.

title: Terrible Things Happen/The Last Match/How I Learned to Write Backwards
label: Slumberland
description: Indie-pop outfit the Aislers Set's three-album discography has gotten the reissue treatment. The records call back to a time when indie culture was still a small-time concern, with callbacks to 1960s pop and the winsome tunes of Saint Etienne and Belle and Sebastian.

title: Encyclopedia
label: Minor
description: Three years after the Drums' so-so second album Portamento, Encyclopedia makes much stronger overtures to the band's thinning crowd. It’s a weirdly charming album: the Drums succeed on their own terms, but their terms never change, they just try harder.

title: Chimes EP
label: Warp
description: The Chimes EP is producer Hudson Mohawke's first true solo effort in over three years, serving as evidence of just how much he's grown in the time since.

title: Follow the Music
label: Tompkins Square
description: The 80-year-old folk artist returns with an album that is as sparse as prairie grass, even as it teems with a rich, Appalachian greenness. M.C. Taylor of Hiss Golden Messenger produces and contributes, along with Brad and Phil Cook of Megafaun.

title: Feel Something
label: Marshall Teller
description: The conversation surrounding London five-piece the History Of Apple Pie’s 2013 debut album Out Of View focused on the young group’s rigid devotion to the sound of ‘90s indie rock. Save for a new bassist, second outing Feel Something offers no major changes from their first outing, with the Horrors' Joshua Third returning for production duties.

title: NehruvianDOOM
label: Lex
description: Young rapper Bishop Nehru's teamed up with DOOM for this brief full-length, and such a relationship could have soildified the former's status as a strong young talent. But NehruvianDOOM sounds more like the work of an MC with a little while longer to go, and a producer who's sounded more inspired in the past.

title: (What's the Story) Morning Glory?
label: Big Brother
description: (What’s the Story) Morning Glory? is Oasis' absolute pinnacle, and this expanded three-disc edition—which outfits the original album with 28  bonus tracks—shows just how much the band was on a roll in 1995.

title: A New Testament
label: Turnstile
description: Christopher Owens' latest solo album hits much closer to the ideas represented by his former outfit Girls than last year's Lysandre. However, Owens’ tendency to borrow from classic pop is starting to catch up with him.

title: Mobile of Angels
label: Profound Lore
description: Portland doom quartet Witch Mountain's fourth album is also their final record with vocalist Uta Plotkin. To her credit, she’s leaving Witch Mountain not only with a goodbye, but with a cruelly beautiful one.

title: Electric Ursa
label: No Quarter
description: On the stellar and small Electric Ursa, her third album but first to be widely distributed, the Kentucky singer Joan Shelley lets prepositions hang with no object, tucks nouns into vivid verb-less clusters, and prefers pronouns that linger with little clear meaning.

title: Visions of Dune
label: Infiné
description: French musician and electronic innovator Bernard Szajner's 1979 album was meant as a kind of interpretive tribute to Frank Herbert's Dune series, but you don't need to have read Herbert's novels to appreciate Szajner's undulating electronic compositions.

title: Cool Choices
label: Hardly Art
description: Jenn Ghetto, formerly of now-defunct Seattle band Carissa’s Wierd, makes darkly confessional songs as S. Her new album, produced by Chris Walla, is her most accessible yet, but her songs are as sharply-observed as ever, offering a typical balance of wry humor and sad yearning.

title: Adore
label: Virgin
description: The Smashing Pumpkins' fourth album is the latest to get the lavish reissue treatment, with five discs of bonus material. With Adore, Billy Corgan made an album nearly as diverse, sprawling, and confounding as Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness, which was the exact opposite of what he set out to do.

title: Right from Real
label: Arbutus
description: Canadian artist Lydia Ainsworth is a studied classicist with distinctly modern curiosities. Her debut album, Right from Real, doesn't attempt to resolve those differences in ideologies, but rather culls vitality from the meditative space between their opposing forces.

title: Desiderium
label: Young Art
description: After a so-so LP for dance powerhouse Ultra, Jennifer Lee's TOKiMONSTA project returns with a self-released EP that, at its best, reinforces her capable beatmaking abilities.

title: Highway Robbery
label: Team Early
description: Highway Robbery, a collaboration between Freeway and Bay Area legend the Jacka, has been held up for years by logistical and legal hurdles—which is a shame, because it's the best and most natural-sounding project Freeway has been involved with since 2007. These are stubby, stocky, unlovely guys with devoted regional fans, and on Highway Robbery they sound like they've been sitting on the same porch together for decades.

title: Hey Hey
label: Downtown
description: Singer/rapper Jacqueline Mapei Cummings' single “Don’t Wait” made a decent-sized splash, and her debut LP represents an ostensible attempt to build on the song’s success. Hey Hey showcases her pleasant voice paired with some interesting musical ideas, but it's ultimately stunted by a reliance on platitudes, staid imagery, and tired themes.

title: Tyranny
label: Cult
description: The Strokes frontman is back with a new band and a new sound. Tyranny is overloaded with ideas, a palette of vibrant colors swirled together until there’s nothing left but brown; it’s as adventurous as it is unlistenable, a spectacular failure.

title: Pulsars e Quasars EP
label: Mexican Summer
description: Following a full-on immersion into art-pop with last year's More, Alexis Georgopoulos' Arp project returns with an EP that strikes a more even balance between electronic instrumentals and vocal-led songs.

title: Something Shines/We Are Divine
label: Drag City
description: Former Stereolab member Laetitia Sadier just released two new albums, one solo effort and one with her latest outfit Little Tornados. Both albums are full of seemingly simple, subversively sophisticated avant-pop, with Sadier’s breathy, balmy voice as the high point.

title: Unknown Memory
label: self-released
description: Swedish "sad boy" rap curiosity Yung Lean's new album scrubs away the most amateurish (and most likable) parts of his sound. Instead of bringing something new to rap, he’s making cheap copies of his role models.

title: Singer's Grave a Sea of Tongues
label: Palace
description: Nine of the 11 songs on Singer's Grave a Sea of Tongues are reworked versions of songs from the 2011 release Wolfroy Goes to Town, along with that record’s accompanying b-sides. While this record isn't destined to be an essential release from Will Oldham’s catalog, it’s certainly not a stinker.

title: Popular Problems
label: Columbia
description: Popular Problems is Cohen's second album in the past two years. As with 2012's Old Ideas, its best songs feel naked and hymn-like but are restrained by an underlying mystery—he sounds like he's telling you everything but he never actually tips his hand. The flat airhorn of a voice he used throughout the '70s has become eerily bottomless, the husk of another voice now gone.

title: Slant of Light
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Philadelphia instrumentalists Mary Lattimore and Jeff Zeigler have become indispensible facilitators for other people’s music. Slant of Light represents the duo’s cautious move into their own distinct territory, consisting of four improvisations that are surprisingly broad in focus given the duo’s limited, idiosyncratic instrumentation.

title: Commune
label: Sub Pop
description: The Swedish band Goat loops musical traditions that have developed outside Western pop into drone-rock, expanding the range of tones and rhythms that most of the bands in Spacemen 3's wake have wielded at their disposal. Their new album is recorded through a thick veil of reverb, which makes for an improvement on the crisper tone of their debut.

title: Remembrance EP
label: Software
description: Remembrance is the first proper release by Suicideyear, the project of young Baton Rouge-based producer James Prudhomme, on Daniel Lopatin’s Software label. Drawing from the electronic/rap subgenre of trap and offering his own spin on the genre, the tracks on Remembrance possess chords and patterns that suggest tension, danger, and, ultimately, melancholy.

title: This Is All Yours
label: Infectious
description: Alt-J's sophomore effort fails not because of hype or unfair standards but because it's dull and tuneless—a frustrating development for those who still believe in alt-rock as an incubator for unfashionable and undeniably great bands.

title: Too Bright
label: Matador
description: Mike Hadreas' third album as Perfume Genius is Hadreas' most extroverted album to date, a record about shattering illusions, defiantly looking away when you feel like it, and boldly staring back at those who hate you. Portishead's Adrian Utley and PJ Harvey collaborator John Parish contribute.

title: Oom Velt EP
label: self-released
description: Nicolas Losada and Juliana Ronderos used to make sour, frothy guitar pop as Il Abanico, but now they call themselves Salt Cathedral. Their debut EP works exclusively in synths, samples, and keyboard patches, a bookish, the Books-ish version of electro-pop.

title: Sway
label: Graveface
description: Whirr’s new album is moody and indrawn, an album that seems to be about nothing in particular; even its song titles, rendered almost entirely in monosyllables like the shoegaze band’s name, are vague and diffident. Above all else, Sway is shoegaze music about what it’s like to like shoegaze music.

title: Black Moon Spell
label: Sub Pop
description: In a way, Black Moon Spell is King Tuff mastermind Kyle Thomas' post-fame record: the tales are taller, the drugs are better, the women wilder, and there’s a conquering hero at the record's center to tell us all about it. If the stories are slightly different, for better or worse, the songs remain the same.

title: Hyperdub 10.3
label: Hyperdub
description: The third volume of Hyperdub's 10th anniversary compilation series focuses on the ambient, minimalist, and experimental side that artists like Laurel Halo, Inga Copeland, and Dean Blunt have successfully tapped into. Yet given the artistic depth of those names and their precursors—most notably Burial, the Bug, and label head Kode9 himself—it's strange that this volume of Hyperdub's 10th anniversary series is the hardest yet to love.

title: Syro
label: Warp
description: Aphex Twin's first album since 2001's Drukqs is sixty-five minutes of highly melodic, superbly arranged, precisely mixed, texturally varied electronic music that sounds like it could have come from no other artist. Syro absorbs many different sounds, from loping breakbeat to drum’n’bass to techno proper to hints of disco, but it has a way of making other genres seem like they exist to serve this particular vision.

title: Dan'l Boone
label: Drag City
description: This outré supergroup's debut, featuring ex-Royal Trux/current Howling Hex frontman Neil Hagerty and Wolf Eyes' Nate Young among others, was recorded at the same time as band member and AIDS Wolf guitarist Alexander Moskos' most recent album as Drainolith. Accordingly, the music possesses a spontaneous, yet quite orderly, approach to chaos.

title: Ontario Gothic
label: Orchid Tapes
description: Foxes in Fiction’s second LP abounds with reverb-insulated synths, lo-res drums, Warren Hildebrand’s barely whispered vocals and little else; this is music for and by people who worry about waking up their roommates, not their neighbors. Owen Pallett contributes string arrangements.

title: Myrkur
label: Relapse
description: The chatter surrounding Myrkur, the once-mysterious one-woman black metal act that was recently revealed to be Ex-Cops co-leader Amalie Bruun, has roared and raged in the heavy music community before a lick of her debut EP was heard by most. So: how does it sound?

title: A Place to Stand EP
label: Dais Records
description: A taster before their new LP arrives, Youth Code's A Place to Stand EP, is comprised of four original tracks and remixes of four earlier cuts by the likes of Sanford Parker, clipping., God Module, and Silent Servant. The new EP boils down the grittiness of their early material and the more polished EBM of last year's *Youth Code *to their common denominators: namely, punk, tempered with an understated pop sensibility.

title: Dude Incredible
label: Touch and Go
description: Shellac have shaved off a few layers of fat for their first album in seven years, and the change suits them, although it’s less a change and more a re-discovery of something they once did so well. On Dude Incredible, Shellac go straight for your throat and don't loosen their grip until the bitter end.

title: Empathy for the Evil
label: M'Lady's
description: Mecca Normal's first LP since 2006 finds the pioneering Vancouver indie-pop duo working with the same minimalist indie-pop toolbox as ever. The duo's embraced a newfound sense of melodicism, too, which makes Jean Smith's politicized lyrics easier to swallow.

title: Los Angeles Police Department
label: Forged Artifacts
description: Ryan Pollie's self-titled debut as Los Angeles Police Department is a pleasingly rumpled yawn of California pop, ambitious in arrangement and melody and narrow in scope, recalling the sleepy melancholia of Grizzly Bear's Yellow House in its halo-effect ambience.

title: The Long Con
label: Goner
description: Produced by Deerhoof's Greg Saunier, The Long Con marks both So Cow's first time in the studio and their first LP as a trio, with frontman Brian Kelly's (mostly) one-man show now rounded out with bassist Sonny White and drummer Peter O'Shea. The Long Con is a knobby, scatterbrained listen, but it's got more than enough charm to see you around the rough edges.

title: Another Language
label: Suicide Squeeze
description: Amidst their post-rock peers, San Marcos quartet This Will Destroy You have always been their own act, coming across as weirder, darker, and noisier. On their fourth album, Another Language, they move further away from post-rock into something that's cut-up and quietly experimental while maintaining a strong emotional pull.

title: Weirdon
label: Drag City
description: Purling Hiss’ new album is tighter and clearer-sounding than past efforts, but what really makes it stand out is its reconciliation of everything guitar hero Mike Polizze has dabbled in over the past half-decade. The project's settled into a more sharply defined middle ground: gentle strumming and blown-out heaviness still lurk in the wings, but the sweet spot is punk rock ’n’ roll.

title: Old World New Wave
label: Neurot
description: Old World New Wave is the pivotal sophomore effort from Los Angeles trio Ides of Gemini. There’s a fuller sense of cohesion here than on previous efforts, as the fat has been trimmed and the influences reined in, leaving Ides of Gemini with a firmer sense of who they are: an atmospheric heavy rock band with a powerhouse chanteuse and doomy inclinations.

title: I've Been to Many Places
label: Thirsty Ear
description: Matthew Shipp's latest finds him revisiting music from his past for the second time in as many years, but the record possesses an immediacy that eschews sentimental reflection. Pulsing and bubbling with focused drive, I’ve Been to Many Places focuses more on where Shipp’s mind is at the moment than where it’s been in the past.

title: Anjou
label: Kranky
description: For the first time since 2001*,* Labradford's Mark Nelson and Robert Donne are back together as Anjou. Their self-titled debut holds up to the doomy strains of their pioneering act's best work and defies direct comparison, thanks to the clattering efforts of virtuoso drummer Steven Hess.

title: Suzi Ecto
label: Houndstooth
description: British producer JR Seaton's debut album as Call Super turns sharply away from dancefloor functionality and towards headier expressions. His efforts result in one of the most evocative sound worlds that techno's seen this year.

title: Sukierae
label: dBpm
description: The double album from Jeff Tweedy and son Spencer carries a subtle, personal theme: many of the songs address, usually in a roundabout way, Jeff's wife and Spencer's mom Susan Tweedy’s battle with non-Hodgkins lymphoma.  Sukierae takes her family nickname as its title, and the backstory lends the breezy music a different urgency.

title: The Tyranny of Will
label: Relapse
description: Iron Reagan are a Richmond band composed of members from notable crossover thrash groups like Municipal Waste and Darkest Hour. Their latest album is a thirty-two minute blitzkrieg that fires off short, potent riffs at a workmanlike pace, letting the listener sort out the mess for themselves.

title: Vibe 2
label: Future Times
description: When Vibe 2 was released in 2011 on the Washington, D.C. dance imprint Future Times, it acted as handy overview of what was happening in the DIY U.S. dance music underground at the moment. Heard now as a reissue, we get a sense of how far these producers have come.

title: Royal Blood
label: Warner Bros.
description: This Brighton bass-and-drums duo have swiftly become the most universally deified emergent UK rock band since the Arctic Monkeys first thawed out eight years ago. But by using their muscular might to prop up otherwise featherweight tunes, Royal Blood have effectively built themselves a castle and furnished it with IKEA.

title: City Wrecker EP
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Spencer Krug's latest release as Moonface features the former Wolf Parade/Sunset Rubdown member again by his lonesome. Written and recorded in his temporarily adopted home of Helsinki, City Wrecker reflects a sense of frigid displacement.

title: Mr Twin Sister
label: Infinite Best
description: The Band Formerly Known as Twin Sister return with a new album that possesses a distinctly nocturnal vibe. Mr Twin Sister is a 37-minute tribute to the way night allows people to discover who they are and who they want to be.

title: All of It and Nothing
label: Ba Da Bing!
description: This album is the official solo debut of the co-founder of the legendary indie-rock band the Clean. Rather than forging something distinct and discreet, he's cast his imagination backward and let it roam.

title: Let's Dance Raw
label: Other Music
description: Japanese rock artist Shintaro Sakamoto's latest album finds him immersing himself in Hawaiian steel guitar, Brazilian cuica, and banjo,  assembling the resulting sounds into a whole that suggests the heady late 1990s as much as they do the go-go '60s.

title: Punish, Honey
label: Tri Angle
description: For his second Tri Angle LP, Bristol producer Sebastian Gainsborough's made a noise-specific techno record beholden to his remarkably generative skills with sound manipulation. His reliance on homespun methods of fabricating instruments gives Punish, Honey a distinctively raw and tactile identity.

title: This Is My Hand
label: Paper Bag
description: Self-produced by My Brightest Diamond's Shara Worden with support from keyboardist Zac Rae, This Is My Hand is an often successful exercise in percussive, jagged art-pop that explores themes of self-acceptance, sensuality, and community.

title: Ryan Adams/1984 EP
label: Pax-Am
description: Ryan Adams' latest pair of releases show off the duality of the artist—the straightforward singer/songwriter, and the rascally punk, that is. His self-titled LP offers a nice, 1980s-imbued twist on the singer/songwriter mode; the 1984 EP plays like a super-obscure hardcore EP that you might find in a crate at the back of an ancient record store.

title: Transient
label: Candlelight
description: Transient is Krieg’s first album in four years, second since a necessary hiatus, and first featuring bandleader Neill Jameson surrounded by a new quartet. Moreover, it’s an hour-long expression of Jameson’s defensive and defiant attitude, as it sprawls from a base of recalcitrant black metal in intriguing, unexpected directions.

title: In the Reaper's Quarters
label: Wharf Cat
description: Florida-hailing outfit the Ukiah Drag features members of Neon Blud and Cult Ritual. Their debut was recorded in New York, produced by the Men's Ben Greenberg, but the album evokes the essential otherness of Florida, if not the stifling essence of Florida itself, and that’s for the best.

title: Souled Out
label: Def Jam
description: For over a decade, Los Angeles singer/songwriter Jhené Aiko has skirted the periphery of R&B stardom. Her proper debut LP finds her advancing command of her voice, as well as attempting a more daring approach to melody; Thundercat, Clams Casino, Common, and others guest.

title: Whorl
label: Anti-
description: At this point, SMD aren’t exactly underrated—their 2012 LP Unpatterns was a just-okay collision of their techno and electro tendencies—but their longevity has perhaps gone underappreciated. Their latest is light on bangers and more focused on texture.

title: Songs of Innocence
label: Island
description: U2 have aligned with their old friends Apple to insert Songs of Innocence into all of our libraries without consent. This indisputably queasy approach to the "surprise release" gambit might be the most interesting element about the band's latest album.

title: Weaving
label: Further
description: Jo Johnson was once a member of riot grrrl UK outfit Huggy Bear, as well as a part of London experimental techno promoters Bleep43. Her debut album is a remarkably accomplished take on ambient music.

title: KOCH
label: Pan
description: The creative arc Lee Gamble’s music has taken is a strange and wonderful thing to behold. The electronic producer's latest is a sprawling record, containing 16 tracks spread out over more than an hour. It takes time and patience to figure out what Gamble is going through, and even then, there are no easy answers.

title: The Dew Lasts an Hour
label: Bella Union
description: It's impossible to talk about Ballet School without mentioning the 1980s, but vocalist Rosie Blair’s skyscraping tendencies and the modest production on their debut album actually situates the record in 2010 more than it does 1984. The Dew Lasts an Hour is more effective as ambience than pure pop.

title: Ritual in Repeat
label: Communion
description: Ritual in Repeat finds Tennis continuing to mature and highlight their strengths with the help of a prominent producer, Spoon’s Jim Eno. It's a nicely confident album, one that takes a simple formula to a few unexpected places.

title: The Physical World
label: Warner Bros.
description: It's been ten years since Death From Above 1979 released their debut You're a Woman I'm a Machine, but this post-reunion second album sounds like it could've been recorded in the same year as that breakthrough debut.  With The Physical World, Grainger and Keeler haven’t entirely scratched the itch they instigated a decade ago, but they’ve learned to live with the burn, and that’s the next best thing.

title: Tliltic Tlapoyauak
label: The Ajna Offensive
description: The Black Twilight Circle collective is the most exciting thing to happen to American black metal in a while, their indigenous Mexican heritage adding a compelling new voice to North American black metal’s overwhelmingly white, Eurocentric narrative. Their latest compilation stretches two hours of new music from both established and brand-new members of the collective over three LPs.

title: Kidnapped
label: Playin Four Keeps
description: Brooklyn-raised, Atlanta-based rapper/producer Wara's first full-length release is filled with the voices of his friends and family. The music's focused on jazzy, spare keyboards, and  the whole effect is to transport us back to Wara's childhood, the years of dirt bikes and Jeeps and Neptunes beats everywhere.

title: Commonwealth
label: Yep Roc
description: The Canadian power-pop veterans' eleventh studio album and first in three years pays titular homage to both the band’s Canadian heritage and their democratic songwriting partnership. It also manages to break new ground, which is no small feat when considering that they’ve been at this for a quarter-century.

title: At Best Cuckold
label: Sub Pop
description: On Avi Buffalo's second record for Sub Pop, the dissonance between the band’s musical progression and Zahner-Isenberg’s regressive lyrical lapses make it an intriguing and relatable document of internal struggle. Its atmosphere is dusky, twilight and ineffably Californian; they could nuzzle into Laurel Canyon between the mystic hippies and the countrified indie scene of Beachwood Sparks.

title: Crush Songs
label: Cult
description: Following Yeah Yeah Yeahs' overstuffed LP Mosquito, Karen O's debut solo album—culled from recordings made between 2006 and 2010—feels like an extension of her soundtrack work for Where the Wild Things Are and Her.

title: Liital
label: Awesome Tapes From Africa
description: In the right hands, the music Senegalese singer Aby Ngana Diop made in the 1980s and '90s could have readily become dancehall riddims or rubbery hip-hop tracks. Awesome Tapes From Africa curator Brian Shimkovitz's imprint has reissued this particular release of hers, and listening to it can feel like putting your head in a waterfall, the pace and relentlessness of the songs rarely letting up.

title: Adrian Thaws
label: False Idols
description: This quick follow-up to last year's False Idols bears Tricky's birth name, suggesting something confessional; it's also been talked up as a departure for the veteran singer/producer, suggesting a more club-oriented sound. However, there’s not much on Adrian Thaws that distinguishes it from the direction Tricky has been heading over the past 15 years.

title: lullaby and... The Ceaseless Roar
label: Nonesuch
description: After years spent reinterpreting the work of others, l**ullaby sees Plant stepping up with his first batch of original songs in nearly a decade and some of the most bravely confessional writing of his career. What he’s doing here stays true to the original spirit of Led Zeppelin in a 21st-century globalized, WiFi-accelerated context, bringing together sounds archaic and modern, rustic and exotic, visceral and vaporous.

title: Lateness of Dancers
label: Merge
description: M.C. Taylor’s fourth full-length as His Golden Messenger mixes regional folk and country traditions with strains of rock and R&B, striking a tone of convivial toil. William Tyler and members of Megafaun and Mountain Man contribute.

title: Goddess
label: Harvest
description: The debut album by American alt-R&B singer/songwriter Jillian Banks often feels far too cultivated; it's all trendy misery assisted by equally fashionable producers, without any substance to hold it all up. Shlohmo, Jamie Woon, Totally Enormous Extinct Dinosaurs, and others contribute.

title: Linear S Decoded
label: Avian
description: Enigmatic Swedish duo SHXCXCHCXSH's second effort is the rare album that allows you to wallow in the techno muck and come out feeling vitalized. Linear S Decoded sets the pair apart from a growing wave of European producers working in techno's blackest margins.

title: Wooden Aquarium
label: Fat Cat
description: British Ameri-indie devotees Mazes travelled to an upstate New York town where their gear was stolen, conditions turned wintery, and the band had to dig their way through thick snow to get to the studio each day. The result was their third album, which reflects a brush with reality instead of a retreat from it.

title: Pink City
label: No Quarter
description: Canadian singer/songwriter Jennifer Castle's second record under her own name finds her hitting the pause button on the universe to linger on the beauty and absurdity of the everyday. Owen Pallett contributes string arrangements.

title: Endgame
label: Planet Mu
description: The latest and longest Ital full-length finds Daniel Martin-McCormick making another good case for his music's dual role for affecting the mind and body. The album was engineered by Rashad Becker, with mixing work from M. Geddes Gengras.

title: El Pintor
label: Matador
description: On Interpol's first album in four years—and first without Carlos D—there’s nothing that touches the band’s creative peak, but it's still a step up from their 2010 self-titled record. El Pintor’s best songs could hang with Interpol’s strongest deep cuts.

title: Happiness Is Happening
label: Dial
description: Roman Flügel's second album under his own name builds on the principles he set out in 2011's Fatty Folders in playful and sometimes surprising ways. If the techno producer's last album reflected a newfound sense of focus in his work, the new one widens its scope without forsaking any of its cohesion.

title: Anchor
label: Temporary Residence
description: The latest solo album from the Books' co-founder is a chilly, downcast collection of tunes that counts as Zammuto’s most low-key work since his earlier band's underrated 2005 LP Lost and Safe.

title: Cowboy's Prayer EP
label: Other Music
description: The Cowboy's Prayer was the final EP that Mutual Benefit's Jordan Lee released before last year's breakthrough Love's Crushing Diamond, and now it's seeing a wider reissue. The five-song release feels like a dry run for what Lee would accomplish later.

title: Seen It All: The Autobiography
label: Def Jam
description: Jeezy's first album in three years is intermittently enjoyable, even if it completely cuts against the presumed goal of presenting Jeezy as an elder statesman of the South along the lines of Bun B or Scarface. However, Jeezy's recent legal troubles add a strange weight to what Seen It All could have been: had it been autobiographical, it may have been even more inherently sad than it already is.

title: Primitive and Deadly
label: Southern Lord
description: For the first time since the mid-1990s, Dylan Carlson's slow-handed metal project has added vocals into their doomy mix. Mark Lanegan and others contribute.

title: Blaze of Glory
label: Omnivore
description: 1980s college rock outfit Game Theory’s debut album is being given a deluxe, expanded reissue in the wake of bandleader Scott Miller's death last year. Featuring Miller's post-grad ruminations on purpose, destiny, and the vicissitudes of lust, Blaze of Glory still sounds like an inspired beginning for the band.

title: Mean Love
label: DFA
description: Ahmed Gallab has spent the last six years slowly refining the scope of his music. The one-time contributor to both Yeasayer and Caribou returns here with an album that seamlessly mixes Afropop and off-kilter electronic sounds.

title: Clearing the Path to Ascend
label: Neurot
description: With seven excellent albums and over a decade of experience under their belt, the esteemed Oregon doom outfit YOB have long since established themselves as one of the most progressive acts of their generation. Their latest album reshapes the traditionally-forlorn moans and groans of doom into an amorphous roar that, however hellish, shimmers with something resembling hope.

title: iLoveMakonnen EP
label: self-released
description: iLoveMakonnen's latest EP finds the emerging Atlanta artist—a rapper that doesn't always rap—at the center of the rap conversation, representing the most recent goal post in the ongoing expansion of what a "rapper" can be. The release features production from Metro Boomin and Sonny Digital.

title: M83 / Dead Cities, Red Seas & Lost Ghosts / Before the Dawn Heals Us Dead Cities, Red Seas, and Lost Ghosts Remixes & B-Sides EP / Before the Dawn Heals Us Remixes & B-Sides EP
label: Mute
description: This batch of reissues chronicling M83's first three albums measures the artistic progression of Anthony Gonzales. They chart the project's progression towards the kind of big tent, feelings-forward electro-rock hybrid that has become the base stock of most popular indie acts.

title: Live in Ravenna
label: Sacred Bones
description: This live document of a sweaty performance from drone-rock outfit Moon Duo in Ravenna features the first time the band's played as a trio, with John Jeffrey furiously hammering on the same beat for upwards of 10 minutes at a time. You can feel all that sweat and humidity dripping off this recording, which corrodes the skillfully sculpted fuzz and laser-like rhythmic precision of their studio albums with enough grease and grime to constitute a fire hazard.

title: Double Youth
label: Asthmatic Kitty
description: New York-based, Florida-born producer/singer Roberto Carlos Lange's latest album as Helado Negro is his boldest and most intricate work to date, grappling with memory and its uncanny tendency to wear away despite our best intentions to preserve it.

title: Beyond the Black Rainbow OST
label: Jagjaguwar
description: For his second release as Sinoia Caves, Black Mountain's Jeremy Schmidt has rearranged his work on the score for the cult sci-fi film Beyond the Black Rainbow to craft a work that alludes to the movie but should work for people who’ve never even heard of the film. Schmidt seems to have composed this music based on hazy memories of old soundtracks, with sly nods to John Carpenter and Goblin, Jan Hammer and Jon McCallum.

title: Indigo Child
label: self-released
description: Eighteen-year-old Atlanta songwriter Raury is exactly the type of performer that makes record companies salivate in 2014. His free debut, I**ndigo Child, serves as a perfect introduction to Raury’s style-sampling aesthetic, as well as the blizzard of sometimes-undercooked ideas he brings to the table.

title: Barragán
label: Kobalt
description: Blonde Redhead's first album in four years finds the NYC avant-rock veterans following down the same path they started on with 2010's Penny Sparkle. Calling Barragán halfhearted would be giving it too much credit, both effort-wise and emotion-wise: it’s a cold fish of a record, dead-eyed and clammy.

title: Golden Skies
label: Brainfeeder
description: Los Angeles producer Charles Dickerson's new album for Flying Lotus' Brainfeeder imprint exhibits the ease with which he draws out flowing ambience, tamps down his noisier tendencies, and sneaks in trace elements of techno that add a sharp edge to his floatier moments. If that sounds frustratingly vague, well, that's the kind of sound we're dealing with here.

title: Things Haven't Gone Well
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Harvey Milk bassist Stephen Tanner has emerged from his main act's latest hiatus with a record as Music Blues. On Things Haven't Gone Well, Tanner doesn’t exactly betray his legacy, but the record on a whole feels insufficiently fleshed out.

title: Overjoyed
label: Joyful Noise
description: Overjoyed is the legendary art-punk band’s first new studio album since 2001’s Hello, and in those intervening thirteen years, the seemingly ageless duo of Jad Fair and brother David haven’t lost their knack for the fine art of the charm offensive. The album shows just how much Half Japanese, despite their reserved seat in the indie continuum, still exist in a hermetic dimension of its own.

title: The Time Has Come
label: Loglady
description: Vivian Girls are no more, and lead vocalist Cassie Ramone's stepped out with her first solo album, which features lo-fi, shambolic musings on slackerdom and matters of the heart. Ariel Pink contributes bass to most tracks on the album.

title: In a Dream
label: DFA
description: The Juan MacLean's third studio album cements their status as one of DFA's flagship acts, cementing the partnership of John MacLean and Nancy Whang as the kind of ever-evolving collaboration the label was built on.

title: Blacc Hollywood
label: Atlantic
description: Wiz Khalifa's third LP nobly attempts to pin his recent rangy genre excursions down onto a single album. Blacc Hollywood is a blur of late night bottle service orders and wake-n-bake seshes that imparts more elite weedhead bonafides than hopes or dreams.

title: 10 Summers
label: Roc Nation
description: L.A.'s DJ Mustard is responsible for more chart hits right now than any R&B/rap producer in recent memory. His first album under his own name is a small, almost humble gesture toward his hometown, a sort of epilogue to My Krazy Life, the YG album produced largely by Mustard that instantly entered the conversation of classic L.A. rap full-lengths.

title: The Water(s)
label: self-released
description: The Chicago rap scene has undergone a creative renaissance in the past few years, and Mick Jenkins is the latest auteur to emerge to the forefront. His new mixtape features improved songcraft and a tightened focus, its cohesive sound reflective of the album's titular metaphor.

title: LOSE
label: Barsuk
description: Cymbals Eat Guitars' third record is a sprawling, complex, and fascinating document of American indie rock. Marked by loss and indebted to New Jersey heroes the Wrens' own approach, LOSE fixates on small moments of startling lucidity and figures out where they fit into the bigger picture.

title: My Everything
label: Republic
description: On My Everything, Ariana Grande ditches the manic-Disney-dream-girl ballads that made up her debut and goes straight for the bangers. As a whole, the album feels like Grande’s arrival as a true pop fixture, not just a charming novelty. The Weeknd, Childish Gambino, Big Sean, and others guest.

title: Underlay EP
label: Merge
description: Melbourne outfit Twerps have cited the Clean and the Go-Betweens as influences, but their new EP, Underlay, doesn't skate by on jangle-centric nostalgia. On older tracks, they proved that they could ride a central groove while exploring different avenues; on Underlay, they find a similar balance between precise and unsteady.

title: Bitchin Bajas
label: Drag City
description: Bitchin Bajas' second, self-titled album finds the experimental trio blending musicial personalities of the past to create their own sonic identity. There are no forced attempts at edginess, even though their simple techniques keep the music loose and live-sounding.

title: Pale Communion
label: Roadrunner
description: Opeth's first album in three years lacks the absolute willpower and prevailing ambition of the band’s best work. These eight songs run cold on new energies and ideas, a rarity for a catalogue custom-made to overwhelm.

title: Tied to a Star
label: Sub Pop
description: J Mascis' second proper solo album suggests that the Dinosaur Jr. frontman's entering a new, quieter phase in his career, as his work with the acoustic guitar receives an increased amount of attention. Pall Jenkins of the Black Heart Procession, Ken Maiuri, and Mark Mulcahy join him on this quiet collection of tunes.

title: After the End
label: 4AD
description: Merchandise's latest and first for new label home 4AD is so determinedly mild-mannered, it essentially amounts to a declaration of war: against dominant notions of cool, the act of hiding your feelings behind a wall of noise, and the idea that anti-pop experimentation is inherently more noble and challenging a practice than writing a simple, emotionally direct love song.

title: Canto Secondo
label: Clenchedwrench
description: After their first record of halting, awkward, sinewy rock, the follow-up from punk legend Mike Watt's latest band flaunts an ease and familiarity that can only come through collaboration and experience, not to mention proximity. On Canto Secondo, they’ve settled into a groove that’s taken on the gabby pattern of a classic Watt spiel.

title: Imagin
label: Monkeytown
description: The trio of Carlo Anderson, Matthew Benyayer, and Thomas Edwards are among the few remaining vestiges of UK bass music. Following five years' worth of impressive 12" releases, their debut album shines whenever it isn't contorting to fit preconceived notions of format.

title: Annabel Dream Reader
label: Partisan
description: Brighton-based trio the Wytches bear a clear debt to the gloominess of Edgar Allan Poe, and their debut album is swamped in menace, murk, and star-crossed heartbreak. Annabel Dream Reader could have easily been a myopic, compromised mess, but it's actually a grab-bag of unhinged sonic surprises—the lyrics, however, are another story.

title: Junto
label: Atlantic Jaxx
description: Twenty years after Basement Jaxx's first release, the dance veterans' new album is a strange one, in the sense that it's not really strange at all. Junto is fundamentally sound, never content to stay in one place for too long but not all that scattershot when it comes to going off the experimental deep end.

title: Green Language
label: Warp
description: Three years after the genre-shattering, scene-defining debut Glass Swords, the inimitable Glaswegian producer Rustie returns with his second, diverse full-length. Danny Brown, Redinho, and others guest.

title: Fabric 77
label: Fabric
description: Techno auteur and Berghain veteran Marcel Dettmann's first mix CD in three years is almost Escherian in the way it folds four-to-the-floor beats into a series of improbable twists and turns that nevertheless seem, somehow, to unroll eternally in a straight line. 15 out of 19 cuts bear his fingerprints, either as producer or A&R.

title: The Man Upstairs
label: Yep Roc
description: For Robyn Hitchcock's latest album, the post-punk troubadour has teamed up with producer Joe Boyd (Nick Drake, Fairport Convention) for an album that's half-covers, half-originals. These ten songs don’t seem to mesh in any way other than the fact Hitchcock is singing them.

title: Neuroplasticity
label: Mute
description: Following her intriguing 2012 debut I Predict a Graceful Expulsion, Al Spx's second album as Cold Specks is an encouraging next step towards a bolder, striking sound. Swans' Michael Gira contributes to two songs.

title: Angels & Devils
label: Ninja Tune
description: On Angels & Devils, the Bug's Kevin Martin bifurcates his interests, offering six songs of muddy dirges and six tracks of raucous, MC-aided bangers that will be familiar to fans of London Zoo. Grouper, Gonjasufi, Death Grips, and others contribute.

title: Manipulator
label: Drag City
description: Manipulator represents the inevitable pause from Ty Segall's usual breakneck pace, its 17-song, double-album sprawl the product of an unprecedented (for him) 14-month writing process. The extra attention to detail is felt on every song here.

title: The Process of Self-Immolation
label: Profound Lore
description: Nashville quartet Alraune's debut LP for Profound Lore is a tour de force, and the quartet have made it clear that they're exactly the sort of band that deserves a leg up out of obscurity. This is raw, cathartic black metal devoid of pretension or compassion, but it does allow itself a few liberties in its pursuit of the greater evil.

title: Ganglion Reef
label: Drag City
description: The debut album from Los Angeles psych-rock project Wand is all about: the passageways between one place or state of mind to another. Accordingly, it moves, what makes Ganglion Reef so euphorically hypnotic is the way it translates bandleader Cory Hanson's itinerant, hyperkinetic tendencies into song.

title: Into Sixes
label: Anyway
description: Ohio power-pop outfit Connections have garnered a few comparisons to Guided by Voices, and they're proving similarly prolific. Their third album in two years faces the challenge of maintaining their established consistency.

title: De Oro
label: Totally Gross National Product
description: The first thing you may want to know about the mystery band Jason Feathers is that it features Justin Vernon, aka Bon Iver. The second is that their album, De Oro, is a hybrid of swamp-rock and rap that trades on myths of the southern United States as a sinister place where laws are flexible, morals are optional and pleasure is central. The third thing is almost a foregone conclusion, and best stated as a question: Why?

title: Brill Bruisers
label: Matador
description: If the previous two New Pornographers records sometimes had a procedural air about them, the vim and vigor of Brill Bruisers forcefully reasserts just how important and therapeutic the enterprise is to all involved. The band's never felt like a purely retro exercise, but Brill Bruisers feels like their most contemporary recording to date.

title: Decimation Blues
label: Asthmatic Kitty
description: After his Castanets project vanished off the map in 2009, Raymond Raposa brings the experimental folk project back for another go-round. Decimation Blues is a fragmented album that trends toward the same path he's already spent five albums exploring.

title: Chorus
label: Slumberland
description: Philadelphia indie-pop band Literature's debut LP for Slumberland sums up so much history: the antsy enthusiasm of the Feelies, the twinkling tone of Johnny Marr’s guitar, the “Go on, then” romanticism of Buzzcocks. But instead of coming off as a retread of bands dead and gone, it charms with humor and heart—a record with feeling, even if it feels like something you already know.

title: Chrome Cactus
label: Matador
description: Austin band the Young represent "record collector rock" that doesn’t even have an interesting record collection. By most metrics, their sophomore album is one of the least interesting albums of the year, but when focusing solely on how a presumable rock record manages to be so nondescript, it becomes quite interesting.

title: Meshes of Voice
label: SusannaSonata
description: Meshes of Voice is the transfixing result of a 2009 live collaboration between Norwegian singers Jenny Hval and Susanna Wallumrød. These 15 interconnected pieces unfold a surrealistic saga that makes up one of the best records of either’s career.

title: V
label: Secretly Canadian
description: On JJ's third full-length, they've started capitalizing their name, and it's a formality that hints at the collection's bigger, fuller production and ambitions. Even with the added string swells, guitar solos, and bolder singing, the Swedish duo's dozy sentiments are the same as they always were.

title: Dark Pool
label: Blackest Ever Black
description: Back in 1995, New York musician Stuart Argabright and fellow Death Comet Crew member Shinichi Shimokawa teamed up as Black Rain to record a soundtrack for the disparaged 1995 sci-fi noir Johnny Mnemonic. Their first album in the 18 years since similarly suggests soundtrack fare, as the pair move into queasy, dark ambient territory.

title: The Golden Echo
label: Warner Bros.
description: Kimbra's L.A.-recorded second album The Golden Echo is the Gotye collaborator's latest wager for staying power, but too often it overstays its welcome. The album's overlong, overdone nature suggests that she doesn't know how to refine her ideas beyond adding to them until they sound overstuffed.

title: Document and Eyewitness
label: Pinkflag
description: Wire's 1981 record centered around an infamous concert in February of 1980 at London’s Electric Ballroom—a gig that would turn out to be Wire’s last for a long time. The album is being given an expanded, remastered, and resquenced reissue, but it doesn’t change the reality of the recording’s technical flaws, not to mention the issues with the performance itself.

title: Experiments in Time
label: CD Baby
description: After a publicized falling-out with former label and XL offshoot Hot Charity, the enigmatic Willis Earl Beal returns to the self-released grind with an album of ethereal, bluesy ruminations that find the artist at a crossroads, creatively and otherwise.

title: I'm Not Bossy, I'm the Boss
label: Nettwerk
description: Sinead O'Connor's latest album is much more musically adventurous, not to mention more lyrically ambitious, than 2012’s How About I Be Me (And You Be You)?; it’s also a bit more self-conscious, which means it never packs the same punch as its predecessor. Still, she continues to lay claim to every musical possibility and refuses to define herself with only one particular style.

title: Tashi Dorji
label: Hermit Hut
description: Asheville-via-Bhutan gutiarist Tashi Dorji has made a handful of diverse releases in the past decade, mostly on cassette. He and Six Organs of Admittance’s Ben Chasny chose tracks from those (and some unreleased tapes) for his first, self-titled LP. There are only six pieces here, but each feels like its own planet.

title: Champagne Holocaust
label: Fat Possum
description: Fat White Family sound just like they look—diseased, drug addled, utterly corrupt. Their debut album is getting a belated North American release after gaining a swell of attention in the UK. It represents the shambolic beginnings of something, full of directions tried and discarded and barely fleshed out.

title: Get Yer Body Next Ta Mine
label: Castle Face
description: Coachwhips' second album showcased a band that seemed happy to take the piss out of their own garage-rock shamble now suddenly finding their swagger. This remixed and remastered reissue doesn’t appreciably change the experience of hearing it, but it does signal the fact that the bandleader and current Thee Oh Sees frontman, John Dwyer, has started taking Coachwhips’ legacy a little more seriously.

title: Get Hurt
label: Island
description: Get Hurt is completely different than anything the Gaslight Anthem has ever done, a record that comes after frontman Brian Fallon's divorce, as well as a retreat from both substances and social media. With every bungled attempt at pop, metal, or pop-metal that the Gaslight Anthem make, Get Hurt just rewrites its own worst case scenario.

title: Lost in Alphaville
label: Polyvinyl
description: The Rentals started as a side project for onetime Weezer bassist/songwriter Matt Sharp, who many think is responsible for the enduring greatness of that band's first two albums. His first proper Rentals album in 15 years, which features Black Keys’ Patrick Carney on drums, is a welcome return for those who were drawn to Weezer for their winsome underdog charm.

title: When the Cellar Children See the Light of Day
label: Sub Pop
description: Mirel Wagner's second album is also her debut LP for Sub Pop, and features production from Sasu Ripatti under his Vladislav Delay alias. Death creeps through this album just as it crept through her 2012 self-titled debut, too matter-of-fact to be sinister but too inescapable to be exactly comforting.

title: Imagine Yourself in a Free and Natural World
artist: B L A C K I E
label: self-released
description: Houston folk-hero noise rapper  B L A C K I E has always shown a wide range stylistically, but his new album is an especially new look. Imagine Your Self in a Free and Natural World is more of an avant-garde, free-jazz effort in the line of Herbie Hancock and Sun Ra than the punk-rap that's come to be expected of B L A C K I E.

title: Lacuna
label: Marathon Artists
description: Childhood recall approximately two dozen different bands during Lacuna, which is key to the British band's appeal. The flow of their Dan Carey-produced debut is easy to enjoy, but you might end up wishing there was some character to these eleven songs.

title: In The Wild
label: Ninja Tune
description: Dance producer Drew Lustman's fourth LP as FaltyDL moves in fits and starts, a tangled succession of intros, interludes, and outros, with the occasional song thrown into the mix. It's not as immediate as Lustman's previous work, but it brims with imaginative potential nonetheless.

title: Foundations of Burden
label: Profound Lore
description: Doom outfit Pallbearer's ascension as one of metal's crossover acts started with 2012's Sorrow and Extinction, and with the release of their brilliant second album, it's easy to imagine them gaining even more popularity. Foundations finds a band firing on all cylinders and surpassing what already seemed like a watermark for the genre.

title: Metal Machine Music
label: Karlrecords
description: Here experimental music ensemble Zeitkratzer offer an interpretation of Lou Reed's noise opus Metal Machine Music. Scoring the crazed feedback for strings and horns, they offer a new way to hear Reed's most notorious recording.

title: EP1
label: self-released
description: Dan Boeckner is over a decade into his career, and he’s spent most of it playing in bands (Wolf Parade, Handsome Furs, Divine Fits) whose appeal was at least partially based on their interpersonal dynamics. In his new band, he's out front on his own.

title: Shelter
label: Ninja Tune
description: Like Flying Lotus and his Brainfeeder imprint or Oneohtrix Point Never with Software, Actress' Werkdiscs label owes much of its aesthetic to its owner's permeating influence. Londoner Moiré is another kindred spirit on the label, and this release finds the producer moving toward more distinctive sound.

title: Worlds
label: Astralwerks
description: The North Carolina producer's shimmering, saccharine-sweet new album comes off like a mix of Passion Pit and M83. Guests include Amy Millan of Stars.

title: LP1
label: Young Turks
description: FKA twigs' first full-length is a monumental debut. On a formal level, it takes the kinds of risks that few pop artists, and few "experimental" artists, for that matter, are willing to take these days. As far as the making of the artist known as FKA twigs goes, it brings her tantalizingly into focus without shedding any of the mystique she has developed so far.

title: Coliseum
label: Deathwish
description: After eight years out of print, Louisville post-hardcore outfit Coliseum's 2004 self-titled debut has gotten an expanded reissue. The album's strength—then and now—lies in its lockjaw tenacity, its willingness to buck every expectation while boiling hardcore down to the thickness of tar.

title: Mabel EP
label: True Panther
description: This 24-year-old London producer is capable of distinctive and impressively detailed instrumental grime but here he foregrounds his voice, aiming for the kind of dubstep-inflected pop brought to the masses by James Blake.

title: PARTYNEXTDOOR TWO
label: Warner Bros.
description: Mississauga-born singer and producer Jahron Brathwaite's second album as PARTYNEXTDOOR matches the Drake affiliate's self-assured cockiness with an increased benevolent streak. It functions something like Toronto's answer to ratch&B, replacing the dirtbag charm (or ugliness, as some argue) of someone like Ty Dolla $ign with a more benign disposition.

title: Musik, die Schwer zu Twerk
label: Warner Bros.
description: The Flaming Lips’ prog-inspired alter-ego act the Electric Würms promotes redoubtable multi-instrumentalist Steven Drozd to bandleader and reduces Wayne Coyne to background noisemaker. The Würms' six-song LP could easily be considered the (slightly) sunnier follow-up to the blood-red-skied electro-psych of 2013’s The Terror.

title: Wild Style Breakbeats
label: Kay-Dee
description: Over the years, there have been countless bootlegs, reconstructions, and facsimiles of the instrumentals used in the seminal hip-hop film Wild Style. This special collection—remastered and overseen by hip-hop and house DJ/re-edit maestro Kenny “Dope” Gonzalez—is as definitive as it gets.

title: Elddop
label: Southern Lord
description: For the last decade, the heavy, agile, and inquisitive Swedish punk band Martyrdöd has thatched a dozen different influences to its national heritage of D-beat and crustpunk. Their fifth LP is bracing and breathless; these 15 tracks hit hard, early, and often, but Martyrdöd have become experts at finesse, too.

title: Migrations of Glass
label: Darkhan
description: Migrations of Glass is Desertshore’s fourth album, but since the instrumental rock outfit's last two full-lengths were overshadowed by heavy collaborations with Mark Kozelek, it's easy to consider this one their sophomore effort. There’s a sprawl to Migrations that shows more confidence and ambition than all of Desertshore’s prior output combined.

title: Tony
label: Lawless
description: King Louie's Tony is a force of nature and one of the strongest projects of his career. The Chicago street rapper marshals the bleak language and imagery of violence to craft a world where brutal realism and mythos collide, where reality bleeds indiscriminately into art, and the extreme is everyday.

title: Being
label: Asthmatic Kitty
description: Mozart’s Sister is the alt-pop project of Montreal’s Caila Thompson-Hannant, formerly of Shapes and Sizes. Her debut LP is most compelling as a pop album when it’s not trying to hook you; the rest is promising, but perhaps could do with a little more dementedness.

title: The World We Left Behind
label: Century Media
description: What could be the final album from black metal outfit Nachtmystium is a nine-track slog that follows an intense period of personal and professional turmoil for founder Blake Judd. Suitably, all of the record's problems seem to result from its creator's vainglory.

title: Storms of Unholy Black Mass
label: Hells Headbangers
description: Extreme metal works well within the EP format, and Louisiana newcomers Abysmal Lord are more than well aware of this. Their debut release is a five-song hellride that just exceeds twenty-six minutes in length and takes heavy cues from war metal's godfathers while channeling the newer, more cerebral school of occult death metal.

title: Gist Is
label: Spare Thought
description: Leeds-based quartet Adult Jazz's debut album is full of formally convoluted songs which seldom run shy of five minutes, and feature plenty of brisk, ponderous guitar figures and difficult-to-parse drumbeats. It's full of clever turns of musical and lyrical phrase which will dispel possible accusations of self-indulgence and pretention, and yet somehow, with a few listens, it's easy to enjoy this unusually paced album.

title: Wild Onion
label: Grand Jury
description: Chicago rockers Twin Peaks' first album ran a compact twenty minutes and was refreshing and ephemeral. Their new one is twice the length, offering two distinct versions of themselves—one of which sounds really good, and the other just okay.

title: Sand + Silence
label: Western Vinyl
description: The once-married, now-divorced Rosebuds convened at Justin Vernon’s April Base Studio in Eau Claire, Wisconsin, to record tracks for their sixth proper album in their 14-year career. Even if this isn’t their first album together as exes, it still sounds like they’re figuring out what the band is now and how it operates.

title: Television Man
label: Captured Tracks
