description: Pacific Northwestern punks Naomi Punk's second LP is a tough, grimy album made by three young men who sound like they could use more "outside time" in their lives. This is a band with a narrow idea of what it wants to do and a firm confidence in doing it.

title: Claw
label: Northern Spy
description: DAMA/LIBRA is a new project from Joel RL Phelps—best known as the former singer/guitarist for Silkworm and current leader of Downer Trio—and G. Stuart Dahlquist of Asva, formerly of Sunn O))), Goatsnake, and Burning Witch. With experimental compositions heavy in an atypical sense, DAMA/LIBRA is a partnership that’s artfully smudged with the fingerprints of both of its participants.

title: Ice Cream Man
label: Boundee
description: Indie-pop artist Hideki Kaji has been one of the most consistent forces in Japanese music over the last two decades. The Tokyo singer-songwriter’s latest album, Ice Cream Man, is his 15th original full-length, and it marks no major sonic changes from what preceded it.

title: The Number Ones
label: Deranged
description: Power-pop foursome the #1s have been kicking around the Dublin scene for a couple of years now, and their self-titled debut album marks the point where this scene may start to get noticed a bit more. It's more ambitious and unabashedly brilliant than four modest walls can contain.

title: Frozen Letter
label: Merge
description: Spider Bags' latest album is their first for Merge and their highest-fi release to date, but here the North Carolina country-punk band's taken on a more skeletal sound regardless. It was recorded in just three days, but it sounds a bit less dangerous, and a bit more inscrutable, than their past releases.

title: Time Is Over One Day Old
label: Dead Oceans
description: Bear in Heaven's latest album is tasteful, electronic indie as ambient music, and when you lean into it, it rarely pushes back. In 2014, it's hard to say what makes the Brooklyn indie-synth outfit stand out from the crowd.

title: Music From The Mountain Provinces
label: Numero Group
description: The backstory to Music from the Mountain Provinces positions it as a set of field recordings, all captured on tape during life-risking ventures into the Philippines during the late 1980s. The natural world around the musicians is as important an ingredient as the instruments and vocals of the musicians that were recorded.

title: Heavy Window
label: Magnetic South
description: Apache Dropout are drenched in retro signifiers, and their music often sounds like 1960s DIY pop rising from its own ashes. Their third album uses that style for what they need rather than getting lost in it for its own sake, making music that points to itself more than its influences.

title: Fan Fiction
label: Chapter Music
description: Melbourne artist Geoffrey O'Connor's sophomore album layers chintzy, thin-sounding synths over reverberating disco guitars, guiding it all with his breathy, nasal whine. Fan Fiction portrays O'Connor as helplessly willing, a wretch begging for punishment if it means at least one night with someone.

title: End Times Undone
artist: David Kilgour and the Heavy Eights
label: Merge
description: David Kilgour’s decades-long body of work, both solo and with his vastly influential New Zealand indie-pop band the Clean, has been remarkably consistent and reliable. His latest, lovely solo album is no different, but in this case—as with all his more recent albums—consistency and reliability do not necessarily mean stagnancy and complacency.

title: They Want My Soul
label: Loma Vista
description: Spoon's eighth album is their most booming LP, most resembling a companion piece to 2007's masterwork Ga Ga Ga Ga Ga. Joe Chiccarelli and Dave Fridmann share co-production credits along with the band themselves, and They Want My Soul pulls at familiar threads, fraying things to make them seem now.

title: Late Night Tales Presents After Dark: Nightshift
label: Late Night Tales
description: The novelty of the Late Night Tales series of compilations stems in part from hearing what bands themselves like to hear, but in tapping dance curator Bill Brewster for a second compilation in as many years, Late Night Tales’ newest iteration of the series has a proper selector at the helm. Nightshift pulls from the late-‘00s era of nu-disco, offering the slightest variations of a restricted sonic palette.

title: Wastoid
label: Federal Prism
description: Stardeath and White Dwarfs' Dennis Coyne is a nephew of Flaming Lips founder Wayne, and on the psych band's latest LP, they haven't yet escaped the shadow of their elders. Flaming Lips guest, as do New Fumes and Chrome Pony.

title: Mediumship
label: Tiny Engines
description: A few years ago, Florida outfit Dikembe put out a record embraced by emo diehards who recognized their potential amidst shoddy production and off-putting in-jokes. Their new album makes intriguing, risky artistic steps forward that could possibly alienate old fans for reasons that go beyond punk ethics.

title: Rückverzauberung 9 / Musik Für Kulturinstitutionen
label: Profan
description: The restless producer and Kompakt founder shifts back into an ambient mode on his latest. Here, he leaves behind some of his recent formal experiments and crafts a droney, gently undulating soundscape sometimes reminiscent of his work as Gas.

title: Romantic Times
label: Light in the Attic
description: It sounds too good to be true. Just two months after Light in the Attic released L’Amour, the amazing lost debut by an artist known as Lewis, vinyl hunter-gatherers in Canada found what appeared to be an even more lost second album. Romantic Times is certainly more self-conscious than Lewis’ debut; it’s loopier, kitschier, and less personal, although it might be more fun, too.

title: Bled White
label: The End
description: Chicago metal veterans Novembers Doom have been steadily releasing heavily emotional melodic doom since 1995. Their ninth album is the latest representation of the band's attempt to peddle sorrow rather than savagery, and this time around, they’ve done an admirable job of making that sale stick.

title: Wilderness of Mirrors
label: Room40
description: Australian sound artist and Room40 founder Lawrence English is responsible for the existence of a daunting number of recordings, especially in regards to his own solo career. His latest solo album and first in three years gins up infernos of harmonic distortion not unlike the heavier sides of Tim Hecker and Ben Frost.

title: Persona
label: Posh Isolation
description: On her latest album, Copenhagen noise artist Frederike Hoffmeier has abandoned the universally bummed out aesthetic that's marked all of her efforts so far. Persona offers disaffection, sexuality, and outright ferocity in addition to the desolation she's offered to date.

title: Seven Years Week
label: Hush Hush
description: Bob Hansen, the Seattle-based producer who sometimes records as Hanssen, spent the first decade of his career making dancefloor-oriented music that occupied a wide spectrum of playfulness. His debut full-length Seven Years Week smacks of synth-based kosmische and marks another step away from his past, while retaining some of the imagination and quirk that made that work special.

title: The Voyager
label: Warner Bros.
description: Jenny Lewis' third solo album is defined and motivated by a sense of personal nostalgia, as these songs sift through Lewis’ past to find some key to her present. It’s not anchored in one particular scene, but plays as broadly California, with sly nods to the Byrds in the guitars, the Go-Go’s in the vocals, and Randy Newman in the wry humor.

title: Money Green Viper
label: Hit + Run
description: Tucson-raised singer/producer Zackey Force Funk, who has acknowledged a debt to '80s-baby fixtures like Prince and Egyptian Lover, walks the line between straight-faced sincerity and pranksterish weirdness.

title: Call 4 Fun
label: Bad Actors
description: Actual Water are a Toronto-based band that makes garage-y power pop, and nowhere on Call 4 Fun do they take themselves too seriously. Their music is steadily becoming simpler while putting more focus on the hooks, which turns out to be a good thing.

title: Magical Pessimism 2014
label: self-released
description: James Brooks, formerly of Elite Gymnastics, returns with his first full-length under his Default Genders alias. This project uses basic A-B song structures, surging choruses, and grooves that recall 1990s big beat as a foundation for political lyrics.

title: Pe'ahi
label: Beat Dies
description: The Raveonettes’ latest shows a marked shift in sound, as the fuzz guitar and simple melodies are augumented with harps, choirs, xylophones, and electronics and basic drum machine pulses are eschewed in favor of more complex, swinging breakbeats.

title: Beck Song Reader
label: Capitol
description: In 2012, Beck published a book of sheet music called Song Reader. This collection features versions of those songs by artists including Jack White, Norah Jones, Jeff Tweedy, and Jarvis Cocker, and the set was executive produced by Wes Anderson music supervisor Randall Poster.

title: Harbinger
label: Prosthetic
description: Two years after their debut, Brooklyn's Mutilation Rites return with Harbinger. Like its predecessor, the new record splits its time between lengthy, metamorphosing epics and thunderous rabble-rousers, with nary a synth or sample in sight. This time around, however, improved sonics and sharpened songwriting streamline the band's venture into the void.

title: Tell Me I Belong
label: Innovative Leisure
description: Sample-happy electronic producer Jim-E Stack steps out with his debut full-length, which folds in influences like Baltimore club, electro, R&B, and dancehall.

title: Cold World
label: Daptone
description: Five years after her Daptone debut, soul veteran Naomi Shelton returns with her second album with the Gospel Queens. Cold World covers a lot of ground stylistically, but Shelton confidently ties everything together with songs that address social issues and paint the world bleakly.

label: Rumors
description: Three years after it was supposed to come out, Diddy's full-length collaboration with Israeli dance producer Guy Gerber has arrived. By all rights, 11:11 should have been an over-the-top fusion of American entrepreneurship and Ibiza spectacle. Instead, it's merely tasteful and weirdly tentative.

title: Who Will Cut Our Hair When We're Gone?
label: Caterpillar
description: In an early-2000s Montreal music community renowned for heart-on-sleeve, shoot-for-the-moon rockestras, the Unicorns were the odd band out. Eleven years on, their messy and often brilliant full-length has been reissued with bonus tracks.

title: Southern Meridian
label: Williams Street
description: East coast rap and Southern rap are often discussed as existing in opposition to each other, but the production on Gene the Southern Child's new album shows how the two sounds can achieve a ready synthesis. The Alabama rapper’s uncanny focus and subtle charm is slowly revealed throughout the album, too.

title: UltraMantis Black
label: Relapse
description: Philadelphia-based professional wrestler UltraMantis Black has a wiseass streak a mile wide, but when it comes to his personal beliefs, he's plenty sincere. With the help of Pissed Jeans' Matt Korvette and Brad Fry, he's made a brutal, sharp record that calls back to hardcore's severe intensity, as well as the Locust's own approach to powerviolence.

title: Whoop Dee Doo
label: Cherry Red
description: Kim Shattuck was Kim Deal's stand-in for the Pixies for six months last year. That role didn't last, but Shattuck's band the Muffs have returned for their first album in 10 years, and nothing on Whoop Dee Doo would have been out of place on any of the pop-punk outfit's five earlier records.

title: Racy
label: Dovecote
description: Brooklyn synth outfit Hooray For Earth are the type of band that no longer has any pretense of being “indie rock” in anything but a nominal sense. Accordingly, their new LP Racy is big, bold, and reveals them as a pop band by context rather than nature.

title: Lese Majesty
label: Sub Pop
description: Shabazz Palaces’ Sub Pop debut Black Up breathed indelible soul into the Seattle duo’s formidable style, but the duo of Ishmael Butler and Tendai Maraire have since decamped to parts unknown. Lese Majesty boasts 18 songs grouped into seven suites, with a subtle science fiction theme; if that sounds proggy, get used to it.

title: Gold
label: self-released
description: Earth bandleader Dylan Carlson returns with his third full-length in three years under the solo guise of Drcarlsonalbion. Gold comprises 24 instrumental vignettes that originally served as the score for a 2013 film that chronicled the ruinous journey of seven German immigrants into the northwest during the Klondike Gold Rush at the tail end of the 19th century.

title: Liminal
label: Mute
description: Five years after his attempted crossover artist album Cope, dance producer Adam Freeland is back with a proper rock band in tow; the Acid's debut synthesizes and streamlines the properties of post-dubstep-influenced British rock, attempting to extract warm blood from cold concrete and offset the bleak with some sleek.

title: Clear Lake Forest
label: Blue Horizon
description: The Black Angels’ most recent full-length suffered from a lack of murky, dreamy atmosphere, but the Austin psych crew's new EP attempts to make up for that misstep, with a loose conceptual bent and an increased depth in their own songwriting.

title: Nobody's Smiling
label: Def Jam
description: Nobody's Smiling is one of Common's most personal records in quite some time, reflecting on the ups and downs of his relationship with producer No I.D. and meditating on the loss of J Dilla. He also addresses his own conflicted decision to leave the city and people that so greatly shaped some of his best music.

title: No More EP
label: Wedidit
description: After last year's successful collaboration "Bo Peep (Do U Right)", R&B singer Jeremih links up again with moody producer Shlohmo for a full EP's worth of songs, including the latter's previously released remix of the former's "Fuck U All the Time". Chance the Rapper guests.

title: Orange Co. Serenade
label: Bathetic
description: Over the last four years, Virginian guitarist Daniel Bachman has lazily meandered through the outer realms of American music. On his newest LP, he sculpts his work into a comprehensive thesis; where he once made stylistic leaps in between songs, he now ambles effortlessly.

title: Melted Toys
label: Underwater Peoples
description: San Francisco quartet Melted Toys opened for Christopher Owens last year, and their self-titled debut on Underwater Peoples is made of radiant colours, clean contours, and propulsive rhythms—but behind the immaculate exterior lies an unshakeable mental fogginess.

title: For the Recently Found Innocent
label: Drag City
description: For The Recently Found Innocent is the fifth album by White Fence, the stage name of Los Angeles-based psych-rocker Tim Presley. It's also his first for Drag City, and was recorded in one-time collaborator Ty Segall's garage.

title: Rough 2 EP
label: R&S
description: Ed Russell's singles as Tessela have been described variously as jungle, hardcore, drum & bass, rave, and just about every other style of English dance music developed around the time Russell was born. As evidenced by his latest release for Belgium's R&S label, his music is hard and appears to be getting harder.

title: Country Funk Volume II 1967-1974
label: Light in the Attic
description: The second installation of this Light in the Attic-compiled collection features tracks from Dolly Parton, Willie Nelson, JJ Cale, and others. If Vol. 1 was about mapping the country funk trend via trucker GPS to show how widespread these sounds were, Vol. 2 is more about showing just how high up the ladder these ideas went.

title: Passerby
label: Sub Pop
description: Quiet folk duo Luluc gained attention after last year’s covers collection Way to Blue: the Songs of Nick Drake; the National's Aaron Dessner produces their sophomore effort and Sub Pop debut.

title: Upright Behavior
label: Hometapes
description: Landlady occupy a big middle space always in need of willing entrants: brainy, melodic pop-rock. They move through their second record Upright Behavior like the USS Sincerity, offering to share with you in your biggest fears: death, loneliness, lack of purpose.

title: FREEMAN
label: Partisan
description: On Aaron Freeman's self-titled solo album, the 44-year old singer and former Ween member finds himself on the other side of recovery, atoning for a life lived recklessly. There’s no easy emotional true north on Freeman, and for Ween newcomers, the record is bound to sound odd, even off-putting.

title: Amphetamine Ballads
label: Domino
description: Short bursts of anger snap into place in the dimly lit songs of the Amazing Snakeheads, a Glasgow band enamored with the well-worn fusion of punk and classic rock'n'roll. This is the punk that takes Jerry Lee Lewis as its starting point instead of, say, the Stooges or Suicide.

title: Trouble in Paradise
label: Polydor
description: Following bandmate/producer Ben Langmaid's departure, La Roux's second album still sounds like La Roux: slick, bright, and instantly familiar. This record breathes more than their debut, with slower tempos and less of an emphasis on vacuum-sealed electronics.

title: Constricting Rage of the Merciless
label: Metal Blade
description: Constricting Rage of the Merciless is the latest full-length from Goatwhore and the follow-up to 2012's Blood for the Master; in a career where the New Orleans band has established a reliable sound, this is the outfit’s most varied record to date, as well as their strongest.

title: Fantômas: Le Faux Magistrat
label: Tompkins Square
description: British guitarist James Blackshaw's latest release is a seamless 74-minute piece stemmed from a commission for a live score for the 1914 silent movie Le Faux Magistrat. It's his most audacious attempt yet to shatter his previously established mold as a radiant guitar-wielding instrumentalist.

title: Strange Weather EP
label: Domino
description: Anna Calvi's new EP, which features five new covers, sounds like an extension of her debut single, 2010’s “Jezebel”. Calvi takes on songs by FKA twigs, Connan Mockasin, Suicide, and others; David Byrne guests.

title: For Those Who Stay
label: Paper Bag
description: PS I Love You's third album is scrappy and self-deprecating guitar rock that often finds frontman Paul Saulnier freaking out about his inability to handle life’s uncertainties. For Those Who Stay embodies the minor stakes and moderate goals of both performer and audience—it’s PS I Love You trying to be the biggest band for their little niche.

title: Wish I Was Here OST
label: Columbia
description: Zach Braff's new film has been touted as the "spirtual sequel" to Garden State, and the soundtrack has a simillar mix of moody indie rock, with contributions from Bon Iver, Cat Power, Badly Drawn Boy, and, yes, the Shins.

title: Perfection & Permanence
label: Cold Spring
description: Trepaneringsritualen is the solo project of Swedish noise artist Thomas Ekelund, known previously for his work with Dead Letters Spell Out Dead Words, Nullvoid, and Th. Tot.  His latest work, Perfection & Permanence, marks his most strangely listenable output yet.

title: The Cover of Hunter
label: Double Double Whammy
description: Liam Betson is a former guitarist for Titus Andronicus, and that band's frontman, Patrick Stickles, guests on a track here. Betson shares his earlier band's sense of dynamics, but the most striking thing about the first record under his own name is the intensity of the lyrics.

title: Alvvays
label: Polyvinyl
description: Toronto indie-pop quintet Alvvays' Chad VanGaalen-produced debut is the sound of pristine pop music blasted through cheap, blown-out headphones. Every time it seems like a song is about to decay before your ears, you sense both the sadness and the liberation of knowing that nothing lasts forever.

title: Hyperdub 10.2
label: Hyperdub
description: Hyperdub 10.2 represents the second of four compilations documenting the label's first decade, focusing on the label's self-professed R&B offerings. Tracks from Burial, the late DJ Rashad, Jessy Lanza, and Kode9 make appearances, as does Ghostface Killah.

title: Never Hungover Again
label: Epitaph
description: Torrance, Calif. pop-punk outfit Joyce Manor have gained a reputation as one of the most popular and interesting bands in their realm, and their third record is their most ambitious and diverse album, as weird as it is instantly enjoyable.

title: Want
label: Flenser
description: California duo Wreck and Reference provide a radical vision of what the metal of the future might look like with their latest album, Want. Metal claims to be challenging, but Wreck and Reference go one step further, challenging the genre's practicioners to pull themselves out of complacency.

title: Ultimate in Luxury
label: Godmode
description: Mr. Dream's earlier records advocated enthusiasm over originality, with touches of sarcasm, cynicism, slyness, and self-awareness about the open appropriation of musical heroes. On the group’s posthumous full-length, their swirl of perk and punk has turned a little sour.

title: Honeyblood
label: Fat Cat
description: After a decidedly lo-fi debut EP, Glasgow indie-pop duo Honeyblood joined forces with producer Peter Katis (the National, Interpol) for their self-titled LP; in turn, Honeyblood doesn’t sound overproduced as much as it does properly heightened, like a well-developed photograph.

title: Break Line the Musical
label: Secretly Canadian
description: Break Line the Musical is a song cycle written by Yeasayer vocalist/multi-instrumentalist Anand Wilder and the story of its creation sounds like a "Portlandia" synopsis. Guests include three-fourths of Yeasayer, Vampire Weekend’s Rostam Batmanglij, Dirty Projectors’ Haley Dekle, and Man Man’s Honus Honus.

title: For Professional Use Only Vol. 2
label: Duke
description: AraabMuzik's proved an able multitasker but he's still a beatmaker at the core, and the sequel to last year's For Professional Use Only has the feel of a traditional beat tape. It's a direct feed to the producer's unadorned, uninhibited style, one that drastically careens between a fun listen for enthusiasts and a utilitarian toolkit.

title: Gangsta Stripper Music 2
label: self-released
description: Texas rapper BeatKing’s Gangsta Stripper Music 2 is in-your-face, crude, lowbrow rap music. He is, in essence, a Houston punchline rapper making crunk records, but he's one of the biggest rappers in Texas right now because the sum is so much more than those parts.

title: Sunburner
label: Bathetic
description: New York trio United Waters are fronted by Brian Sullivan, of 2000s noisemongers Mouthus; their new album is rock and roll submerged, every inch of it muffled and drenched as if it's wearing a sweater in 100-degree weather.

title: Here Comes Now
label: Connect
description: Here Comes Now is a collaboration between the Trinidad-born saxophonist and theoretical physicist Stephon Alexander and the Brooklyn electronic musician Erin Rioux. Its electro-powered free jazz spirit comes across as light-hearted, fun, and on occasion, very silly.

title: Friends EP
label: Classic
description: Houston-born, Los Angeles-based Seven Davis Jr. was reared in the gospel world and played piano in blues clubs on the Third Coast but also spent time in the Bay Area, where he purportedly ghostwrote lyrics for rappers and toured as a member of MC Hammer’s gospel choir. His newest two-track single meets and exceeds the often mutually exclusive wallflower demands of pop and house music.

title: Blue Bell Knoll/Heaven or Las Vegas
label: 4AD
description: Cocteau Twins' fifth and sixth albums are seeing deluxe vinyl reissues this week. These two releases—which were their last for 4AD—present the boundary-pushing innovators as first and foremost a pop band. And pop rarely sounds as transformative and as transfixing as it does here.

title: Lion
label: Nettwerk
description: Peter Murphy's latest solo album picks up where Bauhaus’ gleefully abrasive 2008 album Go Away White left off. Working with producer Martin Glover, aka Youth, he’s completed that previous album’s mission to bring industrial-tinged gothic dance-punk into the present.

title: Move to Pain
label: Audraglint
description: Move to Pain, the debut solo album by Josh Eustis of defunct Chicago laptop duo Telefon Tel Aviv, had a gestation that was long and landmarked by tragedy. Listening to the music without context, though, you'd never guess at the circumstances surrounding its conception, as it sublimates misfortune into distantly sad wisps of retro electro-pop and church-stern interludes.

title: Conversations
label: Secretly Canadian
description: The grayscale glamour of Bat for Lashes, Jessie Ware’s cool, mannered tone, and the minimal romanticism of the xx all snake their way through Conversations, the debut LP from Londoners  Woman’s Hour. The results are erudite, slim dream-pop, made distinct in its best moments by an open-hearted sweetness and innocence.

title: Friend of Mine
label: Body High
description: Friend of Mine is the debut LP from Jerome LOL and Samo Sound Boy's DJ Dodger Stadium project. The record is built on ecstatic forms of house and techno, but its influences go both broader and deeper than simple genre revivalism.

title: The Next Four Years
label: Temporary Residence
description: United Nations are a complicated semi-lark that Geoff Rickly, former lead singer of Thursday, has kept going in some form or another since 2005. The project's always practiced warfare via confusion, and their latest album is structured around the band's fake mythology; musically, though, The Next Four Years moves like a piece of fine engineering—all curved lines, no wind resistance.

title: Shattered
label: Merge
description: On *Shattered—*garage rock veterans Reigning Sound’s first album since 2009 and first for Merge—Greg Cartwright has dialed down the fuzz and cranked up the songcraft.

title: In My World
label: Brainfeeder
description: The West Coast beatmaker returns with a new album on Brainfeeder and he adds a new wrinkle to the dusted thump of his productions: his voice, both singing and rapping on proper songs.

title: Complete Surrender
label: Wichita
description: Rebecca Taylor and Charles Watson, the Sheffield duo who record as Slow Club, have a knack for patient, confident evolution. The band's new record continues their developmental trend: Taylor and Watson have taken a large, proud step into the world of soul.

title: Jungle
label: XL
description: In the summer of 2013, an anonymous UK production duo only known by the initials of J and T released a 7" under the name of Jungle. They've since dilated to a seven-person live band, but their self-titled debut for XL retains the original duo's constricts, favoring the bantamweight soul reminiscent of early '80s British acts like Imagination, Fun Boy Three, I-Level, and Fine Young Cannibals.

title: World Peace Is None of Your Business
label: Capitol
description: Morrissey's first album in five years is as musically rich and worldly as he gets, and it proves he can be as hilarious and multi-dimensional as ever. But it's also a deeply sour record, and this album's expressions of wide-ranging contempt are at times unbecomingly convincing.

title: Cantos de Lisboa
label: Rvng Intl.
description: Kurt Vile collaborator Steve Gunn was paired with transgressive folk-rock explorer Mike Cooper for the most recent installment of RVNG Intl.'s FRKWYS series. The seven-song result might feel at first like a grab bag, as the pair moves between a number of styles, techniques, and instruments, but Cantos de Lisboa isn’t nearly as sporadic or assorted as it initially seems.

title: Overseas
label: Arbutus
description: The Florida-raised, Brooklyn-based brothers Edwin and Andy White make up the eclectic, endlessly touring collagist psych duo Tonstartssbandht. Their Overseas is a live album, though it's not done in one live take: they strung together performances to build an exceptionally cohesive collection.

title: Days of Being Wild
label: Woodsist
description: Guitarist Matt Kivel's debut Double Exposure was a deeply solitary record. On his follow-up, Days of Being Wild, he's still troubled by mortality, but on Days he is pushing away from it, towards life and contact.

title: INSA
label: Odd Future
description: With INSA, Odd Future offshoot Mellowhype pairs a lower-key sound with sharper rapping from vocalist Hodgy Beats.

title: Royalty: The Prequel EP
label: Contra Paris
description: Royalty: The Prequel is an EP The-Dream released for free download one day after announcing its existence, and the seven-track collection features some of his most honest work yet. As he draws parallels between himself and the music he loves, each makes a little more sense.

title: Things Change
label: Self Aware
description: You can sense that North Carolina rock trio Late Bloomer hears Dinosaur Jr., Hüsker Dü, and Nirvana differently than most revivalists, that they’re doing so without any pretense of sounding cool. On their new LP Things Change, the band showcases a new confidence.

title: Promise EP
label: Magical Properties
description: The Los-Angeles-via-Philippines producer Spazzkid has always let gooey sentiments slide into his work, and his new four-song EP Promise continues exploring the thrills and lows of romance without hesitation.

title: Over Me
label: Crime on the Moon
description: Cold Beat is a new band fronted by Grass Widow's Hannah Lew. Away from that groups thicker production and layered harmonies, Lew takes a more minimal approach, foregrounding her voice and her sometimes harrowing songs.

title: These Things Happen
label: Sony
description: Oakland rapper G-Eazy seems unafraid to wrestle with mature ideas and his work is well-crafted and considered. While one does get the feeling that there’s a better album somewhere inside of him, his new These Things Happen shows promise.

title: Celestite
label: Artemisia
description: On Wolves in the Throne Room's earliest releases, they repurposed the furor of black metal, reshaping its sprints into half-marathons and adding classical overtones. Their latest foregoes the former volume and tempo for a liminal mix of synthesizers and beat machines, droning guitars and cascading horns.

title: DJ-Kicks
label: !K7
description: Will Saul’s been around for more than a decade now, but in recent years the Glastonbury producer/DJ’s profile reached new levels of visibility. Here, he taps contributors to his Aus and Simple labels for unreleased cuts while showcasing some of the label’s more notable recent releases.

title: Easy to Forget EP
label: self-released
description: The London dream-pop trio SIGHS is a studio project for now and their debut EP, Easy to Forget, has the feel of a progress report. But there is some latent greatness here.

title: Hail Death
label: Relapse
description: On 2010’s Triumverate, the New York metal band Black Anvil's balance of progressivism and putridity led to their inclusion in the canon of overachieving area extremists. Their J. Robbins-produced new album, Hail Death, finds the group boosting both melodics and concepts.

title: Falling Apart
label: Kinky Beggar
description: On two early EP’s for Warp, Cameron Reed of Babe Rainbow was still feeling things out while working in a loosely post-dubstep realm. His new album finds him in an exploratory mode, moving away from idiom and crafting a sound anchored by synths, piano keys, and a sense of narrative build.

title: Part 6 EP
label: Accidental
description: This new installment in a long-dormant series from producer Mathew Herbert finds him somewhere between his avant and commercial selves, allowing two contrasting parts of his brain to feed off one another.

title: Calypso: Musical Poetry in the Caribbean 1955-69
label: Soul Jazz
description: This recent Soul Jazz comp explores calypso's roots as party music that doubled as a delivery system for current events, street wisdom, social humor, and reflections on daily life.

title: Family Crimes
label: Woodsist
description: Early Skygreen Leopards embraced ragged edges, off-the-beat wobble, and an almost aggressive lethargy, but that slight yet deliberate rawness is all but gone on Family Crimes;. In its place is soft-focus haze that barely conceals the group’s penchant for neat-as-a-pin precision.

title: Wooden Head
label: Slumberland
description: The stylistic touches on London indie rockers the Proper Ornaments' debut LP Wooden Head are extraordinarily ordinary ones: Next to those sweet Beach Boys vocal counterpoints sit Byrds-buzzing guitar interplay and some-Velvet Underground-morning detachment.

title: Pika Pika Fantajin
label: Warner Japan
description: Kyary Pamyu Pamyu is one of Japan’s premier performers and the most globally visible J-pop star today. Outside of her home country she’s still a niche act, but one whose developed a fanbase capable of selling out a three-continent-spanning tour. She returns with an uneven album that feels transitional but has its share of highlights.

title: No Coast
label: Topshelf
description: Braid's first album in 16 years is suprisingly strong. This is precisely the kind of album you’d expect out of Braid if they kept going after Frame & Canvas and learned how to adjust with age.

title: We Are Only What We Feel
label: Warner Bros.
description: NONONO is a new collaboration between production duo Astma & Rocwell and singer Stina Wäppling. On their debut album, the Swedish trio gestures toward the otherworldly moodiness of electro-pop artists from their corner of the world like Mø and the Knife.

title: What Moon Things
label: Hot Grits
description: What Moon Things developed their sound in New Paltz, New York, a place that's isolated even by the standards of the other isolated Empire State outposts that have made major contributions to indie rock in 2014. Their debut full-length contains eight anti-romantic horror stories.

title: The Phoenix
label: Hyperdub
description: The shapeshifting producer's latest is a concept album that recalls not only the Afrofuturist tendencies of early techno, but the heady positivity of '90s pop culture, when science fiction trafficked more in sensory manipulation than dystopian paranoia.

title: Beware the Fetish
label: Crammed Discs
description: Of all the bands that have contributed to Crammed Discs’ Congotronics series over the last decade, Kasai Allstars are the one that cast the widest sonic net. They are a cultural melting pot, blending the hovering guitars of Congolese pop music with heavy percussion, electrified likembes, and a couple of different vocal styles.

title: "Cassette" EP
label: Mexican Summer
description: The Calgary-based band Women came to an end with the tragic death of guitarist Christopher Reimer; Matt Flegel and Mike Wallace from the band have picked up the pieces with their new project, Viet Cong. "Cassette", originally a tour-only release, is the group's scrappy introduction to the world.

title: Emanations
label: Relapse
description: This doom metal supergroup includes members of  Electric Wizard, Unearthly Trance, Ramesses and the Howling Wind. On their first album, they decided how they would sound and what they would ply; on follow-up Emanations, they’ve used that starting point as a real beginning, the origin of a path from which they can move off and on at will.

title: Departure
label: Sonic Cathedral
description: Vermont's Vacant Lots are currently on tour with the Brian Jonestown Massacre, and the pairing gives you some idea of their sound. Departure, their debut album, is marked by heavily repetitive, droning songs embellished with psychedelic lyrics delivered as poetry. Sonic Boom produced and mixed, and Dean Wareham guests on guitar.

title: Brothers & Sisters
label: Mister Saturday Night
description: The Mister Saturday Night collective is at once local and international, with artists both in their backyard and in countries like Scotland and Japan. This comp from the Brooklyn dance imprint shows the range of the label's interests, from the jazzy downtempo atmospherics to noisy bangers.

title: Decline and Fall EP
label: Avalanche
description: More than a dozen years after breaking up following the departure of bassist G.C. Green, Justin Broadrick's Godflesh returns. The Decline and Fall EP finds them picking up where they left off, alternating crudely recorded blasts of noise with the crunchy industrial rock of their prime.

title: High Life
label: Warp
description: High Life, the second collaboration between Brian Eno and Karl Hyde of Underworld in the last four months, is a genuine surprise. Filled with energy, rich harmonies, and sideways references to various strands of global music, it's Eno's best vocal-centric album in years.

title: Alpha Piscium
label: Hooker Vision
description: In the five years since Rachel Evans of Motion Sickness of Time Travel began collecting subdued drone music on Bandcamp, she's managed to put out close to 50 releases. Sometimes, as on her new cassette release Alpha Piscium, she takes a break from her airy synth washes to create a fully realized record greater than the sum of its slowly moving parts.

title: Gamel
label: Thrill Jockey
description: The Boredoms offshoot's seventh full-length arrived last year in Japan on Boredoms’ own Shock City imprint and which is only now seeing wide release through Thrill Jockey; it's the group's strongest effort in some time, taking a number of heady, out-rock ideas and cueing them up into a fairly approachable mixtape.

title: Wysing Forest
label: Border Community
description: Of UK label Border Community's principal players, electronic producer Luke Abbott has long been the gentlest. His latest album offers a swampier take on the craggy psychedelics of label boss James Holden.

title: Careers
label: Kanine
description: Indie-pop duo Beverly is a project comprised of singer/drummer Frankie Rose and Drew Citron of New York pop stylists Avan Lava, the latter of which wrote the songs that make up the project's debut LP*.* Beverly is less a true duo than a vehicle for Citron’s compositional voice, and the material reflects Citron's smart choices with respect to genre and style.

title: Live at Biko
label: Caldo Verde
description: Live at Biko is more than just another vault-clearing quickie to keep Mark Kozelek's diehards satiated. The set focuses squarely on Kozelek’s post-2010 songbook, and thus functions as both a tidy summation of an especially prolific period in his career, as well as a snapshot of how he’s evolved from one of indie-rock’s most enigmatic figures to its greatest oversharer.

title: Will To Be Well?
label: Blackest Ever Black
description: Over the course of one EPs and two full-lengths, Edinburgh's Marc Dall and longtime collaborator Alex Ander have focused their efforts on capturing ominousness rather than agitation as electronic duo Dalhous; on their new album Will To Be Well, they offer placidity in the wake of that disquietude. Where past efforts buried its intimacy under coldness and severity, Will To Be Well offers a warm, familiar embrace.

title: Eaters
label: Driftless
description: Eaters are a collaboration between two young men from Brooklyn, including an engineer who's worked with Parquet Courts and Frankie Rose. Their self-titled LP could be called a rock album, though it features few obviously discernible guitars, and most of its songs are shaped less like songs than like quasi-ambient miniatures.

title: 7885 (Electropunk to Technopop 1978-1985)
label: Mute
description: This compilation of the Sheffield electronic vanguards' work from 1978 to 1985 is practically a greatest hits set, most notable for how they treated electronics and vocals in their formative days. As an entry point into two of the distinct faces of Cabaret Voltaire, #7885 is an undeniably valuable document.

title: EX
label: Mute
description: Richie Hawtin hasn't recorded under his Plastikman moniker in 11 years, but an invitation last year to perform at the Guggenheim’s 2013 International Gala in New York City led Hawtin to revive the project. The resulting album was crafted for a onetime live performance, but Ex isn't a live album, not quite.

title: Caustic Window LP
label: Rephlex
description: Earlier this year, a test pressing of a previously unreleased LP by Caustic Window, one of Aphex Twin mastermind Richard James’ many pseudonyms, appeared for sale on Discogs, followed by a crowd-funded release sanctioned by James. The backstory stands as proof of the connectedness of fandom in the digital era, but the music also has its own rewards.

title: Most Messed Up
label: ATO
description: Most Messed Up, the ninth album from Old 97's, puts the "old" in their bandname. It seems like the kind of album that signals a comeback, and certainly the band rumble through these songs like they’re not tired of each other.

title: Blissfucker
label: Prosthetic
description: There’s a grim, twisted irony at the heart of Trap Them that gives the band a perverse dimensionality, and the metalcore outfit's latest brings it to the surface in a vivid blush of bruised black and blue. The stylistic friction that defined the group has ground it down to the bone; hardcore and metal have finally bled together into an irreducible whole.

title: Trout Steel/Places I Know/The Machine Gun Co. with Mike Cooper
label: Paradise of Bachelors
description: Mike Cooper's led a rich, erstwhile life, and these reissues of a cluster of folk-rock records released in the 1970s highlight just one facet of this multitalented artist's career.

title: Mosaics Within Mosaics
label: Cloud
description: Mosaics Within Mosaics is the first Circulatory System LP in half-a-decade's time, built atop bandleader Will Cullen Hart's home recordings, some dating back a dozen years. Despite possessing a gentler feel than much of Hart's work, the record is trademark Elephant 6.

title: NEON iCON
label: Mad Decent
description: For the past three years, RiFF RAFF has become a cult phenomenon, and his proper debut, Neon Icon, is his movement’s anti-climactic culmination. It’s nearly impossible to criticize the album without coming across as an enemy of "fun," due in part to RiFF RAFF’s knowing, over-the-top branding as low-culture trash. But irony and irreverence can only do so much lifting on a record this thin.

title: The Greeks Believed That the Stars Were Small Holes Where the Gods Listened to Men
label: Flau
description: On Buenos Aires-born experimental musician and composer Ulises Conti's new album, he's fashioned 27 brief sketches, titled from A to Z, into billowing lines of musical verse that equally reward individual contemplation and cumulative immersion. Conti gives diverse musical forms to phonemes and diphthongs by drawing on a sound vocabulary that is limited, but with nuanced differences of resonance and inflection.

title: White Reaper EP
label: Polyvinyl
description: After winning the favor of their native Louisville with their spring-loaded live shows, White Reaper arrive with their debut EP, a 16-minute blast of energetic hooks that draw from the Ramones, the earliest inklings of British Invasion-era proto-punk, and the Jay Reatard/Ty Segall axis of the current garage-rock renaissance.

title: Anthology of Interplanetary Folk Music Vol. 1: Nommos/Visiting
label: Rvng Intl.
description: In 1973, producer Craig Leon went to see an exhibit of ancient art made by the Dogon people, a Malian tribe. He took what he learned and made Anthology of Interplanetary Folk, a masterpiece of early electronic music that acts as a precursor to later explorations in industrial music, new age, and ambient techno.

title: Typical System
label: Iron Lung
description: Total Control are five Melbourne men dead-set on pumping life into the spiritual tradition of post-punk exploration with little regard for sonic congruity. It's easy to read into the densities of their new album, Typical System, but it's more satisfying to give yourself over to the record's bleak, peculiar breeze.

title: These Days...
label: Top Dawg
description: Ab-Soul's latest, long-delayed album calls back to the glory days of the Black Hippy collective's impressive 2012 run, with the sprawling runtime, resonant repeated catchphrases, and grey-toned mood to prove it. The more human Ab-Soul dares to be on record, the stronger he becomes.

title: Eyehategod
label: Century Media
description: The release of Eyehategod, the Southern metal band's first album in 14 years, has been a long time coming; luckily, the resulting eleven-song testament is well worth the wait, resembling the band's most classic work through and through.

title: Liberation!
label: Mexican Summer
description: Peter Matthew Bauer's Liberation! marks his first time singing, writing lyrics, and leading a band; it’s also the first project he’s worked on since his tenure as bassist and organist in the Walkmen, who, in Bauer’s own words, are on a “pretty extreme hiatus.” The record is a bold stroke on a blank canvas, with songs that celebrate freedom and fear in the same breath, two emotions that definitely crop up when someone’s moving on in life.

title: Await Barbarians
label: Domino
description: In between creating albums of secretly smart dance-pop, the members of Hot Chip have indulged in solo projects that focus on specific aspects of the band’s sound. Alexis Taylor's latest solo record lands somewhere between Hot Chip and his more abstract About Group project, slotting abstract sound experiments alongside simple songs that lean on a one main hook.

title: Electric Brick Wall
label: Drag City
description: The latest album by ex-Royal Trux frontwoman Jennifer Herrema's Black Bananas project is a warped combination of past sounds and present-day signifiers fed through a seriously fucked-up filter. Electric Brick Wall is possibly her strongest record since the Trux’s peak.

title: Once More 'Round the Sun
label: Reprise
description: The latest album from the Atlanta metal titans finds them stuck traversing two separate paths: the straightforward wallop of Foo Fighters-style rock records, and the hard, nasty sludge of their older work. Mastodon have jettisoned the overarching concepts of old for a simpler mission: to be a hard rock band making hard rock records.

title: Into Unknown Depths
label: Dais Records
description: Harassor are a rare gem glinting up malevolently from one of Los Angeles’ countless dark corners. Their latest, Into Unknown Depths, is a delightfully dynamic approach to extreme metal’s usual grim-faced presentation. No two songs sound alike, but each one sounds deadly.

title: As the River Flows
label: Eschatone
description: A collection of previously unreleased recordings made by the cultishly beloved glam-rock artist in 1971, As the River Flows adds an intriguing new dimension to Jobriath's limited recorded legacy, presenting an uncharacteristically intimate, unvarnished portrait of Jobriath finding his voice and persona.

title: Ishi
label: Stones Throw
description: The experimental artist's new LP tilts its attention towards new age music, its three tracks flowing into each other subtly enough to qualify as passages rather than discrete songs, building and releasing with a patient determination.

title: HEAL
label: Dead Oceans
description: Timothy Showalter's fourth album as Strand of Oaks and first for Dead Oceans is an album as memoir: stark and at times emotionally harrowing as it recounts with bracing candor the artist’s struggles with friends, family, and most of all himself.

title: Sea When Absent
label: Lefse
description: A Sunny Day in Glasgow's latest and best album has an atmospheric, bleeding-watercolor quality that makes it sound a bit like a My Bloody Valentine record if the moodiness and pensiveness were replaced with a feeling of almost violently explosive joy.

title: Falling Theater
label: Kobalt
description: Matteah Baim's first solo album in five years happens to be her strongest effort yet; Antony Hegarty and MGMT's James Richardson contribute.

title: Hunger
label: Castle Face
description: It speaks to Dan Melchior’s staggering prolificacy that Hunger, the new album by his Dan Melchior und Das Menace project, is made up of scraps. Culled from a pot of previously unused tracks Melchior has recorded over the past few years since adopting the Das Menace moniker, the record erratically pins down his singular vision of art-damaged garage-rock.

title: Horse Meat Disco Volume IV
label: Strut
description: After decades of vilification, disco began to gain traction in the culture once again in the early 21st century, but a crucial aspect was being whitewashed out of this nu-disco revival: its inherent queerness. Enter the four hirsute bears behind Horse Meat Disco, whose fourth installment of their mix series doesn't fail to please.

title: Seek Warmer Climes
label: Matador
description: Copenhagen band Lower's 2012 EP, Walk on Heads, possessed a specific kind of fury; their full-length debut, Seek Warmer Climes, is more romantic and refined, announcing a shift in Lower's sound. Lower are still noisy, but this time around they're focusing more on the jagged, wordy music you could easily term as "post-punk".

title: "What Is This Heart?"
label: Domino
description: Tom Krell's third album as How to Dress Well is a bolder, more accomplished version of what came before in his catalog. The stylistic range of “What Is This Heart?” lends credence to Krell’s “pop, but not populist” ambitions—if he was to make a superproducer-per-song, blockbuster album, this is how it would likely turn out.

title: Promulgation of the Fall
label: Profound Lore
description: It’s been a full six years since Dead Congregation released their last full-length album, Graves of the Archangels. Their new one comes from a band entering into its tenth year of existence with an impeccable reputation and slavishly devoted fanbase, but has spent the past six years fine-tuning the eight compositions on this release.

title: Band of Brothers
label: Legacy
description: Band of Brothers is Willie Nelson's first collection to feature predominantly newly penned songs in nearly 20 years, so it arrives with a great deal of expectations. Even if it doesn’t measure up to recent glories, Band of Brothers is still a showcase for what Nelson does best.

title: Dark Comedy
label: Mello
description: Open Mike Eagle's solo career pushed him from Project Blowed cog to a spotlight that gave him space to ruminate over his fights against orthodoxy. His latest album overlaps between amusing insights and uncomfortable truths, making for one of the most compelling indie-rap listens of the year so far.

title: Why Do the Heathen Rage?
label: Thrill Jockey
description: On Why Do the Heathen Rage?, Matmos member Drew Daniel's third album of propulsive electronica under the occasional name the Soft Pink Truth, taunts perhaps the most reactive, boundary-buttressing subgenre of them all: black metal.

title: Shaken-Up Versions
label: Mute
description: Shaken-Up Versions is an album of the remixes taken from the setlist from the Knife's Shaking the Habitual tour. It makes a serviceable substitute for the live experience, and it's also a fine snapshot of where the Knife’s music is at right now: often challenging, at times a little frustrating, but at its core a thrilling body of work.

title: The Living Ever Mourn
label: Parasitic
description: Nightfell are a Portland metal duo that bring together key players in the city's metal and hardcore scenes.Their debut, The Living Ever Mourn, serves as a bridge between the members' tastes and influences.

title: Auto Music
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: For his debut solo album, the Los Angeles-based composer turned to a swathe of his influences as inspiration, including contributions from My Bloody Valentine's Kevin Shields and My Morning Jacket's Jim James. In a sense, Auto Music provides insight into Reitzell’s thought process behind his film scores.

title: Music for Heart and Breath
label: Deutsche Grammophon
description: The multi-instrumentalist for Arcade Fire and a composer as well keys into the most basic of all rhythms—the human heartbeat—for his first full album of classical compositions. yMusic , the National's Aaron and Bryce Dessner, Nico Muhly, and Kronos Quartet contribute.

title: In the Lonely Hour
label: Capitol
description: From the beginning, Sam Smith seemed set for stardom, and that's the main problem with his debut album In the Lonely Hour: it feels like the record company has groomed him within an inch of his life.

title: Reality Testing
label: R&S
description: Over the last four years, Matt Cutler has steadily established himself as one of dance music’s most exciting producers. The follow up to 2012's excellent Galaxy Garden finds him both expanding his sound and returning to his roots.

title: DSU
label: Orchid Tapes
description: Recording as Alex G, Pennsylvania native Alex Giannascoli's gnarled, wobbly, unfailingly melodic guitar pop evokes Big Star, Elliott Smith, and Built to Spill, as well as more recent low-key breakouts like Youth Lagoon and Jackson Scott. His new album DSU is worthy of its moment, a 13-song set of warped, idiosyncratic sketches, each capable of wending its way to a distinct place into the hearts of anyone who ever warmed to the idea of "indie rock".

title: Just Be Free
label: Queen Diva
description: Bounce queen Big Freedia is teetering on the brink of reaching a mainstream audience, and Just Be Free is her attempt to bring her music to that level. With help from producer Thomas McElroy (Madonna, En Vogue), Freedia and longtime producer BlaqNMilD reworked her trademark sound to make it cleaner, fuller, more nuanced, and more befitting a pop diva.

title: Palo Alto: Original Motion Picture Score / Palo Alto: Music from the Motion Picture
label: Domino
description: Blood Orange's Devonté Hynes provided the score to the debut film from director Gia Coppola, and he also appears on the film's original soundtrack alongside Tonsstartssbandht, Rooney lead singer Robert Schwartzman, and Jason Schwartzman's Coconut Records project.

title: Come On Die Young
label: Chemikal Underground
description: Mogwai's second album, released in 1999, is getting a reissue with a bounty of bonus material that includes demos and the Travels in Constants EP. On Come On Die Young, Mogwai went about becoming the most sullen, brooding post-rock band they could possibly be.

title: Familiars
label: Anti-
description: The Antlers’ first full-length in three years confirms that they are operating in their own zone. It doubles down on their last record's somnambulant moodiness and increases the focus on atmosphere, resulting in their longest, most subtle release.

title: Still Dreamin' Wild: the Lost Recordings 1979-81
label: Light in the Attic
description: Following the reissue of Donnie and Joe Emerson's forgotten homemade album, Dreamin’ Wild, Light in the Attic have culled demos from the years after the younger Emerson, Donnie, graduated high school and began traveling to Los Angeles in the hopes of realizing his teenage dreams.

title: Favorite Waitress
label: Dualtone
description: For their latest album, the upstate New York folk-rock revivalists drove all the way out to Omaha, Nebraska, recording in Mike Mogis’ Arc Studio with long-time producer Jeremy Backofen at the helm. While the Felices project a world-weary and ramshackle aesthetic, their music is actually very deliberate and calculated.

title: Capitol City Soul / The Way Out Label
label: Numero Group
description: Two of Numero's new releases in their Eccentric Soul series dig deep into two of the more fascinating stories they've mined in their history—one of them, a heartening followup to their very first collection from ten years ago; the other, a tumultuous decade-long trip through a label where cops rubbed elbows with numbers runners and a legendary running back was recruited to secure national distro.

title: Noise
label: Sargent House
description: Boris excel at playing around with magnitudes, and on their new LP Noise, all of the panoramas the band has crafted over the past two decades – stoner rock, shoegaze, ambient, pop – have coalesced into one massive, smoldering landscape.

title: Deep Fantasy
label: Domino
description: White Lung’s bracing third LP is a product of its environment, one filled with people who refuse to be a part of the solution because they won’t even admit there’s a problem. Its staunch ideals are delivered by a compelling, relatable frontwoman and 22 vicious, compact minutes of melodic punk.

title: When Life Comes to Death
label: Deathwish
description: Young and in the Way came out raging five years ago and have been steadily gathering steam ever since. When Life Comes to Death is the band’s fourth album, and it seems like they've finally figured out how to properly wield the cluster of influences they flirt with.

title: The Air Between Words
label: Ninja Tune
description: Since his debut album, 2009's Great Lengths, Dutch producer Martijn Deykers has since fashioned himself into a bit of a dance music vagabond. His third full-length continues his move toward big, melodic structures.

title: Love Frequency
label: Akashic
description: Four years after Surfing the Void, Klaxons return with a new album, featuring production by the Chemical Brothers' Tom Rowlands, James Murphy, and Erol Alkan.

title: Me. I Am Mariah...the Elusive Chanteuse
label: Def Jam
description: Mariah Carey's 13th album, Me. I Am Mariah… The Elusive Chanteuse, comes on the heels of her most trying period since the infamous Glitter bomb of 13 years ago. The record seemingly acknowledges her increasingly murky future by looking back at loves and sounds of the past.

title: Ultraviolence
label: Interscope
description: The follow-up to Born to Die finds Lana Del Rey in ballad mode, finding new synergy between the character she presents to the world and the content of the songs. Producer Dan Auerbach of Black Keys turns out to be the perfect creative partner.

title: Symmetry in Black
label: Entertainment One
description: Hardcore metal veterans Crowbar have always managed to sound more straightforward than their peers, and that's still evident in their latest LP, Symmetry in Black. Their last album, 2011's Sever The Wicked Hand, found Crowbar warming up after a six-year recording hiatus, so Symmetry is the sound of the band back in the saddle.

title: Kyle Bobby Dunn and the Infinite Sadness
label: Students of Decay
description: It's easy to take an artist like Kyle Bobby Dunn for granted; he’s made music for 12 years, and it’s all been ambient drone. Despite his consistency, Dunn's latest release is an especially notable release in its catalog, especially in how it's more focused, more laser-like in the way it hits its marks.

title: CLPPNG
label: Sub Pop
description: Los Angeles trio clipping. are a collaboration between rapper Daveed Diggs and producers Jonathan Snipes and William Hutson. Their second album aims to deconstruct rap music while staying within the genre's confines.

title: Rosabi EP
label: Dead Oceans
description: Julianna Barwick’s Rosabi EP was created in collaboration with Dogfish Head Brewery, but the pairing with the brand hasn’t altered her approach to music. The one concession to the partnership is that elements recorded inside the brewery have been added to the compositions, but otherwise it sounds very much like music by Julianna Barwick, which, for fans, is a comforting thought.

title: Niggas on the Moon
label: Harvest
description: Earlier this week Death Grips dropped another free album without warning, this one featuring vocals by Björk. But nothing is quite as it seems in their world, and it's hard to shake the feeling that Death Grips might benefit from a change in aesthetic and conceptual focus.

title: The Oregon Bootleg Tapes
label: MediaGroove
description: One of the most interesting elements of the recently issued live album by 1980s punk-funk collective Stick Against Stone is that it exists at all—it's an audio rip of a 30-year-old VHS tape—but its emergence serves as more proof why they've long been one of the missing pieces in the history of the American punk avant-garde.

title: La Fin Absolue Du Monde
label: Creator-Destructor
description: Enabler are a young Milwaukee trio formed from the ashes of local hardcore groups Harlots and Abbadon. Their second album imbues what many consider to be a dying art form—that is, the fusion of metal and hardcore—with a fresh, if still developing, sense of purpose.

title: Making the Saint
label: Asthmatic Kitty
description: Guitarist and producer Chris Schlarb's used to working with a host of collaborators, but on his new solo album he goes it alone, producing two very long tracks of monumental proportions centered on the electric guitar, and two short ones for acoustic guitar.

title: Stay Gold
label: Columbia
description: Swedish folk-pop duo First Aid Kit's third LP and first for Columbia is their grandest and arguably their most consistent release to date, featuring weary songs about transience that approach their conflicts with wiseness and maturity.

title: Led Zeppelin / Led Zeppelin II / Led Zeppelin III
label: Rhino
description: These reissues of Zeppelin’s first three albums are remastered and are packaged with bonus discs that include previously unreleased live material and studio cuts. However you feel about them and their brand of ultra-huge arena rock, there has never been another band like them, before or since.

title: EP II (+ Skisser)
label: Control Group
description: Swedish singer/songwriter Alice Boman recorded a couple demos but hadn’t totally committed to releasing them; then, Malmö-based label Adrian heard them and decided they were suitable for release. EP II (+ Skisser) packages those early demos alongside an EP of more recently recorded material.

title: What's Between
label: Tri Angle
description: As Irish black metal aesthetes Altar of Plagues reached their career peak, it was clear that frontman James Kelly had other interests. The first full-length to emerge out of his bass-focused solo project WIFE draws from the same barren palette as his past work, but it attempts to approach that darkness through uplifting synth swells and dead-eyed vocalizations rather than screeches and squalls.

title: The Old Believer
label: Profound Lore
description: Chicago metal outfit the Atlas Moth's third album is marked by various forms of loss its members encountered over the past few years; this time, they drift deeper into the shoegaze interests that have previously been only dalliances.

title: Love Me
label: Secretly Canadian
description: Tomas Barfod churned out more new material over the first three months of 2014 than most artists produce in a full year, and he continues this busy streak with a proper follow-up to his 2012 debut Salton Sea*.* Here We Go Magic's Luke Temple, Night Beds' Winston Yellin, and vocalist Nina K guest.

title: House of Spirits
label: Mexican Summer
description: Even though they were reared amid San Francisco’s lo-fi bonanza, it didn't take too long for the Fresh & Onlys to opt out of the garage rock arms race. Their downcast latest effort is a spooky, desert-rock answer to the Cure’s Faith, another record awash in both reverb and metaphysical turmoil.

title: Nausea
label: Captured Tracks
description: Indie-pop project Craft Spells' 2011 debut Idle Labor was a solo record by necessity that dealt with crushes, dates, makeout sessions and of course, post-breakup recoiling. Their new album was influenced by bandleader Justin Paul Vallesteros’ admitted, unhealthy relationship with social media.

title: 9 Songs
label: Dead Oceans
description: Barely-teenage duo Dub Thompson recorded their debut album in a house that Foxygen's Jonathan Rado was renting last summer in Bloomington, Indiana. 9 Songs proves to be less Foxygen’s dutiful doppleganger than its evil twin.

title: Stockholm
label: Caroline
description: Chrissie Hynde has been making records for over three decades now, but until now she’s never released a proper “solo” record. Stockholm was recorded in the album’s titular city with Peter Bjorn and John's Bjorn Yttling, and also features contributions from Neil Young, the Ceasars’ Joakin Ahlund, and tennis legend John McEnroe.

title: Where We Come From
label: Mixpak
description: Popcaan is the current leader in the neverending battle for supremacy among Jamaican deejays, but unlike previous kings of the hill, he’s not overly concerned with projecting the image of a badman. With his latest LP, he's made the best dancehall album of the year so far, as well as one of the best pop albums of the year.

title: C86
label: Cherry Red
description: After 28 years of being held by many as the gold standard for indie-pop, 1986's C86 compilation is getting a lavish reissue with two bonus discs assembled by one of its original curators, former NME writer Neil Taylor, who also supplies copious liner notes.

title: This World
label: Temporary Residence
description: Featuring members of Slint, Grails, King Crimson, and Rachel's, Watter is a post-rock project that drifted into view and will probably exit in a similar manner. The project's debut is a series of question marks and false trails, driven by music caught up in the divide between simple and complex gestures.

title: International
label: Sacred Bones
description: At first blush, it's tempting to refer to the third album from Hannes Norrvide's coldwave project Lust for Youth as "pop"—but his ideas of pop are strictly filtered through post-punk, so the newly minted trio's International is more a logical step forward from his no-fi previous recordings than a giant leap.

title: Savage Gold
label: Relapse
description: For the first five years of their existence, New York metal outfit Tombs sounded undecided about their sound, but their third album is one of the year’s absolute heavy metal masterstrokes. Working with American death metal demigod Erik Rutan, they've mustered the heaviest elements of their sound for a cohesive, propulsive, and definitive statement.

title: Northtown EP
label: Godmode
description: With a piercing countertenor somewhere between Prince masquerading as Camille and the cracking adolescent soul of the teenage Michael Jackson, 19-year-old North Las Vegas native Shamir exudes agile, fluttering performances. His debut EP, Northtown, finds Shamir moving back and forth between sweet, almost holy purity and unearthly hysteria over churning, minimal house tracks.

title: Lazaretto
label: Third Man
description: Since the White Stripes split, Jack White's work has become fuller, but his idiosyncrasies have dimmed a bit, too. Lazaretto, then, makes all of his other projects sound a bit scrawny by comparison. It’s the densest, fullest, craziest, and most indulgent that White has sounded with or without Meg.

title: Esoteric Warfare
label: Season of Mist
description: As much a brand as a band, Mayhem epitomize the intersection of fame and infamy in black metal. Esoteric Warfare isn’t as far-reaching as some of its predecessors, but it’s still an adventurous and energetic record built on stylistic explorations and enthusiastic shifts that you wouldn’t expect from a band that’s had three decades to codify its own sound.

title: L'Aventura
label: Record Makers
description: Sébastien Tellier's latest is a musical reimagining of his childhood inspired by the sights of sounds of Brazil rather than the reality of his French home. Veteran French musicians Jean-Michel Jarre and Philippe Zdar of house duo Cassius contribute, along with celebrated Brazilian composer Arthur Verocai and Brazilian jazz drummer Robertinho Silva.

title: Bodies and Control and Money and Power
label: Don Giovanni
description: Global effective tax rates, security-state paranoia, post-millennial malaise, and a certain modernist furniture outlet: they all get theirs on the latest release from D.C. punks Priests. At just 17-and-a-half minutes, Bodies and Control and Money and Power has neither the time nor the patience for fucking around.

title: Black Hours
label: Ribbon Music
description: The Walkmen recently went on a “pretty extreme hiatus”, and the first batch of its members’ inevitable solo albums are now starting to appear; for his solo bow, Black Hours, frontman Hamilton Leithauser doesn’t veer far from their established sound, and continues their exploration of old popular music, this time with an emphasis on what was on the pop charts two generations ago.

title: Animal Ambition
label: Caroline
description: 50 Cent's new album finds him ditching the unrepentant gangsta rap misanthropy of 2009's Before I Self Destruct, which was just about the only thing it had going for it. There may not be much insight on Animal Ambition, but it does give an accurate survey of where 50 Cent is at right now.

title: Dereconstructed
artist: Lee Bains III & the Glory Fires
label: Sub Pop
description: Former Dexateens member Lee Bains III is a conflicted Southerner: heir to a questionable legacy of racism and regressive politics, yet also to a culture defined by nonviolent dissent and artistic innovation. On his second album with the Glory Fires, Bains continues to plumb the vagaries of Southern heritage as well as his own mixed emotions toward it.

title: MTSYD: the Revenge of the African Booty Scratcher
label: self-released
description: Well$ is a 19-year-old rapper living in Charlotte, but he was born to Congolese immigrants and he grew up raised by a grandmother who speaks no English, listening to as much French rap as American. His debut mixtape presents him as an interesting developing artist who doesn't quite know who he is yet.

title: Third Time to Harm
label: Tic Tac Totally
description: It's rare in 2014 to find an artist that invokes the masters of ultra-mainstream radio rock from the late 1970s and early 1980s, but this aesthetic void is handily filled by Austin shredders OBN IIIs, who revel in their own pose. The lyrics on their third album are plenty macho, and sure enough, that churlishness finds its way into their beefy sound.

title: Early Riser
label: Brainfeeder
description: Taylor McFerrin's debut Early Riser has been in the oven for a little under four years; his debut for Flying Lotus' Brainfeeder imprint tends to float away into the atmosphere long before you even notice it's gone.

title: Vauxhall and I
label: Parlophone
description: Morrissey's personal life saw some losses before the recording of Vauxhall and I; this 20th anniversary reissue doesn’t reveal the album to be a work of spiritual reassessment in the face of loss, nor some rote meditation on mortality, but in hindsight, it’s clearer than ever that Morrissey infused Vauxhall and I with a bone-deep acceptance that aging and dying might be more than just dramatic devices.

title: Love Fail
label: Cantaloupe
description: In 2008, composer David Lang won the Pulitzer Prize for a work called The Little Match Girl Passion, which paired four pure, unadorned singers with some small hand bells. Love Fail feels like a revisiting, or extension, of that work; the fifteen pieces, spread across fifty minutes, touch on emotions closer to mundane existence—the difficulty of communication, the impossibility of remaining in the right.

title: Four Infernal Rivers
label: MIE
description: Following their 2012 LP, Charalambides' Tom Carter and No-Neck Blues Band's Pat Murano have teamed up again for an album of side-length improvisation. It's a wonderfully conversational album, a partnership between two restless improvisers locked deep inside the moments they create.

title: This Machine Kills Artists
label: Ipecac
description: Some of the heaviest musicians on the planet can commune beautifully with the quietude of folk, and Melvins leader Buzz Osborne's the latest to try his luck with the genre. His new solo album is a refreshing breath of unplugged, fuck-it-all folk.

title: Dalliance
label: Slumberland
description: Dalliance, the second record from Atlanta quintet Gold-Bears, is the sound of a guitar band figuring out how much fun it can be without becoming a bore. It’s an immensely present and viscerally enjoyable album, caught in the moment without a second to spare.

title: Sunbathing Animal
label: What's Your Rupture?
description: On Parquet Courts' third and best album of whip-smart rock revivalism, the Brooklyn quartet continue to expand their musical horizons. The impeccably structured Sunbathing Animal calls back to their Texan roots, its wide-open sprawl freed of the band's explicitly urban trappings.

title: Emma Jean
label: Truth & Soul
description: Lee Fields isn't really a throwback—he's always been singing, even when nobody was listening. The R&B singer's latest with his band the Expressions follows in line with the albums he's released since his late-1990s revival; it's simply another notch in a heavily hash-marked belt.

title: Separate Oceans
label: Numero Group
description: Patrick “Ned” Doheny was part of the SoCal scene of singer-songwriters couch-jumping around the canyon and dreaming of stardom. Pretty much every song Doheny ever recorded or released classifies as a rarity, which means for most listeners Separate Oceans, comprised of 19 songs from Ned Doheny’s three albums from the 1970s, seeded with demos and alternate takes featuring some of his more famous friends will be an introduction into his sun-drenched world.

title: Charmer
label: Run for Cover
description: Three of the five members of Pennsylvania indie rockers Tigers Jaw quit the band before their latest album was recorded, but they stayed on to finish Charmer; as a result, the album comes off like a smooth segue into a new incarnation of the band rather than a sudden, painful break or an awkward growth spurt.

title: Only Run
label: self-released
description: Clap Your Hands Say Yeah's fourth full-length was preceded by the departure of three fifths of the band’s formative line-up, and includes contributions from the National's Matt Berninger and Kid Koala. The album has the feel of a band being reconstructed in real time.

title: Superunknown
label: UME
description: Upon its release Superunknown wasn’t just a highly anticipated album from a critically acclaimed rock band—it was Soundgarden’s long overdue turn to come out on top. The 1994 album's being reissued in two-and-five-disc sets; some 20 years later, the album represents the platonic ideal of what a mainstream hard rock record should be.

title: Because I'm Worth It
label: self-released
description: Her first full-length since the dissolution of hers and Dean Blunt's Hype Williams project, abstract beatmaker Inga Copeland's latest is a strange, singular record that offers as many questions as it does answers. It's not an easy listen, but she wouldn't have it any other way.

title: Midtown 120 Blues
label: Comatonse
description: Terre Thaemlitz is best known as an experimental, electro-acoustic composer, and she has released difficult, conceptual works for labels like Mille Plateaux since the mid-90s. Her 2009 album is getting a no-frills reissue because of its scarcity, and it's a treatise on house music that attempts to debunk the myth that house music was an all-accepting, pan-cultural utopia.

title: Beauty & Ruin
label: Merge
description: By all accounts, Bob Mould is on a roll: the former Hüsker Dü frontman's 2011 autobiography and 2012 LP Silver Age were as much capitulations as they were triumphs. His latest solo LP feels like an extension of Silver Age's impassioned buzz and thrust, less a sequel to its counterpart than an appendix.

title: Disgraceland
label: Atlantic
description: Still not old enough to legally drink in most states but old enough to go to war, suburban-Chicago garage-punks the Orwells are fully aware they’re reinventing a wheel that’s been essentially worn down to the rim. Their first major-label outing suggests that the Orwells clearly have loftier ambitions than cracking the Midwest garage circuit.

title: Glass Boys
label: Matador
description: Fucked Up's new album is a relatively compact, dense piece of metacriticism taking an unsparing look at the genre of its creators and its social mores. It's a very personal work and, more crucially, one that doesn’t preach or provide answers.

title: Dead Unique
label: Blackest Ever Black
description: Officer! was a revolving-door band that centered around Half Japanese sometimes-member Mick Hobbs, taking on an off-kilter sound that was psychedelic and distinctly English. 1995's Dead Unique is seeing release from electronic label Blackest Ever Black, but it's not a reissue—rather, it's a record that just never got released, and suitably nothing is quite as it seems on this strange album.

title: Strange Breaks & Mr. Thing III
label: BBE
description: Marc Bowles is ridiculously dedicated to the art of unearthing what-on-Earth 45s and stringing them together with little regard for genre, national origin, or much of anything else besides a certain feel of knuckleball unpredictability. The third volume of his curation seriesis as characteristically preposterous as the previous two, crammed with cuts from various genres and threading them into a free-for-all that scans as hip-hop.

title: The Feast of the Broken Heart
label: Atlantic
description: Hercules and Love Affair's mission has remained consistent throughout: to breathe new life into the sounds and structures of early dance music, particularly the interplay between producer and vocalist that underpinned the genre’s formative years. The project's third album transcends mere homage not only through sonic innovations but by the quality of the emotional connection it makes with its audience.

title: No Peace
label: Odd Future
description: Trash Talk don't need to move beyond hardcore's lockstep for new ground, because they are finding plenty of room within it. Featuring appearances by the Alchemist and King Krule, their latest is their most sustained effort, adding microhooks, catchier riffs, and song structures to the lean skeletons of their songs.

title: A U R O R A
label: Mute
description: The Australia-born, Iceland-based composer returns with his best album yet. Unlike his past work, there are no guitars, piano, or stringed instruments; instead, the 41-minute collection focuses on synthesizers and the heavy percussion of ex-Liturgy drummer and current Guardian Alien leader Greg Fox and Swans’ Thorr Harris.

title: Witch
label: Superior Viaduct
description: Leslie Winer's debut album, which has been recently reissued, is widely assumed to have been heard by a number of trip-hop figureheads. She also looped a similar thread through soul, hip-hop, dub, and punk, linking it to the despair of a country battered by over a decade of right-wing rule.

title: Gz II Godz
label: self-released
description: After Huntsville, Ala. rap duo G-Side released iSLAND in 2011, they called it quits, with ST 2 Lettaz and Clova claiming the separation was amicable. Their comeback album picks up where they left off with their humble-focused style, suggesting that, despite the time away, they haven't changed much.

title: Incursio
label: Mexican Summer
