description: Los Angeles producer Ian Evans has made beats for A$AP Ferg and Kelela, and his debut LP as Napolian is a collection of electro-influenced instrumentals, ranging from lighthearted, disco-inflected dance grooves to more hard-edged earphone music.

title: Alternate Worlds EP
label: Joyful Noise
description: Ryan Lott's most recent album as Son Lux, last year's Lanterns, communicated an ambivalence with the modern world, with Lott yearning for an escape to undefined "alternate worlds". His new EP reconfigures songs from Lanterns and includes a contribution from Lorde; his previously sanguine outlook has been scrubbed away, darkened, and clouded over until it resembles something closer to weary skepticism, if not outright cynicism.

title: The Moon Rang Like A Bell
label: OWSLA
description: The second full-length from Hundred Waters is not an evolution so much as a refinement. If 2012’s Hundred Waters saw the electro-folk band sketching out the borders of their sound, The Moon Rang Like a Bell finds them zeroing in on what they do best and going deeper.

title: A Period of Review (Original Recordings: 1975-1983)
label: Rvng Intl.
description: Experimental artist Kerry Leimer self-released his and others' work on his Palace of Lights imprint, and the erudite RVNG imprint has put together this collection of unreleased tracks that position Leimer as one of the few American artists who worked in the field of kosmiche at the time of the sub-genre's original peak.

title: Fortuna
label: Carpark
description: Jangle-rockers Popstrangers recently moved from New Zealand to London, and their sophomore album arrives with a pronounced uptick in ambition that matches their big geographical move. Despite the band's name, Fortuna is less "strange" and more "pop".

title: Initiation
label: Zoo Music
description: As Haunted Hearts, Dee Dee of Dum Dum Girls and her husband Brandon Welchez of Crocodiles have made an album loosely based around the New York underground of the 1970s and ‘80s.

title: Sylvan Esso
label: Partisan
description: The debut LP from Mountain Man's Amelia Meath and Megafaun's Nick Sanborn fills an obvious void. The Durham, NC duo’s fusion of quirky folk and quirky electro-pop would have otherwise been inevitably and awkwardly willed into existence, which is a good starting point for Sylvan Esso—but it’s also their endgame as well.

title: Do It Again
label: Interscope
description: Robyn and Röyksopp's collaborative mini-album has the epic sweep of a proper album, with contemplative instrumental passages helping frame the more conventional songwriting. The freedom they've given themselves on Do It Again is both what makes the record refreshing and what keeps it from satisfying listeners as a more streamlined full-length would.

title: Wheedle's Groove: Seattle Funk, Soul & Modern Boogie: Volume II 1972-1987
label: Light in the Attic
description: The vision of late 1960s and early '70s Seattle R&B as laid out by Light in the Attic's 2005 comp Wheedle's Groove permeated everything in reach of your speakers, and this collection proves that finding so many lost gems the first time around wasn't just a fluke.

title: Shade Themes From Kairos
label: Drag City
description: Though Stephen O’ Malley, Randall Dunn, and Oren Ambarchi have exhausting rosters of collaborations and contributions, their respective drone-and-doom credits remain preeminent for many. On Shade Themes From Kairos, this trio’s collective résumé turns the preceding four tracks into a wonderland of intrigue, where disparate influences twist and turn into uncanny phantasms.

title: Meteorites
description: For five albums now, Echo and the Bunnymen have been reduced to a duo of Ian McCulloch and guitarist Will Sergeant. As distinctive as they both are, they miss the rhythmic push they used to get when they had a fully integrated rhythm section with as much creative agency in the band.

title: Suburban Light
label: Merge
description: This welcome reissue of the Clientele's first full-length restores it to its UK tracklisting and artwork and puts it back in print on vinyl for the first time in years. The original album has lost none of its evocative indie pop brilliance, and the bonus disc fleshes out the story of the band's early days.

title: Are We There
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Are We There may be Sharon Van Etten's most present-tense album to date, her most immediate and urgent—the peak of a steady upward trajectory. Her songs emphasize the moment, both in the quality of her performance and in the rawness of her lyrics.

title: Melting Sun
label: Prophecy
description: Early last year, Markus Siegenhort, leader of the German black metal explorers Lantlôs, elected to split with Neige, the leader of France’s Alcest and one of the key figures in carrying black metal past its atavistic beginnings. Despite the breakup, on Melting Sun, Lantlôs’ fourth and most cohesive album, Siegenhort likewise sings sans ire, his mid-range croon ferried upward by a set of gentle effects.

title: 10 Years Of Full Pupp
label: Full Pupp
description: The releases on Prins Thomas' Full Pupp label are often pigeonholed as "space disco"—a term addressing the idea that this is music people might want to dance or relax to in equal measure. This pair of mixes from Thomas, featuring label material both new and old, prove to be good companions.

title: Special Victim
label: Bloodmoss
description: Austin noise-pop foursome Future Death recorded their debut LP at a former Dallas funeral home-turned-studio owned by indie super-producer John Congleton; the distorted production and limited sonic range accentuates the sophisticated songcraft trying to poke through the surface squall.

title: Good to Be Home
label: Nature Sounds
description: Blu has the tendency to frustrate, willingly or otherwise. The Cali rapper's latest is especially aggravating in that it's a decent record from a way-better-than-decent artist.

title: In Conflict
label: Domino
description: Since abandoning his Final Fantasy guise to make music under his own name, Owen Pallett's treated his work like a logic maze; on his latest, which features contributions from Brian Eno, he steps free of his own labyrinth, resulting in his most pleading and open vocal performances.

title: Reachy Prints
label: Warp
description: Plaid have been reliable fixtures in “intelligent dance music” since the genre first rose to prominence in the 1990s. Their latest, Reachy Prints, is full of new sounds, but their experimentation is tempered with strides towards a greater accessibility.

title: Tomorrow
label: Blue Flea
description: Tomorrow is the debut solo work from ambient duo Windy & Carl's Carl Hultgren, a limited release complemented by a download with extra tracks that push the runtime to around two hours. It’s quiet music that’s strangely deafening in its way, never letting up in its constant tide of sound.

title: In Cold Blood
label: Crush
description: Morgan Kibby sings, plays keyboards, and contributes songwriting to M83; as White Sea, her over-the-top synth-pop straddles the line between "cheesy" and "cool", and the best moments on her debut LP find a balance between those two poles.

title: The Death of Rave (A Partial Flashback) / We Drink to Forget the Coming Storm
label: History Always Favours the Winners
description: Leyland Kirby has a prolific work ethic, and his latest releases are certainly evidence of that: a culling of material from his 20-hour long The Death of Rave album as V/Vm, and a three-hour album under his own name that closely resembles his work as the Caretaker.

title: ...And Then You Shoot Your Cousin
label: Def Jam
description: …And Then You Shoot Your Cousin finds the Roots in some version of the comfy purgatory they've been residing since How I Got Over. That isn't to say there isn't plenty to think about on Cousin, but most of that thought comes from mood, arrangement, and implication.

title: Keine Oase in Sicht
label: Dekorder
description: Many bands call themselves “collectives,” but few make music that actually sounds communal and leaderless. German experimental outfit Datashock are part of that small club, and their latest album represents their strongest effort to date.

title: The Sleeping Beauties: A Collection of Early and Unreleased Works
label: Into the Light
description: Not to be conflated with fellow Greek countryman and the Chariots of Fire theme composer, this particular Vangelis is also a composer of dulcet tones, yet one whose body of work has hovered just under the radar outside of his native country since the 1980s. This handy introduction to his work shows this composer’s wide range.

title: Faces
label: self-released
description: Faces finds Mac Miller embracing a typical 2010s rapper trope: the exploratory between-album mixtape. Over an hour and a half, he advances on his last LP's heady sprawl with a palette stretching from rainy day introspection to playful wordplay exercises.

title: Da Mind of Traxman Vol. 2
label: Planet Mu
description: Traxman practically wrote footwork's rulebook over the last three decades. The second volume of his Da Mind of Traxman series is trimmer and more muscular than its predecessor, even as it maintains his signature playfulness.

title: Definitely Maybe: Chasing the Sun Edition
label: Big Brother
description: Oasis were terrible at being The Biggest Band in the World, but as this 20th anniversary reissue of their first album—a three-disc collection packed with demos and live performances—makes sparklingly clear, they were amazing at wanting to be The Biggest Band in the World.

title: Lullabies Help the Brain Grow / No Matter How Long the Line at the Cafeteria, There's Always a Seat
label: Light in the Attic
description: 1980s post-hardcore outfit Big Boys' pair of albums are seeing reissue; while hardcore still raged during their existence, the band set the pace for the sounds of post-hardcore that were yet to come.

title: Fabriclive 75
label: Fabric
description: Grime saw a major resurgence in 2013, and Butterz heads Elijah & Skilliam are central to London's scene. Their second official mix CD, for Fabric's Fabriclive series, serves as an overview of the producers and tracks in their orbit rather than as a representation of their DJ sets.

title: Ultima II Massage
label: Ghostly
description: Ultima II Massage finds the Black Moth Super Rainbow frontman moving from the gently corroded Technicolor psych-prog of 2010’s Maniac Meat to a full-on barrage of wobbling, low-end-heavy bizarro pop. Tom Fec’s work as Tobacco is frequently approached as a dichotomy of beauty and ugliness, and at times the "ugly" quotient is often ramped up to match the project's warped, grotty imagery.

title: American Football
label: Polyvinyl
description: The deluxe reissue of American Football's only LP benefits from unusually good timing: as self-identifying emo bands are making music that’s more mature, refined, and exploratory than anything that came before it, American Football is currently the most influential album in the genre.

title: Hyperdub 10.1
label: Hyperdub
description: 10.1 is a two-disc set—the first in a series, no less—celebrating 10 years of the Hyperdub label, with one disc collecting tracks from the archive and the other showcasing new material. It's an expansive and impressive look at what makes this hard-to-pigeonhole label consistently exciting.

title: Stereo Is King
label: Innova
description: Mason Bates, a DJ and composer, is fascinated by sounds, and it doesn't matter where they come from. His imagination for tone colors and textures is obvious on Stereo Is King, and they unfold across a spectrum.

title: Some Heavy Ocean
label: Sargent House
description: To date, Emma Ruth Rundle’s stabs at crafting a musical identity have been tentative ones. Her previous solo material has been guitar-centric and mostly instrumental, but her new solo album is different. She not only sings, but she does so a lot—and when she does, she soars.

title: L'amour
label: Light in the Attic
description: The liner notes for Light in the Attic’s new reissue of L’Amour, the only known album by an artist known as Lewis*,* read more like a murder mystery than a making-of. Full of gently dissolving melodies and gossamer synths (credited to a guy named Philip Lees, also a mystery), the album has become crate-digger lore, as much for the backstory as for the music itself.

title: Full Cold Moon
label: Heartworm
description: After parting ways with Matador, Cold Cave's Wesley Eisold has said that his band's last LP, Cherish the Light Years, is “the Cold Cave I can’t stand to hear.” This collection rounding up his subsequent singles suggests that, in the time since, he’s treated that record like a rejected transplant.

title: Ghost Stories
label: Atlantic
description: Ghost Stories is unmistakably Coldplay's "breakup album," a subdued work that finds Chris Martin and his band crisply moping through mid-tempo soundscapes and fuzzy electronic touches that have the visceral impact of a down comforter tumbling down a flight of stairs.

title: Boys
label: Exit Stencil
description: Herzog’s Boys is a record you’ll never be able to mistake for anything else because all its ideas are laid out plain as day. The band's third, most fully realized record is ready to be soaked up by sad boys and girls who grew up on Weezer’s Blue Album, Thin Lizzy, cheap beer, and suburban ennui.

title: Volume X
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Nearly a quarter century has passed since the poker-faced, tongue-in-cheek trio of Trans Am began making post-rock on its own terms: synthesized, mysterious, and obsessed with classic-pop/rock kitsch. Volume X, the unkillable band’s unsatisfying 10th full-length, lacks focus and force.

title: The Encyclopedia of Arto Lindsay
label: Northern Spy
description: If there’s a constant in the career of Arto Lindsay, it’s in the way he positions deep contrasts in close proximity to one another. This two-disc set spans Lindsay’s solo career circa 1996-2004—a live album and a best-of compilation—and this release is a rare case where both documents feed off one another.

title: WinterSpringSummerFall
label: self-released
description: Beyoncé collaborator and producer/singer/rapper Boots' debut project works in the same realm of his contributions to Beyoncé, as he builds tense, pretty atmospheres with his sweeping production. His talent is capable, if not exactly distinctive.

title: Upside Down Mountain
label: Nonesuch
description: Conor Oberst has been a musician in the public eye for nearly half of his life, and over the past decade, he’d be most accurately described as a folk artist. Upside Down Mountain is Oberst’s latest documentation of his obsessions with escape, death, the passing of time, and the potential of finding serenity in an assumed identity.

title: II
label: Peoples Potential Unlimited
description: Atlanta-based producer Moon B's music has an untenable aspect to its sound. On his new album, the music has grown trickier, but it hasn’t ranged far from what Moon B laid down on his first singles.

title: Metamodern Sounds in Country Music
label: High Top Mountain
description: This Kentucky-born singer-songwriter is a quester, intrigued by the metaphysics of spiritual experience and wondering aloud if the Bible and a handful of 'shrooms will lead you to the same religious epiphany. Regardless, there are no extraneous sounds or ideas on his new album, nothing that’s not battened down to a carefully structured set of lyrics and melodies.

title: FreeBase EP
label: self-released
description: 2 Chainz is rap’s court jester of the moment. FreeBase, his recently released free EP, allows 2 Chainz to stay in character without overstretching his shtick.

title: The Serpent & the Sphere
label: Profound Lore
description: For a band that’s spent the last 15 years gracefully and aggressively testing the limits of the sound of heavy metal, Portland’s Agalloch have committed very few errors. Their fifth album delivers the depth and development that have become synonymous with Agalloch.

title: Days of Abandon
artist: The Pains of Being Pure at Heart
label: Yebo
description: On the Pains of Being Pure at Heart's third album, Days of Abandon, frontman Kip Berman is a young romantic in a state of flux. Once a starry-eyed daydreamer pitching woo at anybody in earshot, Berman now sounds like a guy who's  looking to reconcile his youthful idealism with the complexities and complications of post-adolescent coupling.

title: Membrane Pop
label: Mexican Summer
description: Dan Hayhurst and Reuben Sutherland's Software debut as Sculpture plays like theme music for a cartoon parents might catch out of the corner of their eye and momentarily worry about what their children are being exposed to. The music has a certain kidlike purity, aiming for complex ideas as simply as possible.

title: Hour of the Dawn
label: Hardly Art
description: On the third La Sera album, Katy Goodman, former bassist for the now-defunct Vivian Girls, finds the right balance of joy and heartbreak. An album that could be sad based on the lyric sheet is stuffed with delirious fret runs, muscular drum fills, and sunny guitars soaked with reverb.

title: Sincerely Yours
label: HBK Gang
description: DJ Mustard has the hits to rightfully claim ratchet music's crown, but Richmond rapper/producer Iamsu! has equally pushed the minimalist Cali sound to the masses. His debut LP, Sincerely Yours, is Su’s opportunity to move forward through the doors he's already opened.

title: Easy Pain
label: Temporary Residence
description: Over the years, Kentucky trio Young Widows have used the heaviness of their members' past in the post-hardcore outfit Breather Resist as a foundation for a flexible stylistic composite. Their fourth album swings toward belligerence and volume.

title: Xscape
label: Epic
description: Michael Jackson was a perfectionist about his music, and he recorded many more songs than he ever released. That means that there's a lot of unreleased material in his archives; Michael appeared in 2010, and now we've got this strange, underfed, vaguely horrid eight-song record.

title: Desideratum
label: The Flenser
description: As Planning for Burial, Thom Wasluck filters post-metal, doom, ambient, and goth-rock through his own terminally miserable lens. Desideratum is his second full-length and first for the Flenser; it's an improvement on his earlier work, bringing together the many different sides found on his smaller releases.

title: Farmer's Corner
label: Fire
description: Throughout the last decade, James Jackson Toth's released a steady stream of rangy folk, rock, and folk-rock records under various guises. His latest sounds like he's adjusting to his role as a cult figure among cult figures.

title: Yellow Memories
label: Eglo
description: Fatima Bramme Sey wrestles beneath the combined weight of expectations, aspirations, and existential hardship. Her debut LP oscillates from genre to genre in keeping with the traditions of Eglo Records, the eclectic family of artists assembled by electronic producer Floating Points and label head Alexander Nut.

title: EP 1
label: Fool's Gold
description: Suffolk, Va. rap producer Lex Luger’s finally starting to explore the micro-genre of trap that he accidentally had a hand in creating. His first EP with A-Trak as Low Pros is the best kind of team-up record, where two artists with two very different aesthetics get together and find common ground by throwing everything they have against the wall.

title: White Women
label: Atlantic
description: Chromeo have made it a decade without a widely beloved full-length—instead, they're known more for a few great singles and their winking revivalist aesthetic. But in 2014, this works in their favor: with no classic hanging over their heads and no true expectations, it's easy to be seduced by their quietly fantastic fourth album White Women.

title: Death
label: Norma Evangelium Diaboli
description: Spanish duo Teitanblood have never cared much for niceties, preferring to lambast their hapless listeners with walls of horrific noise. Death, their second full-length is a bitter pill to swallow. Their sound is ugly and intense, but there's a studied musicality concealed within the fracas.

title: Love
label: Sacred Bones
description: Damon McMahon’s work as Amen Dunes has been a process of expansion, andLove is an even grander step forward, both in the roster of musicians McMahon employs—including members of Iceage andGodspeed You! Black Emperor—and the more accessible, classic-leaning songs he’s written.

title: American Interior
label: Turnstile
description: Super Furry Animals frontman Gruff Rhys' latest solo project was inspired by his recent discovery that he's a descendent of John Evans, a Welsh explorer from the 1790s. The resulting LP is far more robust and widescreen-scaled than the modest, folk-oriented music Rhys has thus far released under his own name, in tune with the Super Furry Animals’ manic genre-blurring, retro-futurist mandate.

title: Cool Planet
label: Guided By Voices, Inc.
description: A workmanlike quality—both charismatic and chilling—has grown since Guided by Voices reformed for their lackluster 2012 album Let’s Go Eat the Factory, and it’s carried over into their sixth comeback full-length, Cool Planet. The line between exhilarating and exasperating is still being straddled to the point where it's starting to chafe.

title: Turn Blue
label: Nonesuch
description: Working once again with Brian "Danger Mouse" Burton, the Black Keys try for a moodier, more atmospheric record. Turn Blue sounds distant and subdued, a murky-sounding collection of '70s stoner-rock facsimiles and swirling gray tones.

title: Alas Rattoisaa Virtaa
label: Dekorder
description: More so than on any previous release, Alas Rattoisaa Virtaa, the group’s latest full-length, finds the unclassifiable Finnish collective working primarily with identifiably electronic sounds. The sonic palette and approach are reminiscent of collagists such as Ground Zero and Black Dice, where free-floating noise objects coalesce into loose, slushy grooves.

title: Bermuda Waterfall
label: Arbutus
description: Sean Nicholas Savage wrote most of Bermuda Waterfall, his 11th studio album since 2008, when traveling. He has a memorable way of describing the sights of an otherwise common existence, and he’s breathed new life into his homespun arrangements, learning to dive deeper into himself.

title: Changing Light
label: Absolute Magnitude
description: Mirah launched her career at the end of the 1990s in Olympia, Washington, and while she no longer lives there, the city's twin legacies of riot grrl and twee pop still faintly cling to her sound. Her latest album reflects a marked sonic shift from polish to grit, with contributions from Mary Timony, Greg Saunier, and Jherek Bischoff, among others.

title: Nabuma Rubberband
label: Because Music
description: During the recording process of Little Dragon's fourth LP, singer Yukimi Nagano wandered around the band’s longtime hometown of Gothenberg in winter while listening to Janet Jackson. When Nagano and the band don’t stick too closely to dance music or downtempo on the album, the results are adventurous.

title: To Be Kind
label: Mute
description: With 2012’s colossal The Seer, Swans released a record that seemed designed to test the commitment of the band’s most ardent followers yet expanded their audience to an unprecedented degree. Michael Gira seems aware that anticipation for a new Swans album has never been greater, so he’s responded in the best way possible: by producing a record that is every bit The Seer’s equal.

title: The God Complex
label: self-released
description: GoldLink is a 20-year-old rapper with a sound all his own. Brightly colored, hyper, and upbeat, the Virginia native's music featured on his first mixtape draws openly from genres that street rap usually has no time for: bachata, go-go, classic house.

title: Best of Boiler Room Classics
artist: Mike Adams At His Honest Weight
label: Flannelgraph
description: Mike Adams is a goofball in the best sense, a guy who leads with his sense of humor, and that extends to the music he makes as Mike Adams at His Honest Weight. His second album projects an identity through musical cues, speaking through the shared language of pop.

title: Youth Culture Forever
label: Fat Cat
description: The sophomore album from Scottish trio PAWS arrives to both praise and bury youth. But while they spend time recounting the well-worn experiences of being young—the drunkenness, the heartbreak, the drunken heartbreak—they also push aside foolish things in favor of sober observations, giving them gravitas beyond their years.

title: We On 1 EP
label: Southern Belle
description: In an alternate universe, this EP from the late DJ Rashad would provide four tracks' worth of proof that the juke/footwork pioneer's 2013 breakthrough Double Cup was just the beginning of his next leap forward. As it stands, it's a concentrated jolt of wide-ranging takes on an already down-for-whatever sound, with Rashad throwing odd asides and funny mutations into the 160-BPM barrage of digital percussion.

title: Southsiders
label: Rhymesayers
description: About 10 years ago, already well into a flourishing career, the bluster and self-evisceration of the early records Slug made with producer Ant as Atmosphere suddenly bored him. So he started penning compassionate character sketches while Ant warmed and loosened up their sound with live instruments. Southsiders extends the "quietly durable" phase of the Minneapolis duo's lifespan.

title: Divide and Exit
label: Harbinger Sound
description: The Grantham, England, duo Sleaford Mods newest album, Divide and Exit, is about as punk as punk gets in 2014: Singer Jason Williamson speed-talks bile while Andrew Fearn provides coarse backing tracks, which barely get beyond cheap plastic keyboard presets.

title: In the Hollows
label: Western Vinyl
description: The gist of Nat Baldwin’s music is more interesting than his membership in Dirty Projectors, the selling point his name has most often evoked for much of the last decade. On his latest, In the Hollows, Baldwin falls far into a quagmire of the expected, not only with vocals that take no new chances but also with a cast of collaborators that, however accomplished, scans like a cliché.

title: Product of Industry
label: Ghostly International
description: Like Todd Terje, Mark Evetts rode into the spotlight in the mid-2000s on the strength of his bedroom edits.  Product of Industry is a concept album of sorts that conveys the dark side of industrialization: boredom, hopelessness, depression, and pollution all find a musical corollary here.

title: TANHÂ
label: self-released
description: TANHÂ is a collaboration by Japanese artists Arµ-2 and Lee. The album belongs to a strand of meta-music that takes the surplus of recorded media as both backdrop and subject.

title: Sheezus
label: Regal
description: Lily Allen possesses a terrific flair for irony, but there's a fine line between using irony to make a cutting point and using it as a protective coating to hide the fact that you're not sure exactly what you're trying to say. She was once a master of the former, but her new album, Sheezus, is another story.

title: Histrionic
label: Not Not Fun
description: Maria Juur moved from her own native Estonia to Brooklyn before writing and recording her third LP as Maria Minerva, Histrionic; here, the songs are stronger and more fully formed than on previous efforts.

title: Amber's Stuff
label: UNO
description: Day-to-day life isn't really much of a gimmick, but when Zane Reynolds works out his musical impulses, that's often the context he finds himself in. Originally self-released as a CDR in 2011, his latest SFV Acid release possesses a distinctly personal weight, revealing the inventory of a vividly remembered relationship.

title: II
label: Run for Cover
description: Swedish punks Makthaverskan embody a reaction to what they considered to be a conformist, “happy and cute” indie scene in Gothenberg. Their new album is an interior and personal record of constricted scope, one of unhinged beauty that can be wrested from longing and anger.

title: Asiatisch
label: Hyperdub
description: Notions of place and displacement feature strongly in the works of Fatima Al Qadiri. The Brooklyn-based producer refers to her debut full-length as a “virtual road trip through ‘imagined China,’” refracting the skewed manner in which Asian motifs have sunk into Western pop culture.

title: Ocean Death EP
label: Anticon
description: Will Wiesenfeld's latest EP as Baths, Ocean Death, hits you in the head with enormous, blunt impact. Following his most recent record, last year's Obsidian, the EP showcases the singer’s continued focus on mortality and heartbreak.

title: Postsocial
label: Profound Lore
description: For more than a decade, the deliberately enigmatic, incredibly abrasive Wold have cloaked black metal beats and screams and maniacal guitar playing in a dynamic web of harsh noise and electronic contortion. Their seventh album and second since the act relocated from Saskatchewan to Rhode Island delivers a disorienting mix of power and poise.

title: Breathing Statues
label: Carpark
description: In spite of their best efforts, Young Magic managed to distinguish themselves from their peers with their 2012 album, Melt. On their new album, they’re every bit as intent on blending in with the surrounding scenery instead of standing out, and this time, they’re very successful in doing so.

title: Heavy Hearted in Doldrums
label: Aesop
description: The San Jose rapper’s unorthodox approach situates him with broader, border-crossing peers like Le1f, Big Baby Ghandi, and Cities Aviv. His new album finds him in a more meloncholy mood, but sadness is ultimately powerless before his insatiable libido.

title: Luminous
label: XL
description: The similarities between the Horrors' last album and their latest are disappointing if you value how they've previously made radical transformations from album to album. Luminous is an incremental move towards the edge of the 1990s, where the band slips inside this Hacienda, coloring with sunlight and glowsticks rather than pretty in pink pastels.

title: Nikki Nack
label: 4AD
description: Merrill Garbus' music as tUnE-yArDs has always been playful but extremely confident. Her third album, Nikki Nack, is more reserved than 2011's w h o k i l l; when Garbus calms down here, she does it with the grace and certainty of an archer drawing back her bow—less a concession than a show of power.

title: Attica!
label: Shake It
description: Attica!—indie rockers Wussy’s fifth collection of new material—is a nostalgic record, and not just because of that vaguely ’90s sound. It’s an album about growing up, remembering, and the relationships that accompany those remembrances.

title: Life Among the Savages
label: Memphis Industries
description: Jason Quever has been writing and recording as Papercuts for well over a decade at this point, fleshing out his take on the last 50 years of oft-dreamy, pillow-soft pop-rock. His new full-length places a spotlight on his skills as a producer and arranger playing with several new variations on his warm, woodsy music.

title: Artificial Sweeteners
label: Yep Roc
description: If Fujiya & Miyagi started out ahead of a trend curve, they sounded increasingly commonplace over the intervening years, and at this point they’re the ones rushing to catch up. On new album Artificial Sweeteners, they inject their mannered krautrock with an energizing dose of techno, a shift ostensibly executed to propel them into contemporary relevance.

title: Someday World
label: Warp
description: Brian Eno is rarely idle. His latest, Someday World, is a collaboration with Underworld’s Karl Hyde, and, like much of Eno’s recent output, it’s released by Warp. Eno's presented the record as a collection of half-thoughts he tried to salvage after browsing through a stray hard drive one afternoon.

title: I Never Learn
label: LL
description: Inspired by a cross-continental move following a painful breakup, Lykke Li's ballad-heavy I Never Learn is for the times when heartbreak is so life-affirming that you want to share the feeling with the world.

title: Waiting for Surfin’ Bird
label: Decoherence
description: Davey Harms, who records and performs as Mincemeat or Tenspeed, typically makes big, scruffy beats solely with feedback loops that he coaxes from pedals and mixers. Waiting for Surfin’ Bird is the first release on which Harms uses conventional electronic instruments such as synths and sequencers, and it's proof that his magic isn’t dependent on his tools.

title: Threat To Creation
label: Mexican Summer
description: After UK punk’s first wave had crashed, Adrian Sherwood, a dub scene honcho who’d eventually go on to play an influential role in the industrial movement, assembled some of the more committed players that had established themselves in the burgeoning post-punk scene into a revolving-door dub group called the New Age Steppers. Now, their 1981 album with Sherwood collaborators Creation Rebel's seeing official release in the U.S. for the first time.

title: Libertine
label: Comedy Minus One
description: Of all the obscure indie-rock bands to surface during the 1990s, few were as curious as Montana's Silkworm. Like a lot of their catalog, their 1994 Steve Albini-recorded third album, Libertine, is a series of unconventional decisions made with conventional tools.

title: Shrink Dust
label: Sub Pop
description: If everything Chad VanGaalen touches seems to have a repellant, piss-pungent weirdness about it, that's kind of a ruse—his records of jangly junkyard-pop are warm, inviting, and surprisingly easy to love. His latest, Shrink Dust, is possibly his best, and certainly his most confident; it's the closest we've come yet to getting inside his head.

title: A Letter Home
label: Third Man
description: Neil Young has spent the past few months making moves on something he's been passionately preaching about for a while now: studio-quality audio made accessible to the masses. So what's the first album Young puts out after raising $6.2 million for Pono on Kickstarter? A sepia-toned long-player with a sound that would sit comfortably next to late 1920s Jimmie Rodgers or Carter Family records.

title: Refractory Obdurate
label: Glitterhouse
description: Throughout his career, David Eugene Edwards has mixed gospel and bluegrass, rocking both punk and gothic on a forever-sliding scale. His seventh album as Wovenhand is his "heavy record", making good on the project's post-punk and metal influences while exploring his Christianity that anchors the music he makes.

title: Lost Colony
label: Merge
description: After two albums of instrumental guitar pieces that drew comparisons to steel-string greats, William Tyler tries for a completely different musical atmosphere: that of a standard-issue rock band playing live in a room. Among the three tracks are a Michael Rother cover, providing an unusual  kraut-country hybrid.

title: That's Harakiri
label: Tri Angle
description: Sd Laika's Peter Runge is a Milwaukee producer with a low-key social media presence and enough of a distinct game plan to wind up on the same label as Forest Swords and Evian Christ. His new LP presents real agitation in the form of scrambled rhythms and mutated grime figures, with no real accessible entry point.

title: Nightclubbing
label: Island
description: In 1980, Grace Jones decamped to Compass Point Studios in Nassau, Bahamas where she worked with producers Alex Sadkin and Island Records’ president Chris Blackwell, as well as a crack team of session musicians rooted by the rhythmic reggae force of Sly & Robbie. Across three critical and commercial hit albums, with 1981’s Nightclubbing as her pinnacle, Jones reinvented herself while also altering the face of modern pop.

title: Arcadia
label: Terrible
description: Over the last year, Chairlift's Caroline Polachek was playing secret shows and debuting new material under increasingly inventive, singer-songwriterly pseudonyms such as Ramona Lisa, the name under which she’s presented her solo debut, Arcadia. The album is a quiet curiosity, a quirky side project that’s mostly a labor of love.

title: Loose Power
label: Glacial Pace
description: Loose Power, the debut album by ex-Unwound singer/guitarist Justin Trosper’s new band, Survival Knife, is not a traditional pop-rock record by anyone’s definition. But it is the closest he’s ever come to making anything remotely like one.

title: Prins Thomas III
label: Full Pupp
description: On Prins Thomas' new LP, III, disco’s presence in the mix has been muted and in many places overshadowed by ambient music. Overall, III serves as a low-key but intensely effective rebuttal to dance music's self-seriousness.

title: Get Back
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Stephen McBean has always made music for the open road, but if you value your own safety, don’t listen to Get Back, his first record as Pink Mountaintops in five years, while behind the wheel—or for that matter, while doing anything that requires specific and steady motor skills.

title: Bécs
label: Editions Mego
description: Christian Fennesz's 2001 album Endless Summer was a go-to album of electronic music for people who don’t necessarily listen to a lot of electronic music. For his new record, Fennesz has returned to both the label and the style that provided that breakthrough.

title: Food
label: Ninja Tune
description: Kelis' new Food—produced by TV on the Radio's Dave Sitek and released on indie Ninja Tune—shows the singer in unusual form: ragged, raspy, somewhere between exhausted from effort and deep in reflection.

title: The Honeymoon Workbook
label: Umor Rex
description: The Chicago trio Good Willsmith—three 20-somethings using synths, pedals, and loop stations to make drifting, abstract music—spent years concocting fascinating small-run releases. The semi-public woodshedding culminates on The Honeymoon Workbook, a continuous 41-minute suite.

title: Midnight Passenger
label: Goner
description: The Memphis rock band Ex-Cult's newest 10 songs don't offer a significant step away from the sound they had established on their singles and 2012 self-titled debut. However, on Midnight Passenger, the improved production opens up the band's sound exponentially.

title: Flashbacks and Dream Sequences: The Story of the Moles
label: Fire
description: For the purpose of this compilation, “The Moles” refers to two projects. The first is the Sydney indie pop band fronted by Richard Davies that was active in the late ‘80s and early ‘90s. The second's the psychedelic chamber-pop solo project Davies launched after that band broke up. This reissue collects the complete works of both.

title: Southern Skies EP
label: self-released
description: Daniel Blumberg wrote the majority of Yuck’s excellent self-titled debut and when he left the band, he took most of its underdog snarl, bite, and sadness with him. Last year the new Yuck released Glow & Behold without him, and the quick turnaround for this Southern Skies EP feels like a bit of damage control.

title: More Than Any Other Day
label: Constellation
description: Montreal-based art-punk band Ought’s debut is an endearing and electrifying album that treats panic attacks and adrenalized ecstasy as two sides of the same pounding heart. It’s an anxious, distressed record to be sure, but it presents itself as such simply to show you how that nervous energy can be put to constructive use.

title: Phantom Vibrate EP
label: LuckyMe
description: The Montreal producer's latest release is built extra lush and cushiony, with heavy R&B inflections.

title: Melancholia
label: Temporary Residence
description: Melancholia isn’t a lost album, but it’s one that’s easily overlooked. In 2003, William Basinski was releasing an abundance of music, including further volumes of his Disintegration Loops. This record was released in that year as well, and listening to it now on this vinyl reissue, it feels like a natural successor to his best-known work.

title: Край (Krai)
label: New Amsterdam
description: A composer and singer/songwriter who joined Dirty Projectors for the tour behind 2012's Swing Lo Magellan, Bell moved to Alaska from the Soviet Union when she was younger. Край (Krai) is a dizzy collision of her past and her present, occupying a middle ground between Russian folk song, chamber music, and avant-garde rock music.

title: Shriek
label: Merge
description: On the Baltimore/Portland duo Wye Oak’s fourth album, Shriek, Jenn Wasner replaces her guitar with bass and drummer Andy Stack adds synthesizers to his plate. Wasner's voice also takes up more space on the record; she sings more confidently, and with a broader range.

title: Everyday Robots
label: Parlophone
description: Blur frontman Damon Albarn's last 15 years have included film soundtracks, operas, and collaborative projects including Gorillaz and The Good, the Bad, & the Queen. Everyday Robots is his first proper song-based solo album.

title: Love Apparatus
label: Nomadic
description: On R&B singer Jesse Boykins III's second solo album Love Apparatus, Boykins teams up with Machinedrum, a polyglot electronic producer. On the album, Boykins emphasizes his willingness to further break down whatever barriers may still exist between R&B and the rest of music.

title: Alien
label: Alleviated
description: Chicago producer Larry Heard set the template for house, techno, deep house, and more for generations of electronic music producers. Slowly, portions of his back catalog are finally getting reissued such as Alien, Heard’s third full-length under his own name, originally released in 1996.

title: Young Thugga Mane La Flare
label: self-released
description: Young Thugga Mane La Flare was recorded last summer before Gucci Mane went off to jail yet again. The tape exploits the contrast between the two rappers' contrasting styles: Thug deploys every trick in his arsenal—squawking ad-libs, sung hooks, a multitude of vocal inflections—while Gucci Mane makes a more grounded foil.

title: Hang On to Each Other EP
artist: Thee Silver Mt. Zion Memorial Orchestra
label: Constellation
description: The original version of Thee Silver Mt. Zion's “Hang On to Each Other” from 2005’s Horses in the Sky was recorded around a campfire: It’s mostly a vocal piece, aside from the rasping harmonium planted firmly in the distance. These two new versions of the track are about as close as this band will presumably ever come to producing club bangers.

title: Catalog
label: 4AD
description: This week, the reunited Pixies released their first new album in 23 years. Titled Indie Cindy, the record collects material from three EPs released over the past few months, two of which we've already reviewed. In the interest of avoiding redundancy, we chose to do something a little different...

title: Doss EP
label: Acéphale
description: This recent Acéphale signee steps out with a debut EP of electro-pop that touches on several strands of 1990s dance music. Nods to drum'n'bass and the blissed-out Lite-Brite melodicism of trance music can be heard, but here they're removed from their big-room origins and retrofitted for a more intimate setting.

title: Nordraum
label: Negative Existence
description: We haven’t heard from Old Wainds since 2008, but the Murmansk-based black metal trio remains one of Russia’s greatest musical exports. Nordraum, their fourth album, is genuinely catchy and surprisingly listenable. It’s also their first collection to feature songs sung in English.

title: Who Would Ever Want Anything So Broken? EP
label: Dead Broke
description: Beach Slang is a Philadelphia trio featuring Weston's James Snyder, Ex-Friends drummer JP Flexner, and NONA bassist Ed McNulty. Considering their pop-punk pedigree, you wouldn't be wrong to go into this four song EP expecting a little sunshine, but they've got something stormier to offer.

title: Flemish Altruism / Inindependence
label: Thrill Jockey
description: A Minor Forest’s 1996 debut, Flemish Altruism, and other studio effort, 1998’s Inindependence, were reissued for Record Store Day. Groping for a new vocabulary from the fragments laying around after post-rock’s early-90s Big Bang, the San Francisco band came close to inventing post-post-rock, where the subgenre’s self-seriousness was wrestled with until it laughed, gasped, and collapsed.

title: Drop
label: Castle Face
description: Less than five months after frontman John Dwyer told an audience at San Francisco’s Great American Music Hall that they wouldn’t be seeing the band in action for a while, Thee Oh Sees have reemerged with their eighth full-length record in six years. Drop turns out to be the next logical step in the progression undertaken on 2013’s Floating Coffin and 2012’s Putrifiers II.

title: Boring Ecstasy: The Bedroom Pop of Orchid Tapes
label: Orchid Tapes
description: Brooklyn-based label Orchid Tapes was founded in 2010 by Warren Hildebrand, who's also behind the dreamy Foxes in Fiction project. Boring Ecstasy: The Bedroom Pop of Orchid Tapes serves as a strong introduction to this tight-knit community, and highlights what makes it stand out during a time when anyone with Internet access can conceivably start a label.

title: Weird Drift
label: Planet Mu
description: Half the fun of listening to Heterotic’s Weird Drift is trying to pin down exactly what kind of record it is. On their second album together, Planet Mu founder Mike Paradinas (aka µ-Ziq) and his wife Lara Rix-Martin flirt with a dozen or more styles and subgenres without settling on any particular one for very long.

title: Ashes to Ashes
label: Tankcrimes
description: In 1987, Long Beach's Final Conflict released their pulverizing debut album, Ashes to Ashes, a venom-soaked takedown of the Reagan years, as well as one of the decade's best crossover releases. The set has been reissued in remastered form and packaged with some demos from 1985.

title: P.T.S.D. (Post Traumatic Stress Disorder)
label: W.A.R. Media
description: In 1991 Pharoahe Monch emerged as half of Organized Konfusion, dropping complex multisyllabic rhymes about nebulous geopolitical threats: He is who people are talking about when they talk about thoughtful MCs whose rhymes go over audiences' heads. His newest effort finds him creating some of the more emotionally incisive and grounded music of his career.

title: Journey On: Collected Singles
label: Secretly Canadian
description: Journey On: Collected Singles gathers nine of the late Jason Molina’s first 7-inch singles, including his sides of splits with Oneida, Scout Niblett, and Glen Hansard. The vinyl comes in a canvas box with a CD, a wooden turntable emblazoned with his crowssbow insignia, and a booklet with liner notes by Chicago writer Erin Osmon.

title: Patterns EP
label: Monday
description: The London-based electronic artist and self-taught pianist Tourist, whose real name is William Phillips, has changed quite a bit since surfacing on Myspace in 2010 as Little Loud. The Patterns EP, his first release for Disclosure’s Method label, features his most ambitious material to date.

title: Death III
label: Drag City
description: The selling of the Detroit trio Death as a proto-punk band helped the long-lost group catch the attention of modern listeners, but with their third archival release, it’s become clear that they had much more than spit and snarl up their sleeves.

title: Loom
label: Kanine
description: At first listen, Loom plays like an appropriately wistful dream pop cousin to Young Marble Giants or the Marine Girls, or perhaps something resembling Camera Obscura’s awkward stepsister. But underneath all the jingle-jangling guitars and twee musical meanderings, Fear of Men are quietly seething.

title: The Air Is on Fire
label: Sacred Bones
description: The Air Is on Fire played on two floors of a Paris gallery during a 2007 exhibition of David Lynch’s visual art. Lynch and sound editor Dean Hurley have called the 41-minute piece an “interactive soundscape,” and it has the sequential, impressionistic effect of film.

title: Honest
label: Epic
description: After a protracted streak of hijacking Top 40 smashes like “U.O.E.N.O.” and “Bugatti”, spitballing weirdness out on mixtapes, and farming his more saccharine ideas out to huge pop stars, Atlanta's Future returns with Honest.

title: The Way & The Color
label: Carpark
description: Teeny Lieberson’s voice is chameleonic and firmly in command, capable of twisting into a demanding growl or ringing out like the horns that punctuate her band’s newest album. Backed by her sisters Lizzie and Katherine and bassist Boshra AlSaadi, it’s the fault line on top of which TEEN’s art rock dance party is built.

title: Oblation
label: Season of Mist
description: The Miami sludge-pop band Floor's first album in 10 years comes after vocalist and guitarist Steve Brooks’ success with Torche. Featuring the same lineup that recorded 2002’s self-titled debut, Oblation is more dynamic than its predecessor, and Kurt Ballou’s production gives it the kind of depth that Floor previously lacked on tape.

title: Word O.K.
label: self-released
description: Kool A.D. is a rapper whose best lines are often other rappers' best lines, repurposed, or nonsense that sticks in your head because its fun to say. His new record, Word O.K., is an album of post-modern rap, a self-conscious, fourth-wall-breaking word collage that parodies hip-hop’s grand narratives even as it gleefully fulfills them.

title: Space Project
label: Lefse
description: Space Project is a Record Store Day compilation that takes recordings made by Voyager I and II in the 1970s of “electromagnetic radiation fluctuations in the magnetosphere of the planets, moons, and large asteroids.” These have been handed over to Youth Lagoon, Jason Pierce, Beach House, Mutual Benefit, the Antlers, and Jesu, among others to construct music around.

title: The Long Goodbye: LCD Soundsystem Live at Madison Square Garden
label: Parlophone
description: This 5xLP set documents LCD Soundsystem's final show. It's a largely unedited document of everything this band had to offer: the laughs, the tears, the disco, the rock, the cowbell, the deep cuts—a set for completists, by completists.

title: Free To Eat
label: Epitaph
description: Plague Vendor’s brand of punk rock is Californian, and their debut Free To Eat shows a lot of civic pride, even if their music is handy for joyously loathing wherever you happen to be.

title: Yahoo or the Highway
label: Donky Pitch
description: Scottish producer Tom Banks, aka Lockah, is one of the most promising acts on Brighton's Donky Pitch label. His debut is digital music: forged by modern technology, it reflects the omnivorousness and immediacy of spending time online.

title: Z
label: Top Dawg
description: SZA is TDE's newest artist, the first woman and R&B singer to sign to the label. Her debut album Z plays out like a fractured memory you struggle to piece together fully: there are shards of clarity, but only that.

title: Live at Le Poisson Rouge
label: Northern Spy
description: In September 2013, Jason Pierce performed an improv set with John Colpitts, aka Oneida's Kid Millions and a more recent member of Spiritualized, at Le Poisson Rouge in New York. This limited-edition Record Store Day release documents that show, which bridged the pair’s dueling fondness for minimalism and chaos.

title: Any Other City
label: Rough Trade
description: Life Without Buildings, a mathy art-rock band from Glasgow fronted by one-of-a-kind vocalist Sue Tompkins, only issued one studio album, 2001's long out-of-print Any Other City. This reissue affirms that no one since has sounded quite like them, and to even try would miss the point.

title: Box Set
label: Captured Tracks
description: Nebraska post-punks For Against were early adopters of the UK-centric sub-genre in the late 1980s. Now, Captured Tracks has reissued the band's first three albums; this box set doesn't represent the full sweep of their career by any means, but the overview of the original lineup's work clarifies why the band inspired passion in their listeners.

title: Dizzy Polizzy / Purling Hiss
label: Drag City
description: On last year's Water on Mars, Purling Hiss cleared most of the murk that helped define some of Mike Polizze's earlier solo recordings. These two reissues suggest that Polizze's murkier early material was when he was writing some of the most exciting and affecting songs of his life.

title: Ghetto Cuisine
label: Fool's Gold
description: It's not always easy for musicians to hop between genres while still being taken seriously, so credit is due to Wavves' Nathan Williams, who has made four instrumental mixtapes with his brother Kynan as Sweet Valley without arousing ire. Veteran Fillmore rapper DaVinci clearly hears something in Sweet Valley's music that transcends novelty status, as he's collaborated with them on their latest mixtape, Ghetto Cuisine*.*

title: Under the Skin OST
label: Milan
description: The character Scarlett Johansson plays in Under The Skin is a blank-eyed cipher, a predator without apparent motivation. There is no horror more visceral than the horror of the impersonal, so it makes sense that Mica Levi, who composed the film's score, would turn to György Ligeti's masterful sense of elemental horror. The score has the feel of a thought process, albeit one conducted by a being you have no genetic relation to.

title: Quack
label: Fool's Gold
description: After a few years and a few big singles, A-Trak and Armand Van Helden's wacky dance project has its first full-length. It's crammed with jokes, skits, and quite a few memorable grooves, operating at one intense speed that never lets up.

title: Half-Eaten Guitar
label: P.W. Elverum & Sun
description: Wyrd Visions is one Toronto man, Colin Bergh, making imagined Nordic music that intentionally has an ancient, dredged-up feel, as if Bergh simply transcribed what Druids hummed to themselves to warm up their caves. Phil Elverum's in-house label, P.W. Elverum & Sun, has taken to re-releasing it, dubbing it a "long-lost artifact".

title: Ineffable
label: Local Action
description: Over the past several years, DJ Q has leaped into the void created by the undefined narrative of the UK’s black inner-urban dance scene to claim the territory as his own. His debut album, Ineffable, is a collection of the former star of North England’s bassline scene’s productions that attempts to capture the broader canvasses he typically works with.

title: Make My Head Sing...
label: ATO
description: The Ohio singer/songwriter's new album is her first without Dan Auerbach at the helm, but it’s the album that best captures the minimalist rock ethos of the Black Keys. The record represents a careful subtraction of instruments and elements until only the basics remain: voice and guitar, drums and bass.

title: So It Goes
label: XL
description: At a time when so many young, emerging New York City rappers are eagerly presenting themselves as a sum of their classic New York rap influences, Ratking have generated attention by trying to represent something different. Ratking's palette is restless, chaotic, and cluttered, and So It Goes sounds like it exists in its own world.

title: Spiderland
label: Touch and Go
description: Slint's landmark second album has been reissued in a box set that includes outtakes, live cuts, and a feature-length documentary by Lance Bangs. The record's greatest legacy might be the boundless inspiration it perpetually provides for all the bands that have yet to emerge from the basement.

title: World of Joy
label: Rough Trade
description: Howler's second album is filled with no-frills rock'n'roll about cheap cigs, cheaper gin, mornings in bed, and afternoons on the couch. But there’s enough tenderness in the balladry here to suggest some genuine sincerity behind the smokescreen of sarcasm.

title: Sound Houses
label: Ecstatic
description: The career of Daphne Oram, a pioneer in electronic composition who worked at the hallowed BBC Radiophonic Workshop in its heyday, remains tangled up in tiny mysteries. Sound Houses, commissioned by Oram’s former employers at the BBC, takes elements of her extensive sound library and throws a frame around them with the involvement of Alessio Natalizia and Sam Willis, who make thoughtful electronic pieces as the Kompakt-signed Walls.

title: Built on Glass
label: Downtown
description: Since his cover of "No Diggity" and 2012's Thinking In Textures, Chet Faker has been the Australian poster boy for the nebulous intersection of R&B and soul-influenced electronic music. This is his first full-length.

title: Yeah Yeah Yeah Yeah
label: Bikini Kill
description: Yeah Yeah Yeah Yeah was originally released in 1993 as part of a split LP with Huggy Bear, and it's now been reissued on the Bikini Kill label with previously unreleased bonus tracks. It's another defining punk document from a band that never lost its relevance.

title: Do to the Beast
label: Sub Pop
description: On Do to the Beast, the Afghan Whigs’ first album in 16 years, Greg Dulli seems less interested in rehashing the raw rock-quartet attack the Whigs mastered in the 1990s than he is in building on it. Do to the Beast may not always sound like an Afghan Whigs album, but it operates like one, scavenging the darker corners of pop history to create something personal, vital, and urgent.

title: Unholy Congregation of Hypocritical Ambivalence
label: Profound Lore
description: Australia has a rich tradition of producing some of the most unfettered, uncontrollable metal. Impetuous Ritual, whose guitarists Ignis Fatuus and Omenous Fugue are also in Portal, carry on Australia's reputation for madness with their second album, Unholy Congregation of Hypocritical Ambivalence, which blurs the ever-thinning lines between death metal and noise.

title: Ghetto Ghouls
label: Monofonus
description: Austin, Texas punks Ghetto Ghouls have been making music together since they were 14, and after a decade they're finally putting out their debut LP. The band's received several comparisons to their hometown hardcore forebears, but the Ghouls do more than ride the coattails of SST and Touch and Go's back catalogs.

title: Canyons Cars and Crows
label: Shrimper
description: Henry Barnes initially became known as a member of legendary noise-crust band Man is the Bastard, but has been releasing cracked, rustic art-folk as Amps of Christ for close to two decades. Canyons Cars and Crows, his first full-length since 2006, is both sweeter and messier than his past work.

title: The Both
label: Superego
description: At the tops of their respective games, Aimee Mann and Ted Leo provide such a study in contrasts that a partnership between the two is as intriguing as it is unlikely. The duo's joined forces under the un-Googleable name the Both, and you’d expect that they’d each bring the other out of their respective comfort zones on their debut album.

title: With Light and With Love
label: Woodsist
description: When Woods released 2012’s Bend Beyond, they’d released five proper LPs in as many years, all just about equally good. The result of a relatively lengthy two-year process, their new album With Light and With Love might not be a bold reinvention, but there's an unmistakable focus and determination that can serve as a proper substitute for overt, bar-raising ambition.

title: Melana Chasmata
label: Century Media
description: Triptykon's first album, Eparistera Daimones, was fueled by the anger withinguitarist, vocalist, and primary songwriter Thomas Gabriel Fischer over the tumultuous breakup of Celtic Frost, the pioneering metal group he was long associated with. Melana Chasmata is the follow up to Eparistera Daimones, and while it retains much of the strength of its predecessor, it doesn't quite feel like the triumph Triptykon's debut did.

title: Lithium Burn
label: Park the Van
description: Deleted Scenes are part of a lineage of wistful, guitars-n-yelps indie rock bands that were never fashionable even when they were novel. Their new album is an honest account of what happens when years of small, short-term decisions put you in a place where you really don’t want to be and it’s unclear how you’re going to get out of it.

title: Silent Ascent
label: Infiné
description: A decade into their career, Barcelona duo Fabrizio Rizzin and Pere Solé have hit on a new sound that suits them, one that mixes dubby noctural ambience with the ruddy dance music textures of John Talabot.

title: Old Fears
label: Memphis Industries
description: David Brewis of Field Music returns with a solo album that pays homage to the jittery funk and new wave of his 1980s youth.  Old Fears brings you closer to the elusive Brewis by clearing away the clutter around him, leaving him singing about young anxiety and young love against mannered proto-funk.

title: Broken Ankles EP
label: self-released
description: This unlikely pairing turns out to be Freeway's best solo project in at least four years. And Girl Talk's production is legit: he has the sound and feel of early Roc-A-Fella releases internalized, and he spits it out convincingly.

title: Tweens
label: Frenchkiss
description: Cincinnati "trash pop" outfit Tweens recently opened for the Breeders on that band's current tour, and on their self-titled debut they take cues from Be Your Own Pet and the Donnas while focusing directly on boys who fuck up because they don’t know any better.

title: Seer
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Jonathan Sielaff and Matt Carlson of Golden Retriever look toward the cosmic and the karmic, favoring set-it-and-forget-it synth jams that seem ripped from 1970s Germany; they’re scientific and mechanical in their construction, but they still imbue their work with emotion.

title: Spiritual
label: Dark Entries
description: Cute Heels—aka producer Victor Lenis—grew up in Bogota's punk scene and that ethos bleeds into his new release, Spiritual. That influence rings loudest in Spiritual's strictly defined palette of vintage synthesizer and drum machine sounds.

title: Convertibles
label: Federal Prism
description: Cool Kids member Chuck Inglish's first solo album, Convertibles, was co-produced by Incubus guitarist Mike Einziger, and features Action Bronson, Chance the Rapper, Chromeo, and Mac Miller, among others.

title: The Future's Void
label: Matador
description: Erika Anderson's second full-length as EMA finds her working in a loosely conceptual zone, with songs about surveillance and the difficulties of navigating plugged-in digital culture. It's a risky and uneven album with its share of brilliant moments.

title: Ryonen
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Man Forever—Oneida drummer Kid Millions—teams with So Percussion on this two-song, 30 minute collection. There’s clarity throughout, even when the drums overlap and the rhythms blur, as well as a precision that gives a sense of purpose to every move.

title: Tremors
label: 4AD
description: The Vienna-based, London-born producer SOHN is one of the more high profile examples of artists who've run with the “indie” R&B of James Blake and the Weeknd's House of Balloons. His debut LP Tremors is coded for everything you could learn about this sort of music*.*

title: Dances in Dreams of the Known Unknown
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Lungfish vocalist Daniel Higgs has served as post-hardcore’s devotional core in secret and for so long that many don’t even realize it. He's returned to more rocking territory as a frequent guest vocalist for the Swedish group the Skull Defekts, and his third album with the band has a lighter, more porous touch than their previous collaborations.

title: Music For Robots
label: Warp
description: Squarepusher's Tom Jenkinson received an invite to develop music for a group of music-playing robots collectively named Z-Machines. The resulting EP sounds like he schooled a group of robots in his familiar musical motifs, dragging them down with him into the mix of jazz fusion and electronics he’s been peddling for the past 20 years.

title: The Infamous / The Infamous Mobb Deep
label: self-released
description: Havoc and Prodigy have reissued their classic album The Infamous via a PledgeMusic-funded project. In addition to the original album, they are including a disc of rare and unreleased tracks from the sessions along with a full new album, confusingly, called The Infamous Mobb Deep.

title: Exits
label: Black Acre
description: The debut LP from Loops Haunt—aka Scottish producer Scott Douglas Gordan—is built from a small ensemble of tense, pickled sounds that circle each other warily.

title: The Mother of Virtues
label: Relapse
description: The N.Y. technical death metal band Pyrrhon play most everything but straightforward death or doom, hardcore or noise rock on their excellent second album, The Mother of Virtues. Instead, they push those elements together to craft complicated, personal tantrums that lash at the bounds of strict genre acceptability.

title: Oh, Common Life
label: Triple Crown
description: The Detroit quintet's third LP is pop-punk for the same reasons that determine most genre affiliations—pedigree and presentation. There are enormous instant-singalong melodies here that could potentially trigger gag reflexes, but they unify a record of expansive range and clever writing. Fireworks have made an exceedingly catchy record that candidly and intelligently grapples with struggles of adulthood.

title: Wasted Years
label: Vice
description: When they emerged, OFF! were full of life, boiling hardcore down to its most essential elements. Their latest album, Wasted Years, adds another 16 tracks to the band's catalog; it's their longest album at 23 minutes, and yet it still sounds like it could've used some careful editing.

title: Enter the Slasher House
label: Domino
description: To date, Dave "Avey Tare" Portner’s projects outside of Animal Collective have leaned toward the intensely introspective. His new band, Avey Tare's Slasher Flicks, resemble Animal Collective in stripped-down, garage-band, power-trio formation: not quite as densely textured and sonically adventurous, but more than capable of generating the same sense of euphoric abandon.

title: Here Be Monsters
label: In De Goot
description: Jon Langford's a Wales native who made his first mark in the late 1970s with the eminently British post-punk of the Mekons, but he's lived in America for decades and has been paying homage to American roots music even longer. Here Be Monsters is one of Langford’s least focused albums in recent memory, but it also ends up as one of his richest.

title: Visibility Is a Trap
label: Blackest Ever Black
description: While the new EP from Dalhous—the Edinburgh electronic duo of Alex Ander and Marc Dall—hosts genuinely blissful passages, it’s mostly just unsettling in a way that’s difficult to pin down.

title: Young & Sick
label: Harvest
description: Young & Sick is the musical project of Nick Van Hofwegen, a Dutch artist who's designed album covers for Foster the People, Maroon 5, and Robin Thicke. As a visual artist, Van Hofwegen's style is whimsical and fun; musically, his debut LP heads in a similarly upbeat direction, fusing soft rock, smooth R&B, and the occasional idiosyncratic flourish.

title: Under Color of Official Right
label: Hardly Art
description: On their debut album No Passion All Technique, Detroit's Protomartyr excelled at crafting a post-punk onslaught that was thrillingly breakneck and oppressive, showcasing a new band capable of stomping, shredding, and obliterating. On their follow-up, they've cleaned up their sound a bit and sanded down a few of their rough edges without becoming tepid or tame.

title: It's Album Time
label: Olsen
description: It's Album Time is, as advertised, disco producer Todd Terje's first full-length album, and its title sets the tone: casual, confident, and unburdened by the imagined need for significance that scares so many good dance producers into losing their cool when given a bigger platform. Terje is a careful artist that's fluent in history, an expert with texture, and possessing a grasp on composition more akin to a 1960s film composer than a contemporary dance producer.

title: Remember Me
label: Republic
description: Sage the Gemini of the Bay Area’s Heartbreak Gang collective has refined a sound that draws influence from frenetic dance-informed NorCal hyphy music and L.A. jerk music, with hints of the sleek “crunk&B” of Jazze Pha and Ciara. His chart-placing instructional dance floor drills are presently his livelihood, so his debut album Remember Me arrives with a mission: keep listeners on their feet, but show some range.

title: Baby
label: Dead Oceans
description: White Hinterland's latest finds Casey Dienel experimenting with more jagged percussion and orchestral flourishes, notably horns.  But for all the sonic change-ups, her idiosyncratic voice remains the music’s signature.

title: E S T A R A
label: Brainfeeder
description: Teebs' 2010 debut Ardour had a way of flooding your ears with lush sonic environments. On his new E S T A R A, he aims for a more concise approach.

title: Doom Abuse
label: SQE
description: The Faint released their debut album Sine Sierra nearly twenty years ago, and if that makes you feel old, imagine how they must’ve felt when they went on hiatus following 2008’s Fasciination. Their first album since reuniting, Doom Abuse, isn’t so much an argument for the Faint’s continued relevancy as it is for the potency of their real-time nostalgia.

title: Smell the D.A.I.S.Y.
label: self-released
description: De La Soul's work with J Dilla helped define their transition from the Prince Paul-produced lightheartedness of their first three albums. This new mixtape featuring unreleased Dilla beats and reworked lyrics from De La Soul's catalog provides an alternate-history look into a meaningful partnership.

title: Nux Vomica
label: Relapse
description: Portland's Nux Vomica swirl together crust, melodic death metal, black metal, metallic hardcore, doom, noise, and ambient music into a cohesive, engaging whole. On their self-titled third album, and Relapse debut, they’ve hit upon an ideal balance of beauty and brutality.

title: Range of Light
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Sean Carey's new album is the first he recorded in Bon Iver bandmate Justin Vernon's April Base studio in Fall Creek, Wis. The warmth, reverb, and dusty textures here form something much larger than S. Carey has ever done before, but his real talent lies in making these songs seem tiny set against the world around him.

title: Drop the Vowels
label: Modern Love
description: Millie & Andrea is the project of Andy Stott and Demdike Stare's Miles Whittaker. On their debut LP, the duo offer a mix of hollow dub techno, into-the-red noise, and breakbeats that hiss and spit with static, but the extra flourishes are what prove most surprising.

title: I Shall Die Here
label: Rvng Intl.
description: Portland-based metal outfit the Body take doom metal as their core template and shred it to pieces until it's completely unrecognizable. On their new I Shall Die Here, the Haxan Cloak's Bobby Krlic comes on board as producer, helping drummer Lee Buford and guitarist/singer Chip King rip the guts out of their sound to achieve maximal brutality.

title: Sisyphus
label: Asthmatic Kitty
description: The last release from Sufjan Stevens, Son Lux, and Serengeti's Sisyphus project was a scattered lark that featured an abundance of Auto-Tune; for their self-titled debut LP, they've ditched the Auto-Tune and improved on their ability to create fractured-sounding music together—even if the results prove a little frustrating.

title: NOW + 4EVA
label: Casual Workout
description: Australian indie pop collective Architecture in Helsinki’s new record finds them continuing to embrace simple, radio-friendly sounds, with one foot newly planted in the realm of contemporary synth-pop. NOW + 4EVA rings with genuine enthusiasm.

title: Yearling
label: Morr
description: On his own, Thomas Meluch records cloudy electro-acoustic songs as Benoît Pioulard that sound hand-cobbled, while Rafael Anton Irisarri drapes brooding ostinatos with dusky delay and reverb. Their second album as Orcas retains the debut's vast scale, glacial pace, and visual splendor, while bringing a human presence closer to the surface.

title: Crystal Cult 2080
label: Crème
description: Danny Wolfers is the rare producer whose personal mythology enriches his music instead of distracting from it. His latest album as Legowelt, Crystal Cult 2080, isn't weirder than Wolfers' previous albums—it's just better at being weird.

title: Inventions
label: Temporary Residence
description: Inventions, a new project by Matthew Cooper—the producer behind the multifaceted ambient project Eluvium—and Explosions in the Sky guitarist Mark T. Smith, sounds much like you'd expect. But the familiarity works in this uncommonly beautiful record’s favor.

title: Memoryhouse
description: The new reissue of German-born composer Max Richter's Memoryhouse serves as a jolting reminder of just how much classical music has broken outside of its shell and into other realms during the last decade.

title: Amusements
label: Goner
description: Geelong, Australia's Ausmuteants aren't making politically militant or socially conscious songs—they're delinquents indulging in low-hanging fruit, writing about stepping in shit and pissing your pants. Their new record, Amusements, offers 12 tracks of ripping, captivating, fun synth-punk.

title: Cope
label: Loma Vista
description: After the simultaneous crescendo and crash of 2011’s Simple Math, Manchester Orchestra's fourth album is 11 bullshit-free rock songs about getting past the bullshit in your life. They sound like Band of Horses at their major-label crossroads, with none of that band's sweep and expanse.

title: Through Force of Will
label: Not Not Fun
description: Luke Wyatt, the Brooklyn-based Va. transplant behind Torn Hawk, releases an astonishing amount of music, some of it beat-oriented, some of it close to the VHS nostalgia feel of chillwave, much of it accompanied by collaged YouTube clips. On his newest effort, things don't lead where you expect them to on first glance.

title: Angel
label: Fat Possum
description: Angel, the third album by Austin’s Pure X, is lackadaisical in its tempos and moods, coming on at an almost laughably leisurely pace. But while there’s a lot of emphasis on mood and texture, they never get in the way of the songwriting, which is consistent and generous with its hooks.

title: Salad Days
label: Captured Tracks
description: Mac DeMarco's second full-length isn’t a departure from its predecessor so much as a richer, increasingly assured refinement. At its best, it's an outstanding crystallization of his gifts, the real-talk advice of Jonathan Richman with a far more accessible poetic dreaminess.

title: Important Picnic
label: MIE
description: The longtime Long Beach noise-rock trawlers Gang Wizard's newest album, Important Picnic, might be the best of their 40 or so releases. On previous efforts, their boundlessness has sometimes drifted into tedium, but there's no downtime on this pulse-quickening collection.

title: Physical World
label: Lovemonk
description: Singer/songwriter Bart Davenport's catalog is a series of nested quotations brilliantly lifted and folded into power-pop confections that he's mastered. His latest album sounds like a world of record sleeves, thumbed through masterfully.

title: Real People EP
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Small Black's laid-back vibe often masks a certain sonic perfectionism. Real People, their new five-song EP, was written and recorded quickly in an attempt to smuggle a little more of the sweaty throb of their recent live shows into the studio.

title: Miles at the Fillmore - Miles Davis 1970: The Bootleg Series Vol. 3
label: Columbia
description: Miles at the Fillmore, the latest entry in Columbia’s revelatory bootleg series collecting unreleased Miles Davis live material, finds the trumpeter departing one musical world and entering a new one. Excerpts from these four nights were released on the 1970 Miles Davis at the Fillmore 2xLP.

title: Here and Nowhere Else
label: Carpark
description: Cloud Nothings' latest album moves in one direction and at a breakneck pace. Dylan Baldi is simply unwilling or unable to stop writing hook-filled songs, rendering Here and Nowhere Else even more tense and thrillingly conflicted than its predecessor. The band continues to make powerfully utilitarian music for people who don’t seek out this type of music just to be told what to think.

title: II: Void Worship
label: Metal Blade
description: The young Rhode Island doom revivalists Pilgrim's second album is more relentless and loaded than its predecessor, even though the duo often forgoes an additional layer of vocals. But their abiding sense of doom remains intact, and they now seem capable of writing around the records from which they learned.

title: riZe vadZimu riZe
label: Brick Lane
description: Each project that's spun off from Shabazz Palaces has resembled a distinct piece of art, but when considered together, they represent a group of musicians with a connected set of sensibilities. Chimurenga Renaissance is the latest, helmed by Tendai (“Baba”) Maraire and featuring a crew of guests, including SP bandmate Palaceer Lazaro.

title: Crush
label: YG
description: The brash all-female Korean pop supergroup 2NE1's new album, Crush, bottles up contemporary trends as well as their usual EDM/reggae/hip-hop/R&B stylemash. But it represents a sleeker, more refined vision for the group.

title: Fenris District EP
label: Ninja Tune
description: The latest EP from Travis Stewart's project finds Machinedrum at a crossroads. Here he takes a stab at the buoyant trap-derived sound popularized by TNGHT, and adds remixes from Rustie and Adrian Sherwood.

title: Teeth Dreams
label: Razor & Tie
description: After four good-to-fantastic records, the Hold Steady returned in 2010 with Heaven Is Whenever, a too-sleek, cliche-mottled shrug of a record. From its opening line on, the band's sixth album, Teeth Dreams, tries to position itself as a return to form.

title: Piedmont Apocrypha
label: Three Lobed
description: The experimental blackened doom/Americana outfit Horseback's newest album, Piedmont Apocrypha, compacts the North Carolina group's meandering trajectory into a five-song narrative that's inclusive, intriguing, and creepy.

title: Dylan's Gospel
label: Light in the Attic
description: Over two days in July, 1969, a group recruited by Lou Adler from the L.A. backup-singer circuit recorded churchified versions of 10 familiar Bob Dylan tunes, and the results are way better than they have a right to be. This remastered reissue features liner notes interviewing Adler and vocalists Merry Clayton and Edna Wright.

title: The Rite of Spring
label: Sony Masterworks
description: Musicians will never stop trying to reimagine Stravinsky's savage, gleaming The Rite of Spring, and now the Bad Plus are stepping up to the plate. The jazz trio won acclaim by twisting hard rock and punk songs into their own language, but the Bad Plus just aren't a match for the full blast of Stravinsky's orchestra.

title: Adventureland
label: Cantaloupe
