description: The Wilco drummer returns with an album of pieces influenced by classical minimalism, including a work writen for the Kronos Quartet. Where his previous albums foregrounded himself as a virtuoso performer, Adventureland is about Kotche as a composer first and foremost.

title: Out Among the Stars
label: Columbia
description: Johnny Cash recorded Out Among the Stars with countrypolitan producer Billy Sherrill in the early 1980s, but the album never saw release at the time. Rescued from the vaults and augmented with new instrumentation, Stars sheds welcome light on a period when Cash kept a low profile.

title: III: Beneath Trident's Tomb
label: Century Media
description: Twilight features metal heavyweights like Leviathan’s Wrest, Krieg’s Neil Jameson, and the Atlas Moth's Stavros Giannopoulos along with newest member Thurston Moore. On III: Beneath Trident's Tomb, the collective scrapes through black metal and sludge, industrial and noise, post-punk and atmospheric interludes.

title: Boy
label: Constellation
description: Carla Bozulich has spent decades navigating the art-rock underground through sheer tenacity and a fierce commitment to her own distinctive musical vision. She proclaims her latest solo album, Boy, as her version of a “pop record,” and it's indeed her most approachable album in a while.

title: Dream.Zone.Achieve
label: R.F.C. Music Group
description: On his new Dream.ZONE.Achieve, Harlem rapper Smoke DZA showcases his strong ear for production while struggling to establish his own voice.

title: Panasonic EP
label: Donky Pitch
description: On last year's Nonfiction, James Hinton plumbed deep dynamics in the form of bright, gently jostling terrain. His new EP as the Range exemplifies the electronic producer’s knack for texturing glossy tones with busy, off-kilter rhythms.

title: My Krazy Life
label: Def Jam
description: Compton rapper YG and producer DJ Mustard have forged the type of symbiotic producer-rapper bond that's scarcely been seen on a mainstream field of play since Drake and Noah "40" Shebib. On YG's major-label debut, Mustard’s production and YG’s songwriting have both gone deliciously widescreen.

title: Winter & the Wolves
label: Rhymesayers
description: Seattle rapper Grieves’ fourth album Winter & the Wolves is “about the instinctual fight for survival.” That struggle mostly makes itself known through reflective songs about the rapper’s life, including a batch concerned with the events of childhood and a now-defunct relationship.

title: Dissed and Dismissed
label: Slumberland
description: We’re used to the kind of power-pop that San Franicsco songwriter Tony Molina makes by abiding certain rules and forms, but the songs on Dissed and Dismissed slyly toy with expectations.

title: Two
label: Polyvinyl
description: Unlike almost anything that Tim Kinsella has been involved with, Owls' first LP in nearly 13 years, Two, doesn’t need a preemptive warning about its “challenging” nature. Kinsella's pretty much stopped caring about public perception, which has resulted in some of his most honest and direct music.

title: Lavender Country
label: Paradise of Bachelors
description: Patrick Haggerty was raised on a dairy farm outside Seattle before the twin shocks of the Stonewall riots and his ejection from the Peace Corps radicalized him. In 1973 he released Lavender Country, widely regarded as the first country record by an openly gay person, in an edition of 1,000. Now that the label Paradise of Bachelors is reissuing the collection, the richness of Haggerty's achievement can be appreciated again.

title: Singles
label: 4AD
description: Thanks to a performance on "Late Show With David Letterman" that went viral, Future Islands are now ready for their close-up. Their fourth album does not disappoint. This is pop music distilled, something Future Islands have been working at since their earliest lo-fi electro-punk records.

title: Louder Space
label: 12XU
description: In just three years, Lamont “Bim” Thomas, who's played drums in V-3, Bassholes, This Moment in Black History, Puffy Aerolas, and others, has cranked out three albums plus EPs and singles as Obnox, pouring his energies into burning-red noise-punk blasts. His newest, the blazing Louder Space, is the first he recorded in a studio.

title: IN.RAK.DUST
label: UNO
description: Gang Gang Dance co-founder Tim DeWit's first full-length as Dutch E Germ is his most substantial artistic statement since co-producing GGD's landmark 2008 album Saint Dymphna. Following contributions to a soundtrack for a Baltimore biker documentary and his appearance on Yeezus, IN.RAK.DUST sees him creating a new kind of dub.

title: Oksastus
label: Kvitnu
description: Pan Sonic, the Finnish noise duo who split in 2010, recorded this meticulous live effort in 2009 in Kyiv in the Ukraine. It's impossible to frame it without thinking about the impending meltdown of both band and country, cloaking Oksastus in an apocalyptic backdrop.

title: By Any Means
label: Breadwinners Association
description: With his Atlantic debut looming on the horizon and a higher profile than he's ever enjoyed, the Baton Rouge rapper Kevin Gates' newest mixtape is packed with uptempo anthems, chest-pumping bravado, and a 2 Chainz guest spot. The beats here are a little bigger than in the past and have more of a sheen to them.

title: Mess
label: Mute
description: Mess is the first Liars album that could be given a “dance-” hyphenate since their debut; it’s physical, bodymoving music for people who don’t have much interest in proper dance music.

title: Light Divide
label: Thrill Jockey
description: On Light Divide, Barn Owl multi-instrumentalist Jon Porras moves between drones and keyboard melodies, deep beats and microscopic clicks, foreboding bass and comforting silvery drift. The collection refracts and then reorders moody electronic music, creating more of a mirage than a mere collage.

title: Forcefield
label: Mom & Pop
description: Tokyo Police Club frontman David Monks has joked that the Strokes' “Juicebox” and Weezer's “Hash Pipe” were spiritual guides for the band during the creation of Forcefield, the band's first album in four years. It's a pop record, produced like pop and structured to grant instant gratification.

title: St. Carolyn by the Sea / Suite From There Will Be Blood
label: Deutsche Grammophon
description: This handsomely appointed Deutsche Grammophon release of recordings by Bryce Dessner, guitarist for the National, and Jonny Greenwood, guitarist for Radiohead, is a sign of shifting cultural tides regarding orchestral works by rock stars.

title: Waterfall EP
label: Tri Angle
description: The UK producer now best known for contributing to Yeezus returns with an EP that finds his music sounding bigger in every way. This is essentially big-stage EDM, with colossal surges of bass and thick, serrated synth lines.

title: Recess
label: Atlantic
description: Skrillex is a festival-circuit megastar who’s already put an indelible sonic imprint on the early stretch of this decade, but Recess is his first proper album. It's a mix of big-drop dubstep tunes and whatever-works eclecticism, including spots from Chance the Rapper, Diplo, and Michael Angelakos of Passion Pit.

title: Daughter of Everything
label: Merge
description: On their blur of a debut, guitarist John Schmersal (Braniac, Enon, Crooks on Tape) and drummer Christian Beaulieu (Triclops!) mine post-Beatles power-pop with a bounty of jagged, 120-second song shards. Robert Pollard turns up for a guest vocal turn.

title: We Must Rebel/I Hate Myself/Endless Struggle
label: Southern Lord
description: Of all the historic punk and hardcore bands based in Austin in the early 80s—MDC, D.R.I., the Big Boys, the Dicks—Offenders remain the least celebrated. In an effort to rectify this blind spot, 1983’s We Must Rebel, 1985’s Endless Struggle, and the 1984 7” “I Hate Myself”/“Bad Times” have been collected by Southern Lord as a double-LP anthology including beefed-up fidelity. Not that these songs have ever sounded less than staggeringly savage.

title: I Am the Last of All the Field That Fell: A Channel
label: The Spheres
description: For the last three decades, Current 93 have been not so much a band as an ever-evolving collective anchored around the complicated vision of David Tibet. I Am the Last of All the Field That Fell not only re-taps past collaborators Antony Hegarty, James Blackshaw, and Nick Cave, but adds John Zorn and Dutch classical pianist Reinier van Houdt, among others, to the fold.

title: Catch the Throne: The Mixtape
label: Launch Point
description: Catch the Throne, compiled to promote Game of Thrones, drafts the production team from New York’s Launch Point Records to fashion hip hop beats out of the show’s rich orchestral score. It features contributions from Big Boi, Wale, Common, Daddy Yankee, Kilo Kish, and more.

title: Underneath the Rainbow
label: Vice
description: Black Lips are no strangers to A-list producers, having worked with Mark Ronson on Arabia Mountain. Here they team with Patrick Carney of Black Keys for over half the tracks, with decidedly mixed results.

title: Mirrors the Sky
label: Sub Pop
description: On her first full-length, Mirrors in the Sky, London singer-songwriter and producer Lyla Foy’s songs are both lush and low-key, intimate and surprisingly intricate. She layers beats generously but carefully, alternating between buoyant and bittersweet.

title: Vermont
label: Kompakt
description: Vermont is the new synthesizer-based project from German electronic composers Daniel Plessow (Motor City Drum Ensemble) and Marcus Worgull. These careful, patient pieces, a handful featuring Can's Jaki Liebezeit on drums, are focused and luminous.

title: When the Past Arrives
label: Drag City
description: The low-key and frequently wonderful project Woo returns with a new collection. Their music is ambient and gentle as new age music can be, but it’s also densely melodic and playful, sounding like Durutti Column as rendered on ukulele, or Cluster if instead of amassing early synthesizers, they collected clarinets.

title: Suck My Shirt
label: Suicide Squeeze
description: On their new album Suck My Shirt, Atlanta punks the Coathangers manage to have it all. It's well-recorded, well-written, and teeming with both force and emotional depth.

title: Darlings
label: Arts & Crafts
description: In comparison to 2007's Spirit If..., the Broken Social Scene leader's second solo album doesn't feel like the work of a band. Synth-heavy and prone to slow-building torch songs, Darlings turns out to be a fine showcase for Drew's expressive voice and distinctive obsessions.

title: The Drain
label: Profound Lore
description: Psalm Zero is the Brooklyn duo of Andrew Hock (Castevet) and Charlie Looker (Dirty Projectors, Zs, Extra Life). Their debut album, The Drain, offers a mix of metal aggression and industrial wallop, supported in places by Hock’s academic past in free jazz and Looker’s exploration of classical forms.

title: Dental Denial
label: Dull Tools
description: Austin garage rockers Beth Israel—the duo of Zack Claxon and Ramsey Eddins—package strange lyrical musings with stellar hooks on their debut Dental Denial.

title: Awake
label: Ghostly International
description: On Awake, Scott Hansen, the San Francisco-based visual artist who records colorful techno as Tycho, expands his sound. It's the first Tycho album recorded as a three-piece band, and his previous albums now sound like mere dreams of the luminous world he was trying to create.

title: Satellite Flight: The Journey to Mother Moon
label: Universal Republic
description: Cleveland rapper Kid Cudi's new Satellite Flight: The Journey to Mother Moon represents his catalog in miniature: A vast, serene, often-beautiful vista of sounds—and then this guy, standing right in front of them.

title: Lost in the Dream
label: Secretly Canadian
description: If the mesmerizing motorik hum of the War on Drugs' earlier records gave leader Adam Granduciel an outlet to escape his problems, Lost in the Dream is where he pulls a U to survey the emotional wreckage. The result is the band's most lustrous, intricately detailed, and beautifully rendered record to date.

title: Love Is Here To Stay
label: Subliminal Sounds
description: The music Bo Anders Persson made in the late 1960s and early 70s may not have spread wide, but its influence went deep.  Bardo Pond, Acid Mothers Temple, and Sunburned Hand of the Man all owe their smoky trails in part to the paths that Persson’s bands blazed. This set collects some of his early tape-based experiments and ensemble compositions.

title: Jimmy the Burnout
label: Hellfyre Club
description: L.A. rapper Nocando thrives on a heady blend of lyrical intricacy and haymaker punchlines. But on his new Jimmy the Burnout, he reaches for deeper things in between the witty turns of phrase.

title: We Got a Love
label: DFA
description: Marcus Lambkin, the Irish producer who records as Shit Robot, is part of a lineage that runs through James Murphy's DFA empire. His new album draws from house, rave, and disco, and includes guest spots from Luke Jenner from the Rapture and Nancy Whang.

title: Hey EP
label: XL
description: Brooklyn rapper Le1f's new Hey EP—a joint release from XL and Terrible Records—is both an announcement and a confident distillation, the essence of what makes Le1f so captivating, packaged up into something mass consumable and effortlessly fun.

title: Say Yes to Love
label: Captured Tracks
description: Following a searing, four-song demo tape released last year, Perfect Pussy's proper full-length debut Say Yes to Love is an unrelentingly intense experience—23 minutes of five people pushing themselves to their absolute limit.

title: Hammer of the Witch
label: Relapse
description: Most songs by Cleveland hardcore vets Ringworm have the same ingredients: thrashy riffs, breakdowns, and a total absence of pretension. Hammer of the Witch, their sixth album overall and first for Relapse, shows the quintet remaining as consistent as ever.

title: The Unsemble
label: Ipecac
description: *The Unsemble—*the eponymous debut album by a trio comprising Alexander Hacke of Einstürzende Neubauten, Duane Denison of the Jesus Lizard, and drummer Brian Kotzur—is neither industrial nor pigfuck. It’s a refined, even contemplative assemblage of instrumental art-rock with a marked lack of shit getting bashed.

title: Fabric 74
label: Fabric
description: On his new mix Fabric 74, it's clear that ambient techno musician David Moufang—aka Move D—is intent on bringing his own party-starting side to the home-listening audience.

title: The Drive In Theatre
label: Unknown
description: The new mixtape from New Orleans rapper Curren$y successfully channels the atmosphere of his Pilot Talk series, making it the rapper’s strongest project in nearly four years.

title: Joyland
label: Arts & Crafts
description: Canadian coldwaver Trust's second effort Joyland—now a Robert Alfons solo project due to the departure of  Maya Postepski—is a couple notches sleeker than its predecessor.

title: Soft Opening
label: Beating A Dead Horse
description: On their sophomore album Soft Opening, Seattle indie rockers Posse imbue their no-frills, rumpled indie rock with a discernible point of view and more importantly, a personality.

title: The Aquaplano Sessions / Velo Di Maya EP
label: Spectrum Spools
description: For the last decade, Italian electronic maestro Donato “Dozzy” Scaramuzzi’s been a leader of his home country’s unheralded electronic music scene. The Aquaplano Sessions, an EP collaboration with Nuel, and the Velo Di Maya EP showcase the producer moving into darker territory.

title: The Take Off and Landing of Everything
label: Fiction
description: After the morbid nostalgia of 2011’s Build a Rocket Boys!, there’s a softer, rounder, lighter obviousness to Elbow's sixth full-length The Take Off and Landing of Everything.

title: Rat Conspiracy
label: Numero Group
description: The new Unwound box set Rat Conspiracy collects the Seattle punks' 1993 LP F**ake Train and 1994's New Plastic Ideas along with a third album of 7” singles, radio sessions, compilation appearances, and unreleased tracks from the raw, formative years of the band.

title: Piñata
label: Madlib Invazion
description: The appreciation of Madlib and Freddie Gibbs' new collaboration Piñata depends on the range of your hip-hop tastes and your familiarity with both artists' deep cuts. Funk-fusion and soul jazz breaks bubble and blister in the heat and Gibbs states the facts as he sees them.

title: The Parasitic Survival of the Human Race
label: Moribund
description: The Greek metal outfit continues the sonic clean-up that began on 2008’s Death Set the Beginning of My Journey. Here, the group's crusty strain of black metal is leavened with dashes of punk while the longer songs are punctuated by sounds from the 2012 Athens riots.

title: Untitled EP
label: Peoples Potential Unlimited
description: Mysterious L.A. producer Benedek draws on obscure boogie, funk, freestyle, house music, modern soul, and lost R&B to create a strange yet danceable new world of sound on his new Untitled EP.

title: “Second Poem To Karmela" Or Gypsies Are Important / Bob Frank
label: Light in the Attic
description: Guitarist Peter Walker’s second album, “Second Poem to Karmela,” or Gypsies Are Important, and songwriter Bob Frank’s self-titled debut are the first two titles of an exciting new series from the resurrection-prone imprint Light in the Attic.

title: Young Money: Rise of an Empire
label: Young Money Entertainment
description: Five years after We Are Young Money comes another collection from Lil Wayne's imprint. A lot has changed. While YM's Drake and Nicki Minaj make clear how lucky they are to have the label, this weak set shows how lucky Young Money is to still have them.

title: Dean Wareham
label: Double Feature
description: Like last year’s Emancipated Hearts EP, Dean Wareham’s new self-titled full-length, featuring Papercuts' Jason Quever and My Morning Jacket's Jim James, is less Dean & Britta than Dean to Britta. It’s an album that humorously but honestly explores the tensions that arise in any long-term relationship.

title: Glow
label: Astralwerks
description: Four years after the reliable German house producer made waves with "Coma Cat" he returns with his full-length debut. Guests include Nile Rodgers and Jamie Lidell.

title: Heathen
label: Gilead Media
description: Thou have lightened up a bit on their excellent fourth album, their first since 2010’s Summit, without losing their ability to shock and awe. Mixing in clean vocals, acoustic passages, and strings and horns, the 60-plus minute Heathen is the Louisiana sludge/doom band’s most punishing work to date, and yet it's also their most beautiful.

title: Abandoned City
label: City Slang
description: As Hauschka, Volker Bertelmann writes fairly plain piano music that winds up sounding bewilderingly elaborate. On his new Abandoned City, songs have a clumsy grace, eagerly tripping over themselves as they rush between frolicsome and ominous moods.

title: Belomancie
label: Drag City
description: Recently, Sun Araw has been an expanding universe, one that finds Cameron Stallones incorporating various musicians into studio and concert settings. But his newest offering, the 80-minute double album Belomancie, is a solo record showcasing a hypnotic minimalism.

title: Zentropy
label: Double Double Whammy
description: Greta Kline is a 19-year-old who records under the name Frankie Cosmos. Her charming new indie pop album Zentropy touches on love, aging, and the archetypal triumphs and disappointments of young life in a big city.

title: Kindly Bent to Free Us
label: Season of Mist
description: Mixing technical death metal and thundering jazz fusion, the Florida band Cynic's 1993 debut, Focus, still sounds like future music, and their post-reunion LP, 2008’s Traced in Air, thrived on a similarly ambitious mix of power and prowess. But did they really need to make a third record?

title: Axxa/Abraxas
label: Captured Tracks
description: Axxa/Abraxas is a charming album from an artist with an obsessive/compulsive love for writing shambolic, vaguely psych-infused rock songs. Jarvis Taveniere of Woods produces.

title: Doubled Exposure
artist: D. Charles Speer and the Helix
label: Thrill Jockey
description: In the last several years songwriter Dave Charles Shuford has reclaimed his Georgia roots by inhabiting the alter ego of D. Charles Speer, frontman of a band he calls the Helix. His new album, Double Exposure, is a fun, chewy listen.

title: Eagulls
label: Partisan
description: Eagulls are a four-piece band from Leeds who mix dark atmosphere and shoegaze noise. So far, their music has been overshadowed by their off-record antics, but their self-titled debut has its share of memorable post-punk songs.

title: Love Letters
label: Because
description: On Metronomy's new Love Letters, songwriter Joseph Mount arrives with another rearview glance at pop and rock history, aging backwards into a gray space between late psych and early glam.

title: Spectre
label: Mute
description: The Slovenian group Laibach are fundamentally a performance-art project, with a barbed joke they've been repeating for over 30 years: observing how art becomes a tool of totalitarianism, and pushing it as far as it can go in that direction. The title of their new album, Spectre, is an allusion to the opening line of The Communist Manifesto, but it's also a description of the current state of the band.

title: The Drop Beneath
label: Kanine
description: On Virginia indie rockers Eternal Summers' third proper full-length—the PledgeMusic-funded and generally excellent The Drop Beneath—the band takes another assured step forward thanks to production help from Doug Gillard (Guided by Voices, Nada Surf).

title: The Soul of All Natural Things
label: Asthmatic Kitty
description: Linda Perhacs' psychedelic folk album, 1970’s Parallelograms, has persisted over decades, even as she's moved on with her life and copies of it disappeared from print. The followup, arriving 44 years later, was made with several of Perhacs' admirers, including Julia Holter and Nite Jewel's Ramona Gonzalez.

title: No Mythologies to Follow
label: RCA
description: The new album from Copenhagen electronic artist MØ—aka Karen Marie Ørsted—ditches shock-rap for more mature but no less immediate electro-pop exploring the swirling confusion of young adulthood.

title: G I R L
label: Columbia
description: Riding high on the 2013 success of collaborations with Daft Punk and Robin Thicke and with a current #1 single, Pharrell returns with his second solo album. G I R L is an immaculately blended pop smoothie bound for ubiquity.

title: Three Seashells
label: Greedhead
description: On his new pay-what-you-want full-length debut Three Seashells, New York rapper Lakutis is still prone to fits of bizarre leftfield humor. But Three Seashells reigns the focus in a little and unveils a darker, more unhinged version of the artist.

title: Aqonis
label: Day Tripper
description: Eadonmm, the solo electronic project of Osaka’s Shinya Wada, offers a shadowy, captivating debut filled with disorienting moments. Armed with pitched vocal samples and goth-leaning visuals, he establishes a genuinely unsettling mood throughout.

title: Yung Archetype EP
label: Quite Scientific
description: On his five-song EP Yung Archetype, Nigerian-American songwriter Tunde Olaniran's approach most closely resembles the kitchen-sink genre pastiche of M.I.A. or the silly perceptiveness and electronic experimentation of rap acts like Das Racist. The product is a pitch-perfect mashup of pop-leaning underground music.

title: Guilty of Everything
label: Relapse
description: Relapse Records’ recent signee, the Philadelphia band Nothing, are fronted by ex-Horror Show vocalist Dominic Palermo. Their debut*, Guilty of Everything*, might be unusually heavy dream-pop, billowy alt-rock, or blustery shoegaze, but it is definitely not metal.

title: Mastermind
label: Maybach
description: Rick Ross’ sixth studio album Mastermind arrives following a rough year for the Maybach Music empire. The collection shines when guest raps from the likes of Kanye West, Meek Mill, Lil Wayne, and Jay Z light a fire under his ass.

title: Dreams
label: Darup Associates
description: Informed by dance and electronic music, the Copenhagen pop trio WhoMadeWho's fifth album shuffles through genres while maintaining a cohesive sound. The group features drummer Tomas Barfod, whose 2012 album Salton Sea gave him a kind of name recognition that, at least in the States, the band itself has yet to achieve.

title: The Air You Found
label: Translation Loss
description: Empty Flowers retrench the sounds of Slint, Shellac, Girls Against Boys, and Archers of Loaf with a little metal heaviness. This new collection, The Air You Found, offers reworked versions of songs from their two previous LPs by the likes of Justin K Broadrick and members of Tombs, Gorguts, Dysrhythmia, Isis, and Khanate, among others.

title: The Power and the Glory
label: Perc Trax
description: Ali Wells, aka Perc, has been making scraping techno bangers, with little rest or deviation, since 2002. His second album, The Power and the Glory, is a bold, roiling collection that feels looser and more chaotic than the rigid constructs he normally works within.

title: English Oceans
label: ATO
description: English Oceans is the first album since Drive-By Truckers' 2001 breakthrough Southern Rock Opera where the songwriting duties are split solely between Patterson Hood and Mike Cooley. In several aspects, it's a return to form.

title: Warfaring Strangers: Darkscorch Canticles
label: Numero Group
description: Numero Group's Warfaring Strangers: Darkscorch Canticles is a snapshot of mid-1970s American proto-metal, a loose confederation of groups working mostly in obscurity and isolation that drew on Deep Purple, Uriah Heep, and Black Sabbath. What makes these bands so compelling are their idiosyncratic visions of weird America.

title: Shochu Sounds
label: Perfect Touch
description: Japanese producers Obey City and Seiho created the collaborative EP Shochu Sounds for a recent tour. Featuring a pair of tracks from each, it’s a solid introduction to both artists, touching on what makes them such promising producers to watch.

title: Pulsing EP
label: Secretly Canadian
description: While Danish producer Tomas Barfod once delivered a surveying glance at electronic music—floaty vocal electro-pop, playful house, meandering headphone fodder—he sticks to a rigid dichotomy on his new Pulsing. It's sharp, finely sung pop in one hand, and moody instrumental cuts on the other.

title: ESTOILE NAIANT
label: Warp
description: The largely anonymous London producer patten's ESTOILE NAIANT builds a satisfyingly awkward bridge between his inclinations to amble and to stick a fork in his machinery. On these tracks, room to breathe is as important as the restricted spaces of his earlier work.

title: Death After Life
label: Software
description: Chicago producer Ryan McRyhew, aka Thug Entrancer, started out on an IDM pathway but his new Death After Life gravitates toward stripped-down, chromed-out footwork.

title: Tomorrow's Hits
label: Sacred Bones
description: Tomorrow's Hits is the first record the Men put together in a high-end studio, but a year after New Moon, the message is the same: they’re a rock band and the roll continues.

title: Island Intervals
label: Sub Pop
description: The ambitious subject material on Death Vessel's new Island Intervals could easily be mishandled by someone more precious or novel in his dedication to this aesthetic. But singer Joel Thibodeau’s ear for richly pastoral arrangements make him more than a high-voiced novelty.

title: Soul Jazz Presents: Studio One Rocksteady
label: Soul Jazz
description: Soul Jazz's Jamaican rocksteady comp Studio One Rocksteady highlights songs that demonstrate tremendously tight vocal arrangements and exude the ease of a growing music industry.

title: The Perfect Lullaby Vol. 2
label: self-released
description: Electronic duo Nguzunguzu's new world pop-sampling mix, The Perfect Lullaby Vol. 2, finds the duo fitting the exotic pieces together with minimal tweaking, but still hiding the seams expertly.

title: Apocalypse Soon EP
label: Secretly Canadian
description: After a busy 2013, Diplo’s back with another EP, this one in the guise of Major Lazer. Apocalypse Soon, like its predecessors, is rich in guest stars (Pharrell Williams, Sean Paul) and attempts to bring nuclear-level energy to the world’s dance floors.

title: Atlas
label: Domino
description: On Real Estate's rich, sad third album, Atlas, the once-ideal pool party band has turned to soundtracking the cleanup: Everyone's gone, the sky's threatening rain, there are cigarette butts floating in the pool, and we've all gotta work tomorrow. The result is at once their most forlorn record and their most beautiful.

title: Wave 1
label: Ghostly International
description: Wave 1, the first new material from Com Truise, aka Seth Haley, in two years, plants itself at the intersection of synth-funk, electro, and fussy 80s computer-pop. On the EP, Haley seems unconcerned with the trends of the day, blissfully mining Reagan-era pop at its most meticulous.

title: Electric Balloon
label: Western Vinyl
description: The 11 irresistibly fun songs on Brooklyn indie rockers Ava Luna's new Electric Balloon are as eccentric as anything the band has ever done, but they stick in your head in a way their earlier material didn't.

title: Three Love Songs
label: Orchid Tapes
description: Ricky Eat Acid is Sam Ray, a Maryland-based musician who mixes unobtrusive electronic drifts with the basic shapes you expect from more linear types of songwriting. Three Love Songs is at once hypnotic, triumphant, and bittersweet.

title: Home, Like NoPlace Is There
label: Tiny Engines
description: The Worcester, Mass., emotive rock band the Hotelier’s sophomore record Home, Like NoPlace Is There, burns with a five-alarm intensity. If there isn’t an intervention or a 3AM phone call that must be answered, a funeral is likely to follow. These emergencies are related with rousing group chants, call-and-response hooks, and collegiate jangle.

title: Oxymoron
label: Interscope
description: L.A. rapper Schoolboy Q specializes in hairpin turns from cautionary street tales and remorseful reflection into wanton bacchanal. His Interscope debut Oxymoron is essentially a volleyball match between his warring proclivities.

title: Konstellaatio
label: Sahko
description: For 30 years, the Finnish musician Mika Vainio has doggedly explored the outer edges of extreme electronics in a variety of contexts, including his duo Pan Sonic. Konstellaatio, his first full-length in three years under his occasional mononym Ø, is a beautifully somber reverie.

title: Manhattan
label: Warner Bros.
description: The New York rock quartet Skaters’ debut album about living in Manhattan is titled Manhattan. If the Strokes savvily refashioned NYC iconoclasts like the Velvet Underground and Television as dance-party pop music, Manhattan is what’s become of your head-shop CBGB t-shirt after another 12 years of laundromat visits.

title: Workbook 25
label: Omnivore
description: Bob Mould was an angry young man in Hüsker Dü, and anger abounds on the empty spaces and meandering melodies of his 1989 solo LP Workbook. This expanded reissue includes a live set recorded in Chicago in 1989.

title: Moodymann
label: Mahogani
description: Kenny Dixon Jr.—aka Moodymann—represents the second wave of homegrown Detroit electronic music masters. His new self-titled album throws in plenty of gospel, blues, house music, and roller-rink funk on top of his singular sound.

title: Close to the Glass
label: Sub Pop
description: The Notwist's first full-length since 2008's The Devil, You + Me is their first for Sub Pop. On it, the German electronic band's identity feels increasingly cloudy.

title: Inner Fire
label: Strut
description: The adventurous Ottawa collective's latest patches together swatches of North American, African, and Latin styles to create hybrids that resist easy categorization.

title: No. 2
label: Kranky
description: Brussels-based composer Christina Vantzou first made her name as one-half of the Dead Texan, a project with Stars of the Lid's Adam Wiltzie. Her second solo album, engineered by Wiltzie, underscores her way with mood and commitment to subtle composition.

title: The Satanist
label: Nuclear Blast
description: Behemoth's tenth album, The Satanist, is not only the first album by the Polish firebrands in five years, but also their first since frontman Nergal was diagnosed with leukemia in 2010. The collection's vividly rendered, with bright moments that shine outward from the prevailing doom and themes that wind into dense knots and unravel into electrifying leads.

title: Indoor Living
label: Merge
description: Superchunk's 1997 LP Indoor Living is a moody outlier in Superchunk's great early run. A new Merge reissue includes a live performance and liner notes by bassist Laura Ballance.

title: Present Tense
label: Domino
description: The distinctive sound of Wild Beasts—the dueling voices of Hayden Thorpe and Tom Fleming, a sleek and supple rhythm section, immaculate production—remains on the new Present Tense, but there's a marked shift in lyrical tone. This is on the surface a more domesticated Wild Beasts, but they've lost none of their skill for sharp observation.

title: NVM
label: Hardly Art
description: Instead of a blistering indictment, the Seattle bubblegum rock quartet Tacocat's NVM throws a double-handful of confetti in the face of topics—the male gaze, menstruation, seasonal affective disorder—that might otherwise induce rage blackouts.

title: White Sands
label: Stones Throw
description: Queens rapper Homeboy Sandman's new EP White Sands combines Sandman's scalpel-wielding deadpan with the production of Paul White (Danny Brown's Old). White Sands is a self-contained universe with a lot to explore.

title: The King
label: self-released
description: The once-hyped Austin band Voxtrot was led by the singer-songwriter now simply billed as Ramesh. His comeback album, The King, is a collection of moody indie rock that was partly funded via Kickstarter.

title: Hubba Bubba
label: Castle Face
description: Thee Oh Sees' John Dwyer recently decided, after years of making primarily guitar-centric music, to track down a synthesizer he remembered from his childhood. The result is his debut as Damaged Bug, a release defined by blaring, primitive sonics.

title: Morning Phase
label: Capitol
description: On Morning Phase, Beck returns to the style and form of his 2002 singer-songwriter record Sea Change*.* Instead of a much-needed daring comeback statement, it feels more like a pointed exhale.

title: Interrupt
label: Kanine
description: Over their past few records, Philly garage rockers Bleeding Rainbow—formerly Reading Rainbow—have slowly sorted out who they are. Their new album, Interrupt, is a zippy, Superchunk-y set of buttoned-tight pop-rock songs that bounce nimbly on their heels.

title: Flash
label: !K7
description: The young Bulgarian rapper DENA's debut album Flash is a small and inviting record that is unfazed—delighted, even—by its own rough edges. She strikes a balance between sounding naive enough to pray to the altar of American rap flash and excess and savvy enough to recognize her own distance from it.

title: Palermo House Gang
label: 100% Silk
description: This dancey project from Mi Ami's Damon Palermo is an open-armed embrace of disco's sparkle and classic house music's sassy thump.

title: Blank Project
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: The unclassifiable singer's Blank Project isn’t a roaring, triumphant return to form. Instead, the Four Tet-produced record is understated to the extreme, a master class in the ways in which simple pleasures can become fascinatingly deep.

title: St. Vincent
label: Loma Vista
description: Over the course of four albums, St. Vincent's Annie Clark has been focusing her vision and sharpening her music's edges. St. Vincent is in a sense the Platonic ideal of a St. Vincent record, executing with perfect poise everything we already know she can do.

title: Songs of Descent
label: Forcefield
description: These Nashville upstarts keep the doomy legacy of their forebears close and add to the mix teeth-gnashing thrash, ferocious grindcore breakdowns, slabs of Palm Desert-style stoner rock, and a little industrial ambience.

title: Digital Resistance
label: Metal Blade
description: The heroic metal band Slough Feg’s excellent ninth album is an exploration of how electronics have turned intelligent people into facile consumers following the orders of a screen. But frontman Mike Scalzi has a lot of fun delivering the lecture: These songs overflow with two-guitar pirouettes and resplendent hooks, dynamic surges and appropriate aggression.

title: I Am Back To Blow Your Mind Once Again
label: Mississippi
description: The R.E.M. guitarist's second vinyl-only solo album improves on his first. I Am Back picks up where Peter Buck left off except that it’s more focused and funnier while still retaining its DIY grit.

title: Voices in a Rented Room
label: Drag City
description: Ben Chasny of Six Organs of Admittance and Donovan Quinn of Skygreen Leopards unite on this appealing loose and folky song-based project. Voices in a Rented Room is modestly scaled and simply structured, and Chasny and Quinn are a harmony duo that thrives on mischief and discord.

title: Your Arsenal
label: Parlophone
description: The reissue of Morrissey's third solo studio album comes with a slightly muddy but passable live DVD filmed at California's Shoreline Amphitheatre in October, 1991. And naturally, Morrissey has now doubled down on the annoyance factor of his last few reissues by tinkering with the track listing.

title: Acid Arab Collections
label: Versatile
description: The compilation Acid Arab Collections—which prominently features Syrian electronic star Omar Souleyman—is among the most exuberantly noisy and enthusiastic collections of any sort of dance music to come out in recent memory.

title: Someday, the Moon Will Be Gold
label: Parliament Of Trees
description: The 23-year-old Ottawa singer-songwriter Kalle Mattson's third album, Someday, the Moon Will Be Gold, is a document of personal growth set against the backdrop of his mother's death. His sound's never been this fully realized, and he has never drawn himself in such clear, unflinching light.

title: New Roof EP
label: No Pain in Pop
description: London-based Midwesterner Karen Gwyer showcases a retro-futurist direction on her new three-song EP. The electronic producer brings to mind Autechre in their straighter, earlier form, when they were on the cusp of deconstructing music altogether.

title: Dark Was the Night
label: Endless Flight
description: On Optimo's new mix Dark Was the Night, the Scottish duo thread together techno, industrial, dub, and postpunk with a respectably casual disregard for genre boundaries.

title: Black Light Spiral
label: Hemlock
description: On his proper full-length debut, Jack Dunning, the bass producer who co-runs the Hemlock label, exhibits a drastic shift in direction that abandons proper song structure. This dark record finds him mixing Basic Channel-style dub techno with a horror-movie aesthetic evocative of Haxan Cloak.

title: Days of the Fallen Sun
label: Prosthetic
description: Enduring metalgaze outfit Junius have been plugging away for ten years, mixing lead singer Joseph E. Martinez's clean-toned vocals with doom-metal guitars and soaring choruses. Their new Days of the Fallen Sun EP includes some of the strongest and most sensuous work they've done.

title: Oblique To All Paths
label: Relapse
description: After seven years, the international metal quintet Culted have still never met in person. Mixing doom and drone, death metal and sludge, harsh noise and field recordings, their second full-length, Oblique to All Paths, is one of the most willfully eclectic metal records you’ll hear all year.

title: Ghosts of Then and Now
label: Ninja Tune
description: On Ryan Hunn's first full-length as Illum Sphere, drum'n'bass, techno, glitch, footwork, electronic soul, and hard-knocking hip-hop are all subjected to deconstructive treatments in the cerebral Brainfeeder style and artfully blended with live instruments that can edge toward jazz.

title: Guilt Mirrors
label: Stars & Letters
description: It's been seven years since Shocking Pinks' fine 2007 self-titled album and project leader Nick Harte returns with a 160-minute triple album. He still has a rare ability to convey all-consuming sadness, but finding the worthwhile songs in this bloated set takes some work.

title: Motivational Jumpsuit
label: GBV
description: While indie rock icons Guided by Voices' recent albums—five in two years—have by no means tarnished their legacy, they haven’t exactly expanded upon it either. So it goes with Motivational Jumpsuit, though it's the shortest and strongest of the recent batch.

title: As The Stars
label: Northern Silence
description: The Australian group Woods of Desolation, piloted by a musician known simply as D., complete the shift from depressive black metal to something brighter and more refined on their third album, As the Stars. As with Deafheaven, post rock’s builds and joyous crescendos make up a huge part of the compositions, lending a triumphal feel to the overarching despair.

title: Blame Confusion
label: Fat Possum
description: Montreal fuzzmerchants Solids operate at one of two speeds: pretty fast, and stupid fast. The duo's debut LP, Blame Confusion, is a blur, 37 minutes of speed limit violation that draws from hardcore blister, dream-punk, and raucous cusp-of-the-1990s indie rock.

title: Breaks My Heart Each Time
label: Apollo
description: On his Apollo Records debut, prolific electronic musician James Leyland Kirby works with a familiar sound palette, but it's more than simple tribute fare—there's a remarkable playfulness and sensitivity to Breaks My Heart Each Time that hints at a possible new direction for Kirby.

title: Small Town Heroes
label: ATO
description: Folk outfit Hurray for the Riff Raff's Small Town Heroes borrows liberally from old-time traditions, including Appalachian reels, Big Easy R&B, and Piedmont blues. Yet these songs put a fresh and wily spin on old sounds and ideas, thanks to the formidable presence of singer/songwriter Alynda Lee Segarra.

title: Voices
label: Interscope
description: On their second full-length, synth-pop outfit Phantogram look to graduate from the subliminal to the substantial. It's a quintessential, 1990s-style major-label debut: more heavy-handed and more expensive-sounding, and also exceedingly self-aware of its mission to deliver the goods at this crucial juncture in the band’s career.

title: Cheatahs
label: Wichita
description: Multinational, UK-based quartet Cheatahs work within a narrow stylistic range on their self-titled debut, mixing shoegaze, squalling indie rock, and alt-rock in various ratios. But the group distinguishes themselves with crucial songwriting choices.

title: Dizzy Heights
label: Kobalt
description: It’s been a dozen years since Neil Finn’s last solo album, but between 2002’s One All and this new Dave Fridmann-produced collection, the New Zealander released three Crowded House records and a handful of other offerings. Rather than retrospective singer-songwriter fare, Dizzy Heights is a collection of sunny psychedelia and woozy pop grandeur.

title: Somewhere Else
label: Bloodshot
description: Lydia Loveless' songs are based in country, but she tweaks the forms and formulas of the genre with a bleary belligerence that is, more often than not, directed at herself. Her self-destructive streak makes Somewhere Else both a bracing and a deeply harrowing listen.

title: The Soul Is Quick
label: Ecstatic
description: Hands is a new project from the Field's Axel Willner. If the Field is all vivid colors, the noisier Hands is more focused on a monotone grey.

title: Burn Your Fire for No Witness
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Burn Your Fire for No Witness finds the singer-songwriter inhabiting a fuller, louder sound and embracing punchier song structures. The blown-out, full-band energy enlivens Olsen, kindling an intensity that’s always been present in her songs and fanning the flames even higher.

title: Est...Folle / Comme à la Radio
label: Superior Viaduct
description: The curious French chanteuse Brigitte Fontaine’s oeuvre was a touchstone for a number of 90s alt-rock icons like Beck, Sonic Youth, Björk, Jarvis Cocker, and Stereolab. But only with recent reissues of her third and fourth albums—1968’s playful Est…Folle and 1971’s more avant-garde Comme à La Radio (which she recorded with Art Ensemble of Chicago)—is her music domestically available in the US.

title: All Love's Legal
label: Human Level
description: On All Love's Legal Planningtorock's Jam Rostron refines her approach, adding or subtracting beats and strings until finding the right tension between her unambiguous gender politics and her unknowable voice.

title: Acoustic at the Ryman
label: Brown
description: This live album documents Band of Horses' two-night stand at the legendary Ryman Auditorium in Nashville in April 2013. Hearing the group's songs in an unplugged setting doesn't do them any favors.

title: A Place That Doesn't Exist
label: Hot Charity
description: The joy from Willis Earl Beal's free A Place That Doesn’t Exist EP doesn't always come from the music on it, but more from the plot development in his career. The songs rely less on bluesy moans to convey emotion and more on tightly wound tunes.

title: Adhesive
label: Liberation Technologies
description: Container's Ren Schofield works at the crossroads of techno and noise. His new EP Adhesive's four tracks are simultaneously giddy and rotten, boggling techno's customary propulsion with lingering, heady rhythms and puzzling clamor.

title: Blue Film
label: 4AD
description: For Lo-Fang's debut mixtape-turned-album, Blue Film, classically trained indie rocker Matthew Hemerlein muses aimlessly about his travels and his life. His music is full of intriguing, subtle touches of craftsmanship, but is inert and overwrought in spots.

title: Death By Burning
label: Svart
description: Mantar, a duo from Hamburg, Germany, take plenty from the groovier aspects of 90s metal on their debut LP, but they don't quite feel like the bands they emulate. They're a group who can claim Jesus Lizard as an influence and still hang with staunch metalists.

title: Sleepwalking Sailors
label: Sargent House
description: Sleepwalking Sailors, the third album by Washington state trio Helms Alee, features bracing post-hardcore and primeval indie rock, soporific drift and phosphorescent post-rock. It's their most aggressive, but accessible and fully realized offering to date.

title: Animal Heart
label: The End
description: The Cardigans singer steps out with a loosely conceptual solo album heavy on acoustic instruments. Her voice is beautiful and she writes a great chorus but there are some nagging shortcomings.

title: Cilvia Demo
label: Unknown
description: Cilvia Demo, the debut release from Top Dawg Entertainment's Isaiah Rashad, introduces an MC who isn't afraid to lay every anxiety and frustration bare and winds up looking stronger for it. His first full-length could go down as one of the best debuts of the year.

title: Sun Structures
label: Heavenly
description: UK rockers Temples' new Sun Structures reproduces the sounds of the psychedelic 1960s era with a painstaking, granular attention to detail. But the recreation is so studious that the album is devoid of individual personality.

title: Lowlife
label: Not Not Fun
description: *Lowlife—*the first LP from Afterhours, aka Los Angeles electronic musician Nicholas Crozier Malkin—is an entirely downtempo affair, built out of narcoleptic soul loops, frazzled static, and distant, echoing vocal samples.

title: Freezing Opening Thawing EP
label: Woe to the Septic Heart
description: Freezing Opening Thawing's opener may be the most dramatic outlier in Shackleton's entire body of work. While he's known for his darkly paranoid productions, here the tracks are bright and glossy, fully blanched of color, and a sterility hangs in the atmosphere.

label: Sumerian
description: ††† has been framed as “Chino Moreno’s witch house” project, but what you'll find on the trio's self-titled LP is stadium-status electro-rock akin to Depeche Mode's Songs of Faith and Devotion and Nine Inch Nails. In fact, ††† are supposed to be taken on the same scale as Moreno's other band, the Deftones.

title: Real Hair EP
label: Carpark
description: Speedy Ortiz's four-song EP keeps runtimes tight and choruses front-and-center, pulling in some of Major Arcana's looser ends without sacrificing the fall-apart charm. The band still worship at the altar of early 90s indie—Pavement, Helium, and Archers of Loaf are their holy trinity—but frontwoman Sadie Dupuis has emerged as a distinctive voice.

title: Tranquilizers
label: Carpark
description: In their second offering as a band, Washed Out keyboardist Phil Jones' chillwave outfit Dog Bite leave little evidence of growth or, more importantly, purpose.

title: Soak / The Blue Eyes OST
label: Ectopic
description: Listening to J.G. Thirlwell’s work as Foetus is disorienting. His new record Soak is full-on rock'n'roll, albeit of the theatrical variety, but with a dizzying tone. On the other hand, The Blue Eyes, his soundtrack for a movie of the same name, is eminently clear about its intentions, about the emotions it’s trying to convey, and the response it hopes to evoke.

title: You're Gonna Miss It All
label: Run for Cover
description: The Philadelphia emo band Modern Baseball’s second album features a wealth of infectious songs that are both sharply observed and sharply written. You’re Gonna Miss It All mostly concerns itself with wasted time, and it's dense with both hooks and lyrical barbs.

title: Hardcore Traxx: Dance Mania Records 1986-1997
label: Strut
description: Hardcore Traxx: Dance Mania Records 1986-1997 is the first-ever compilation to honor Chicago house music's coarse, brilliant, and suddenly trendy prodigal son. Best known for lewd, raw, high-tempo tracks—a style known then and now as ghetto house—the Dance Mania label churned out dozens of classic singles that rarely escaped the Midwest.

title: Hotel Valentine
label: Chimera
description: On Cibo Matto's new Hotel Valentine, their first in 15 years, the duo displays a more intent purpose than mere let's-get-the-band-back-together restlessness. Seamlessly sampling acid-jazz, Tropicalia, and deep-bass microhouse, Hotel Valentine reveals how many possibilities Cibo Matto have always been open to.

title: Galore
label: Sub Pop
description: The debut album from the UK pop duo and recent Sub Pop signees Thumpers is filled with extroverted melodies, booming, insistent drums, and glimmering production.

title: Longhena
label: Handshake, Inc.
description: In the world of grindcore, the American/Japanese group Gridlink's pedigree, technicality, and imagination were unrivaled. The band split up following the completion of their third record Longhena, their most intense, oddly beautiful statement.

title: Slip Away
label: Black Bell
description: On Brooklyn indie rockers Total Slacker's new Slip Away, the band largely steps away from the cartoonish caricature they created for themselves on their debut Thrashin' and adopts a new, gauzier aesthetic.

title: Emmaar
label: Anti-
description: Malian musicians Tinariwen's new Emmaar showcases their ever-swirling guitars while also displaying an increasingly refined approach to album-making.

title: Little Red
label: Columbia
description: The singer's full-length follow-up to her influential 2011 album On a Mission finds her trying to write a new chapter in the story of post-millennial British pop: the artist who exploded out of the London underground and then crafted a sustainable career on her own terms, without relying on newer trends or reliable pop heavyweights.

title: We Invented the Bop
label: self-released
description: Out of the exhaust from Chicago's drill scene’s fission emerged its antithesis: bop, a chirpy, hyper-saturated romp through major keys and egregious Auto-Tune paired with a goofily swaggy (though no doubt athletic) dance. The We Invented the Bop compilation is the scene’s first official survey on record.

title: THRU.U
label: White Rainbow
description: As White Rainbow, Portland's Adam Forkner was a darling of a time when indie rock was just beginning its dalliance with synth music. After a hiatus that lasted several years, he's returned with a self-released collection where he attempts to update his hippietastic sprawl with a more modern template and a newfound sense of irony.

title: Instant Alpha
label: Ed Banger
description: Feadz, aka Fabian Pianta, has been a longtime pillar of French house. He emerged in the 90s alongside Mr. Oizo and has put in work for both BPitch and Ed Banger. If his full-length debut, Instant Alpha, highlights anything, it's the limits of how far mere dabbling can get a producer.

title: Chorus EP
label: Rvng Intl.
description: This two-track EP finds composer and vocalist Holly Herndon continuing to develop two sides of her intriguing cut-up aesthetic; the highlight is the brilliant title track, a full realization of her pop-leaning tendencies.

title: July
label: Sacred Bones
description: The haunted folk singer's latest album is her most tactile, thanks in part to producer Randall Dunn, best known for his work with metal bands such as Earth, Sunn O))), and Wolves in the Throne Room.

title: Spiritual Emergency / Mitral Transmission
label: Thrill Jockey
description: For the last two years, Greg Fox has worked with a dozen projects, but his name has been chased by one thorny apposition: (ex-Liturgy). With two new releases, Guardian Alien’s near-brilliant second LP and a collaboration with jazz pioneer Milford Graves, he may have finally drummed himself past parenthetical suffixation.

title: BUM
label: Born Bad
description: The French trio Cheveu make scrappy garage punk featuring belligerent percussion, textural chaos, synth oddities, and lyrics with absurd narratives and a sense of humor. While still unpredictable, their third album, BUM, is perhaps their most delicately arranged.

title: Dunes
label: Secretly Canadian
description: The Santa Barbara, Calif., quartet Gardens & Villa create synthesizer-heavy naturalistic pop that still gets called “indie rock.” Their second album, Dunes, boasts production from DFA’s Tim Goldsworthy, who ensures they keep things varied and in motion.

title: The Unnatural World
label: The Flenser
description: For all its unrelenting gloom, the Connecticut post-punk outfit Have a Nice Life's six-years-in-the-making second album, The Unnatural World, oozes beauty. Sinuous instead of rigid, bloody instead of embalmed, the album refuses to be frozen in time or place.

title: Along the Way
label: Dead Oceans
description: A little more than a year ago, Mark McGuire announced his departure from Emeralds. On his kaleidoscopic new LP, Along the Way, he wrote, played, and produced everything, stepping beyond his usual guitar tessellations to add keyboards and mandolin, drum machines and hand drums, vocals and noise. It is a meticulous solo rendering of a full band’s effort.

title: Woodsman
label: Fire Talk
description: On Denver psych rockers' Woodsman's new self-titled album, the group cuts away the vocals and lets their patterned instrumentals shine through.

title: Terrestrials
label: Southern Lord
description: Considering Sunn O))) and dark Norwegian post-metal experimentalists Ulver's résumés, the relatively bright sounds, open-ended structures, and medium volume of Terrestrials might come as a surprise.

title: Deleted/Fool EP
label: Friends of Friends
description: Jerome LOL, previously of LOL Boys, has been identified as a representative of the Seapunk movement, a combination of 90s fashion, internet 1.0 imagery, early aughts R&B, and house music. His Deleted/Fool EP is a collection of R&B tracks punctuated with swirling dancehall rhythms, dulcet California synths, and female guest vocals.

title: Worth EP
label: Downtown
description: Thomas Arsenault, aka Mas Ysa, is a Montreal-born multi-instrumentalist whose music moves seamlessly between 80s synth-pop, contemporary techno, and indie electronic styles. On his debut EP, he precisely executes his musical ideas and leaves the bloodletting to his lyrics, faintly petulant spasms of romantic denunciation and guilt.

title: Angel Guts: Red Classroom
label: Polyvinyl
description: Angel Guts: Red Classroom comes bearing the promise of being the most dark and bleak Xiu Xiu album to date. The source for the title of Jamie Stewart's L.A. album is a “Japanese erotic noir” that explores “racialized sex, double suicide, double penetration, criminality, fear of physical harm.”

title: VoyAager
label: Northern Spy
description: Given their meticulous ethic, it’s not a complete surprise it’s taken the rhythmically inclined Brooklyn indie-rock act Aa seven years to release a proper follow-up to their 2007 debut, gAame. VoyAager's expertly sculpted 3-D sound world is situated somewhere between the grandiose digi-symphonies of Fuck Buttons and the technicolor throttle of early NIN.

title: The Life Stains
label: HOSS
description: The Life Stains, the first album from electronic producer DJ Dog Dick, is a full-on expression of Max Eisenberg’s artistic attitude. As the album progresses, sneaky craft bleeds in, and humor and gravity meld into something not so easily pegged.

title: High Land, Hard Rain
label: Domino
description: Aztec Camera's 1983 album High Land, Hard Rain showcases frontman Roddy Frame at his most blissfully unaware, creating soulful post-punk with pieces that weren’t neccessarily supposed to fit together. This 30th Anniversary Reissue includes B-sides, remixes and live radio sessions from the period.

title: So Long, See You Tomorrow
label: Island
description: Bombay Bicycle Club's latest So Long, See You Tomorrow is an often dazzling, euphoric electronic-pop record where the band has decided to depart from their jangly indie pop roots.

title: After the Disco
label: Columbia
description: The second album from the Shins' James Mercer and producer Brian Burton (aka Danger Mouse) is a more cohesive and full-bodied work than their self-titled 2010 debut. The title of After the Disco suggests that Broken Bells' attention has turned to the dancefloor and that holds true, to a point.

title: The Age of Fracture
label: Tough Love
description: When UK rockers CYMBALS first debuted they were on the scrappy side of post-punk, releasing their energy in brief, nervous bursts. On The Age of Fracture, they’ve settled down and drawn out a solemn groove, furthering a sound indebted to bands like New Order and Depeche Mode.

title: Piano Nights
label: Ipecac
description: Like their previous work, Bohren & der Club of Gore's eighth album folds in lounge jazz, dark ambience, the languorous adagios of classical-music requiem, and the saturated romance of Italian film soundtracks. But while the German band's earliest recordings were chilly and even brittle, Piano Nights is luxurious in its warmth.

title: Past Life
label: Anti-
description: On their third album, orchestral North Carolina band Lost in the Trees reduced themselves from a sextet to a quartet, worked with an outside producer for the first time, and folded electronic elements into their indie-folk. The resulting music is refreshingly streamlined and direct.

title: moon
label: Bella Union
description: Former Cocteau Twins member Simon Raymonde collaborates with vocalist Stephanie Dosen as Snowbird. There are also guest spots from Radiohead's Ed O’Brien and Phil Selway and Midlake and Lanterns on the Lake members on this gently appealing collection of lush, but understated songs.

title: Benji
label: Caldo Verde
description: There are 11 songs on Sun Kil Moon’s astonishing sixth LP Benji, and in nearly all of them, somebody dies. Mark Kozelek wants us to know that they all lived, loved, fought, fucked up, and often did the best they could. While Benji is consumed with death, sadness, and tragedy, there's gratitude within this melancholy, and it’s Kozelek’s most life-affirming record.

title: Rooms With Walls and Windows
label: Orindal
description: Seattle vocalist/guitarist Julie Byrne's Rooms With Walls & Windows feels like a secret she's keeping from you, even when it is safely in your headphones. Her version of folk, a whisper bordering on an ambient hum, will be familiar to fans of early Cat Power, or Grouper's Dragging A Dead Deer Up A Hill.

title: Electronic Works 1976-1977
label: Dais Records
description: In between playing with Cecil Taylor in the early 70s and forming the instrumental trio the Notekillers in 1977, David First took a class in electronic music at Princeton, where he got to play a Buchla 100 modular synthesizer. Judging by the dizzying music he made, released as Electronic Works 1976-1977, First dove headlong into the Buchla’s possibilities.

title: Beach House EP
label: Atlantic
description: After paying dues producing for Compton stars YG and Problem and featuring on Cali rap records of every stripe, Los Angeles singer/producer Ty Dolla $ign zeroed in on a sleek, commercially viable sound on his Beach House mixtape series. Beach House the EP succeeds where last year's Beach House 2 didn’t, further commercializing Ty’s sound without sacrificing the meat and potatoes of it.

title: Too Much Information
label: Daylighting
description: UK alt rock vets Maximo Park were originally noted for being another successful, angular guitar act. A few albums later, they’ve flipped the script: Too Much Information, their newest, eases up on the gas while deepening their commitment to contemplative songwriting.

title: wonderland
label: Modular
description: On 2010's White Magic, Swedish producer CEO—aka the Tough Alliance's Eric Berglund—suggested he'd made peace with the contradictions between creativity and publicity, self-expression and selling yourself. His new Wonderland is luxuriantly widescreen and eccentrically detail-rich as ever.

title: Radio Niger
label: Sublime Frequencies
description: Comprised of recordings of radio broadcasts made by Hisham Mayet in the Saharan country of Niger and edited and sequenced by Alan Bishop, Radio Niger is a swirling collage that captures both captivating music and the sense of play and experimentation with which Nigerien DJs approach their trade.

title: Native State
label: Brutal Honest
description: The Austin native Jess Williamson’s particular strain of folk is at once earthy and gothic, often seeming haunted by some invisible, vaguely tortured presence. Her debut full-length Native State is only seven songs long, but it unfolds at an unhurried pace that makes it feel expansive.

title: Winter's Diary 2
label: self-released
description: Tink is a teenage singer and rapper from the south Chicago suburb of Calumet City who has put out four mixtapes of varying tone and quality since early 2012. She stakes out a distinctively young, female voice whether she's expressing the frustration of dealing with flaky lovers or playing at and winning that boys' rap game of pretending you're a drug kingpin.

title: Held In Splendor
label: Mexican Summer
description: On Quilt’s 2011 self-titled debut, the ghosts of the Byrds, Jefferson Airplane, and Mamas and the Papas were summoned via jangly, well-written pop songs. On the Mass. trio’s sophomore release, they blow out those simple psych-folk ditties into multi-part suites that build toward thrilling, guitar-heavy climaxes.

title: No Depression: Legacy Edition
label: Sony
description: Uncle Tupelo is typically evoked in discussions of the two outfits it birthed (Wilco and Son Volt), but the band's 1990 debut is a significant record independent of its fallout. Jeff Tweedy and drummer Mike Heidorn were 22 and Jay Farrar was 23 when they arrived at Fort Apache to record No Depression, and the tangling of sensibilities yielded something remarkable: a raw, lonesome clatter, the singular sound of Midwestern kids getting loud and desperate.

title: In Roses
label: Hardly Art
description: Boston-area trio Gem Club’s follow-up to their 2011 album Breakers is warmer and richer than its predecessor, going for a lush chamber-pop feel that suits the band's songwriting.

title: Drained of Connotation
label: Blackest Ever Black
description: In the 80s and 90s, Stefan Jaworzyn was central to the UK noise underground via his work with Whitehouse, Skullflower, Ascension, and others. He disappeared in the late 90s, but returned last year: Drained of Connotation, a collection of solo pieces he made in 1982 using a synth and a drum machine, shows his recent beat-oriented mindset didn't come out of nowhere.

title: Divine Ecstasy
label: Dovecote
description: Chicago production duo Supreme Cuts' Whispers in the Dark was a strikingly trendy and sometimes engrossing stew of bass beats that seemed more eager to confound than galvanize. Alongside a number of vocal collaborators on their new album Divine Ecstasy, Supreme Cuts shoot for the anthemic but come up measurably short.

title: The Green EP
label: Warp
description: Electronic producer Bibio's new Green EP collects outtakes from last year's Silver Wilkinson. Like the album from which it was derived, the Green EP is pleasantly moody.

title: Nixon
label: Merge
description: When Nixon was released in 2000, it was immediately enshrined by the British music press, though most people in America continued to have no idea who Lambchop were. Merge's 2xCD reissue of the Nashville country/soul troupe's sumptuous fifth collection also offers the White Sessions 1998: How I Met Cat Power, a set by singer Kurt Wagner on French radio.

title: 20th Adversary of Emptiness
label: Svart
description: Just as rock'n'roll has its shadow canon, the Trout Mask Replicas and SMiLEs that offset the Revolvers and Blonde on Blondes, extreme metal has an alternate-universe hall of fame. The 1993 collection Nespithe, the only LP released by the eccentric Finnish death metal band Demilich, is one of these. This 3xLP/2xCD retrospective packages it with everything the brainiac obsessives ever recorded.

title: Wedding Bells EP
label: LuckyMe
description: On the second EP from Cashmere Cat—the alias of Norwegian electronic producer Magnus August Høiberg*—*he ramps up the twinkly, diaphanous, twee elements in his arsenal.

title: Innocence
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Though by no means a "comeback" record, the latest from Blue Ridge rockers Pontiak, Innocence, does have a whiff of rejuvenation about it.

title: Ghettoville
label: Werk Discs
description: Darren Cunningham's fourth album as Actress is a record that takes his fascinations—Detroit techno, Chicago ghetto house, rap—and repeatedly kicks them in the ribs. After three collections that played Jenga with genre rules, Ghettoville is content to wallow in the ruins of the musics its predecessors so fascinatingly deconstructed.

title: Thirtysixtwentyfive / Misnomer / Glasshead / Dialogue
label: Output
description: Earlier this year Kieran Hebden opened a Bandcamp account, offering streams and downloads of three early Four Tet EPs and the full-length Dialogue. The material dates to the late 1990s, when Four Tet was more of a side project for Hebden, and when his attention fell mostly on his three-piece band, Fridge.

title: Malleus Maleficarum
label: Forcefield
description: On their second LP, Malleus Maleficarum, the Knoxville, Tenn., trio Argentinum Astrum aim to bridge the gap between doom and black metal. The DIY production values are subterranean, blanketing the recording in a thick miasma of distortion and soot.

title: Morgan Delt
label: Trouble in Mind
description: California native Morgan Delt is a homegrown musician whose debut evades convenient pigeonholing. The collection is a carefully built mosaic of jangly power pop, fuzzed out martian rock, and did-it-myself B-movie soundtracking that dissolves into a melted mess.

title: Trouble
label: Merge
description: On their second album, Hospitality move beyond the catchy indie-pop of their 2012 debut. With Trouble, the Amber Papini-led Brooklyn trio make a point of showing their listeners the difference between "beautiful" and "cute."

title: Come to Life
label: Young One
description: Memphis rapper Cities Aviv continues to exist outside neat genre lines, mixing spacey production and rock aggression into a distinctive and personal style.

title: Too True
label: Sub Pop
description: Dum Dum Girls mastermind Dee Dee has been flirting with, and stepping tentatively back from, full-fledged stardom ever since she introduced herself to us. Her well-crafted third album is sparkling and beautiful, a glittering glaze of guitars and keyboards.

title: Lord Steppington
label: Rhymesayers
description: The Alchemist and Dilated Peoples' Evidence bring their shared understanding of the history and context of rap (and a guest list that includes Domo Genesis, Action Bronson, Styles P, and Blu) to their new project Lord Steppington, a welcome addition to the collection of solid boom-bap rap albums that Alchemist has helmed over the last few years.

title: Drowners
label: Frenchkiss
description: On their self-titled debut, the New York-based post-punk band Drowners, fronted by Welsh male-model/musician Matt Hitt, recall early Strokes and Arctic Monkeys. Their willingness and ability to sound like two and only two bands is actually kind of impressive.

title: Where Shine New Lights
label: Kranky
description: Tara Jane O'Neil's first solo LP in five years finds the ex-Rodan bassist, painter, constant collaborator, and tireless solo experimenter carving scenery out of sound. It's quite possibly the finest merging of the chameleonic O'Neil's song-based work and her more experimental side.

title: Abandoned Apartments
label: Grand Palais
description: Jeremy Jay, who's been signed to Calvin Johnson's K Records for years, has an ongoing fascination with dreams and cinema, and an aesthete's ear for perfect little sounds. His newest collection, Abandoned Apartments, is more nocturnal and forlorn than 2011's Dream Diary.

title: Transgender Dysphoria Blues
label: Total Treble
description: On their sixth album Transgender Dysphoria Blues, Laura Jane Grace and Against Me! draw a hard line between “identity” and “ideology.” Produced by Grace and put out on her own label Total Treble, the band splits the difference from old and new into a compact sound that skews more Sex Pistols than Foo Fighters.

title: Michael Lee Yonkers / Borders of My Mind
label: Drag City
description: As new albums from Minneapolis cult hero Michael Lee Yonkers have come to light, it seems as if his breakthrough Microminiature Love’s raving, avant-garage inclinations were just a blip. The new Drag City reissues of two of his early-70s albums show just how much country and folk were part of Yonkers’s idiosyncratic musical worldview.

title: From All Purity
label: Relapse
description: The Chicago blackened doom band Indian's fifth album wields as much power from a distance as it does in close quarters. With ex-Wolves in the Throne Room guitarist Will Lindsay re-enlisting to split guitars and vocals, and Bloodyminded mastermind Mark Solotroff adding sheets of  noise, it's an album whose every layer seems customized and every crease deliberate.

title: Brothers and Sisters of the Eternal Son
label: Secretly Canadian
description: Damien Jurado’s 11th album, Brothers and Sisters of the Eternal Son, is the third piece in a Richard Swift-produced triptych that began with 2010’s St. Bartlett and continued on 2012’s Maraqopa. It's yet another leap into territory that Jurado has only touched on previously.

title: Spaces
label: Erased Tapes
description: The Berlin-based composer Nils Frahm's Spaces is a live album patchworked together from various recordings, containing songs both old and new, some shortened, some lengthened, some radically different in approach. It's a mesmerizing and beautiful work.

title: Have Fun With God
label: Drag City
description: Have Fun With God is Bill Callahan and his mixer Brian Beattie's dub version of last year's excellent Dream River. It feels like a live, real-time dub, and in addition to this sense of spontaneity, the arrangements lend themselves well to the treatment.

title: Shy Boys
label: High Dive
description: Kansas City indie pop trio Shy Boys' self-titled debut is a triumph of ramshackle aesthetics and homespun hooks. Instrumentally, Shy Boys is far from dazzling, but that doesn't seem to hold the group back.

title: Sanctuary: The Complete Discography
label: Sacred Bones
description: The relatively unheralded UK outfit Vex was an anarcho-punk band that sounded far more dark, desperate, raw, and apocalyptic than anything at the time. A new reissue of their lone release, 1984's Sanctuary, showcases a band throbbing with ominous, semi-industrial precision.

title: Light Show
label: God?
description: Enigmatic L.A. musician Jack Name—who has also recorded as Muzz, Fictional Boys, and John Webster Johns—creates his own world on his new Light Show. It's Name's attempt at a rock opera, and even though it features catchy, immediate songs, it's an album that asks for focus and thought.

title: Tuck Box
label: Island
description: The posthumous marketing of Nick Drake's music has been arduous and fitful, a decades-long attempt at setting right what everyone agreed went horribly wrong the first time. His new box set Tuck Box, the latest and possibly final repackaging, includes studio albums Five Leaves Left, Bryter Layter, and Pink Moon as well as two compilations of rarities.

title: Warpaint
label: Rough Trade
description: The Los Angeles band Warpaint's three-years-in-the-making second album, featuring cover art from acclaimed video director Chris Cunningham, was produced by Flood and mixed by Nigel Godrich.

title: Edges
label: New Kanada
description: While peers adjusted from "post-dubstep" to techno and house, Toronto electronic duo Graze offered a fully-formed and distinct aesthetic on their self-titled debut. Its follow-up LP, Edges, strips their sound down to its bare essentials.

title: Shelter
label: Prophecy
description: The French outfit Alcest has been slowly turning away from the corrosive, ambient metal of their early work—a sound that’s influenced many, most notably Deafheaven—toward an unbroken dreamscape of cushiony shoegaze. Their fourth album, Shelter, produced by Birgir Jón Birgisson and featuring vocals from Slowdive’s Neil Halstead, marks that clean break.

title: Strong Feelings
label: No Quarter
description: On Doug Paisley's third album Strong Feelings, featuring guest vocals from Mary Margaret O’Hara, the Toronto alt-country artist seeks refuge in the beauty of the romantic lyrical metaphors that have populated the country genre since at least the heyday of Hank Williams.

title: Post Tropical
label: Vagrant
description: Irish singer James Vincent McMorrow's sophomore effort Post Tropical is an album that seems suited to winter. It features lyrics about “elements of frost” and “cold air” and taut, pensive songs that carry a pristine stillness.

title: Fuck Off Get Free We Pour Light on Everything
artist: Thee Silver Mt. Zion Memorial Orchestra
label: Constellation
description: The orchestro-punk Godspeed offshoot Thee Silver Mt. Zion's excellent seventh album examines the difficulties of keeping one’s moral compass steady in a society that’s becoming ever-more indifferent to the things you value. The songs are more outwardly anthemic and viscerally rocking than Godspeed’s slow-surging, side-long epics.

title: Gay Disco
label: NNA Tapes
description: Led by vocalist Kassie Carlson, who evokes a tuned-up Kathleen Hanna or Molly Siegel of Ponytail, the Boston band Guerilla Toss channel the fractured funk of pre-Echoes Rapture, Black Dice's anti-grooves, and the tinnitus-beckoning mania of Lightning Bolt.

title: Fabriclive 73
label: Fabric
description: On Pangea's Fabriclive 73 mix, Kevin McAuley uses the platform to articulate a compelling case for the state of UK techno in 2014. Fabriclive 73 is complex and confrontational but resolutely unshowy.

title: The Invention of Animals
label: Amulet
description: The legendary Lounge Lizard and no wave filmmaker/actor John Lurie has always had a big personality, but he's also a consummate collaborator. The Invention of Animals is a collection of live recordings and studio tracks used for episodes of his "Fishing With John" series that he made with drummers Billy Martin and Calvin Weston.

title: Killed by Deathrock: Vol. 1
label: Sacred Bones
description: Sacred Bones' new odds-and-ends compilation Killed By Deathrock, which unearths bizarre modern punk bands who produce oddities and competent facsimiles of more popular bands, is pure fun.

title: Rave Tapes
label: Sub Pop
description: Mogwai's eighth album outside their soundtrack and remix work has been framed in terms of its increased use of electronics. The instrumentation has indeed shifted, but Rave Tapes digs hard into a place they've consistently circled back to throughout their career.

title: Alternate / Endings
label: Ninja Tune
description: Lee Bannon broke through as one of the most promising producers associated with Joey Bada$$'s Pro Era crew, offering potent updates of beats forged by the likes of RZA and DJ Premier. Since then he's gotten weirder, and his drum and bass-inspired second album, Alternate/Endings, seems more interested in atmosphere than rhythm.

title: Eighteen Hours of Static
label: Tough Love
description: Throughout Eighteen Hours of Static, arty Brooklyn post-punkers Big Ups' howling debut LP, vocalist Joe Galarraga and company put the world on notice. For 28 minutes, no grievance goes unaired, and no blood's left unlet.

title: Chiaroscuro
label: Bella Union
description: Swedish electronic duo I Break Horses' sophomore LP Chiaroscuro finds a band deliberatly slowing down and simplifying their sound. But for all this reduction, I Break Horses are left with little that they can call their own.

title: Has God Seen My Shadow?: An Anthology 1989-2011
label: Light in the Attic
description: Even when he’s stealing the spotlight, Mark Lanegan still seems like he’s lurking in the shadows, not so much singing a song as haunting it. So it’s appropriate that Lanegan’s now receiving a tribute that most don't receive until they're dead, the career-spanning collection Has God Seen My Shadow?: An Anthology 1989-2011.

title: Bad Debt
label: Paradise of Bachelors
description: Songwriter M.C. Taylor—who records as Hiss Golden Messenger—wrote Bad Debt in 2009, months after his son was born, and recorded it in his North Carolina kitchen. Destroyed in a warehouse fire and just now seeing wider re-release, Bad Debt is an album deeply concerned with the nature of faith and man’s relationship with his Maker.

title: Mr. Jones
label: Rekids
description: In 2013, the Russian electronic producer and DJ Nina Kraviz was the focus of discussions on feminism and raw sexuality in club culture. Mr. Jones, her first material in 18 months, is a 54-minute double EP.

title: Audion X
