label: Ghostly
description: Matthew Dear's dancefloor-oriented side project Audion was introduced in the middle of the last decade to provide an outlet for his baser desires. Audion X, offered up 10 years after the release of Audion's sole album, Suckfish, collects 18 tracks from a dozen-plus EPs and that album, and adds two new tracks in anticipation of a sophomore LP, due later this year.

title: The State vs. Radric Davis II: The Caged Bird Sings
label: 1017 Brick Squad
description: On this Bandcamp release, Gucci gets ample assists from his usual Brick Squad brethren Young Thug, Peewee Longway, and Young Scooter as well as production help from 808 Mafia and Zaytoven.

title: Keep Doing What You're Doing
label: Topshelf
description: The Orlando emo band You Blew It!’s sophomore LP, Keep Doing What You’re Doing, is a deeply satisfying “airing of grievances” record. The group's poised to fill a role for frustrated listeners who can no longer find loud, angsty rock'n'roll via traditional indie channels.

title: White Light/White Heat
label: Interscope
description: When the Velvet Underground's second album descended on the world in January, 1968, nobody was ready for it. As the story goes, it was a relentless, screeching, thudding, scoffing assault on the pop sensibilities of its time. For its 45th anniversary it's been reissued in expanded, remastered form, and listening to White Light/White Heat now, it doesn't quite fit the template of its legend.

title: The Soul Tape 3
label: self-released
description: Fabolous' The Soul Tape 3 is the third and final installment in his trilogy of soul-sample-heavy mixtapes, and it attempts to reinforce his status as a go-to for those in search of comfort food rap.

title: Cartography for Beginners: A Best of the Lucksmiths
label: Matinee
description: Australian trio the Lucksmiths were exemplars of a certain kind of deliberately anti-macho indie-pop that would have made sense on Sarah Records or as part of the C86 scene. Their 16-year artistic evolution meant a slow, steady improvement in craft, making this the rare decade-plus retrospective where the later songs beat the early ones.

title: Broken Swenglish Vol. 1 EP
label: Ingrid
description: The four English-sung power-pop songs on Broken Swenglish were originally recorded in Swedish and found across a pair of Peter Morén solo albums he released outside his main gig in Peter Bjorn & John. The music's nearly identical to the originals, but the lyrics have shifted.

title: NOT O.K.
label: self-released
description: The amount of material Victor Vazquez has made in the year since Das Racist called it quits tops the total output of his previous gig. But despite being a collection of outtakes from his upcoming proper album, Not O.K. features the kind of roster (Toro Y Moi, Del Tha Funkee Homosapien, Ladybug Mecca from Digable Planets, etc.) that makes it feel like the biggest event of  his post-DR career.

title: Give the People What They Want
label: Daptone
description: Even if the title of Sharon Jones and the Dap-Kings' fifth album invokes one of the more state-of-the-art slices of 70s soul as delivered by the O'Jays, Give the People What They Want finds the group staying in their late 1960s lane. It's an album built less on advancement than resilience.

title: The Shaw Tapes: Live in Detroit 5/27/88
label: Third Man
description: Detroit punks the Gories' new archival release, The Shaw Tapes: Live in Detroit 5/27/88, showcases a slapdash snapshot of a young, feral gang of throwbacks reinventing a genre by uninventing it.

title: Forever
label: Polyvinyl
description: Forever, the debut LP from the San Francisco psych-pop duo Painted Palms, crafts a balmy sound that showcases their refind melodicism. However, its 39 minutes often run together.

title: Iller Than Most
label: self-released
description: Bay Area hip hop vet Del tha Funkee Homosapien's unexpected return—the low stakes, free mixtape *Iller Than Most—*is both ridiculously goofy and ridiculously fun.

title: Enter
label: Fantasy
description: Cybotron’s 1983 album, Enter, is widely considered to be where Detroit techno began. The collection's obsessed with the future as co-creators Juan Atkins and Richard Davis saw it, a vision dominated by the notion that human life would become so intertwined with technology that they’d be essentially inseparable.

title: Settle: The Remixes
label: Island
description: Settle: The Remixes features Hudson Mohawke, Baauer, Totally Enormous Extinct Dinosaurs, Flume, DJ Premier, Larry Heard, and others remixing tracks from Disclosure's instant classic debut, along with two new originals.

title: Until the Colours Run
label: Bella Union
description: UK indie rockers Lanterns on the Lake’s second album Until the Colours Run is borne of loss, turmoil, and doubt on every level. The group expresses faded glory and missed opportunities while exhibiting potential with many rich sounds and potent concepts.

title: Grassed Inn
label: Fire
description: From the dense psych of 2010’s Headless Ark, to the damaged rock of 2012’s Go Easy, Aussie noise rockers Blank Realm have been tracing an arc toward accessibility. Their latest, Grassed Inn, is their most structured, tune-heavy album to date—as well as their best.

title: Marci Beaucoup
label: Man Bites Dog
description: Over the course of his first two albums, New York rapper Roc Marciano established himself as one of the foremost purveyors of classicist New York slick-talk. His latest release, Marci Beaucoup, finds Marciano stepping out of the spotlight and focusing on his production chops.

title: Early Live Recordings
label: Human Ear
description: Early Live Recordings is a 2xCD set that digs into Ariel Pink’s earliest material, and while there are no exact dates to peg to these 36 tracks, the recordings appear to predate Pink’s inspired 21st century spurts. They are lo-fi recordings to say the least, heavy on detuned bass, lackadaisical tambourine rattles, and feral growls, all of it couched in tape murk.

title: High Hopes
label: Columbia
description: Bruce Springsteen’s 18th record, High Hopes, is a collection of new recordings of songs he's been playing for 10 or 12 years. They're essentially outtakes from The Rising, Magic, and Working on a Dream*,* but Springsteen re-recorded them with producer Ron Aniello—often with Tom Morello on guitar—and sequenced them into an album.

title: Terminal Teen Age
label: Dead Beat
description: Sick Thoughts is the garage punk project of Baltimore teenager Drew Owen. His exciting, impressive debut, Terminal Teen Age, delivers bug-eyed weirdness, screaming intensity, and a seemingly effortless knack for crafting hooks.

title: Battlefields Forever
label: Gold Metal
description: After the demise of their longtime label Hydra Head, the Los Angeles heavy rock/light metal trio Big Business decided to release Battlefields Forever, their excellent fourth album, on their own. It turns out they're better at making records than marketing them.

title: Try Me
label: Deathwish
description: Over 10 years and dozens of releases—under their current name and as End of a Year—Self Defense Family have built themselves out of perversity, mixing black humor, jarring turns of phrase, and pop-culture references with open-hearted hardcore. Their official full-length debut, Try Me, strays even further from emo fundamentalism.

title: Dirty Gold
label: Island
description: No one will come away from New York-via-Detroit rapper Angel Haze's major label debut doubting her natural talent, but Dirty Gold lacks the spark and distinct personality of a proper coming-out.

title: EP-2
label: self-released
description: The resurrected Pixies' EP-2 dates from the same recording sessions as last year's EP-1. The four new songs here are less blank than the four on the first, but the gulf between the feel this music has on the mind and the name on the cover remains jarring.

title: Dr. Stokley
label: Mello
description: Dr. Stokley represents a synthesis of Stones Throw rapper and singer Dudley Perkins’ career, combining his relatively grounded early days as Declaime with the funk, soul, and afrocentric mysticism that he’s embraced in his later years.

title: River of Souls
label: Empty Cellar
description: Tim Cohen wrote the songs for River of Souls with backup singers in mind. He’s said the only thing that separates his Magic Trick material from his work with the Fresh & Onlys are the two bands’ personnel, but this breezy collection is all about beauty and sheen.

title: Dell'Universo Assente
label: Die Schachtel
description: As one might expect that with a title like 'The Absent Universe," the reissue of style-sampling Italian composer Luciano Cilio's Dell'Universo Assente is a spare album, its pleasures revealed through careful listening rather than quick snippets. Not a single note or gesture feels out of place.

title: Spezmodia EP
label: Monkeytown
description: Jettisoning most of the 2012 "comeback" LP Parastrophics' sonic jumble for something more explicitly streamlined, Spezmodia represents one of Mouse on Mars' sharpest left turns in the past decade. On these five-songs, they shape their taste for aggressive textures into new, more dancefloor-ready molds.

title: The Abstract And The Dragon
label: self-released
description: The new collaborative project from New York Native Tongue veterans Q-Tip and Busta Rhymes, The Abstract and the Dragon, features a handful of interesting exclusives but mostly revised older work. The new cuts, in particular, showcase a madcap chemistry unblemished by the passage of time.

title: Clapper Is Still
label: Upset the Rhythm
description: Each homespun song on "pastoral punk" duo Way Through's new Clapper Is Still >plots a course through England's history. It's a noisy, warm record filled with chaos and constant upheaval.

title: The Ancient Tonalities Of…
label: No Pain in Pop
description: The best tracks from this Finnish producer fall somewhere in the middle of Kompakt's crushed-ice prettiness, Border Community's glowing pastoral techno, and the enveloping analog warmth of Warp's ambient outposts.

title: Wind In Lonely Fences 1970 - 2011
label: All Saints
description: Harold Budd's music exists somewhere between ambient, new age, and minimalism. Wind in Lonely Fences is a 2xCD retrospective of the prolific composer—with as many albums as Budd has to choose from and no responsibility to things like radio hits, the job of the compiler becomes an unusually creative one.

title: Drilluminati 2
label: self-released
description: Though Chicago drill veteran King L has splashed around in other styles, his new mixtape Drilluminati 2 emphasizes his music is very self-contained.

title: Instrumental Tape 3
label: self-released
description: Producer Mike Volpe, aka Clams Casino, released his third instrumental mixtape for free on Twitter just before 2013 came to a close. This final installment in the series features beats for A$AP Rocky, Mac Miller, Mikky Ekko, DOOM, a remix, and three previously unreleased originals.

title: Retrieval
label: Blackest Ever Black
description: Mamiffer's Faith Coloccia runs SIGE Records with husband and frequent collaborator, ISIS co-founder Aaron Turner. Her debut with Chicago multi-instrumentalist Alex Barnett of Oakeater offers warped AM radio transmissions comingling with soporific beats, Motorik clicks riding beneath keyboard nightmares.

title: Justus Köhncke & the Wonderful Frequency Band
label: Kompakt
description: Although the new album from Kompakt Records tentpole Justus Köhncke boasts a characteristic mix of mid-tempo house, techno, disco and kitschy pop, it’s hardly a definitive statement.

title: There’s A Dream I’ve Been Saving: Lee Hazlewood Industries 1966–1971
label: Light in the Attic
description: The four-disc box set There's A Dream I've Been Saving chronicles the output of Lee Hazlewood’s California-based LHI label during the prime of the hippie era, and it’s steeped in the bright, balmy Hollywood atmosphere from whence it came.

title: L.I.E.S. Presents: Music for Shut-Ins
label: Delsin
description: The title of L.I.E.S.' two-and-a-half-hour second label-summating compilation, Music for Shut-Ins, may or may not playfully allude to the forward thinking dance imprint's reputation for fringe-originating dance music. But the collection approaches a perverted accessibility.

title: Wig Out at Jagbags
label: Matador
description: Most of Stephen Malkmus' newest solo effort, Wig Out at Jagbags, sounds like 70s guitar-rock rendered as some kind of ergonomic desk toy: compact, brightly colored, unlikely to stir the depths of the soul but nifty nevertheless. He's never resisted age but has never seemed younger.

title: Hallelujah All the Way Home / Juvenilia
label: Flying Nun
description: Captured Tracks' reissues of the Flying Nun catalogue continue with two releases by New Zealand's the Verlaines. Hallelujah All the Way Home is the post-punk band’s first album from 1985, and Juvenilia is a 1987 compilation.

title: A Fallen Empire
label: Downwards
description: The music of Berlin-based Brit Samuel Kerridge bears a pitch-black complexion that firmly positions it alongside an entire strain of current electronic music. However, on his new A Fallen Empire, Kerridge incorporates different electronic shades than his peers, making the release stand apart.

title: Journey of the Deep Sea Dweller IV
label: Clone
description: This is the fourth and final volume of Dutch imprint Clone’s Drexciya reissue series, which gathers out-of-print music from the difficult-to-classify Detroit electronic music project. This set contains some of the group's spikiest electro, as well as music that has the raw spirit of punk.

title: The Block Brochure: Welcome To the Soil, Pt. 4, 5, & 6
label: Heavy on the Grind
description: Making great rap music is a reason to live for Bay Area legend E-40, whose fierce new The Block Brochure: Welcome To the Soil installments act as a fountain of youth.

title: Beyoncé
label: Columbia
description: Beyoncé's fifth album, surprise-released on iTunes in December, finds the singer hitting a new peak. Working with a large cast of collaborators, she shifts gears to pull off her most explicit and sonically experimental music to date, exploring sounds and ideas at the grittier margins of popular music.

title: Saâda Bonaire
label: Captured Tracks
description: Saâda Bonaire, the model-esque non-singers Stefanie Lange and Claudia Hossfeld, released their lone single in 1984. This unexpected reissue from Captured Tracks under their Fantasy Memory subsidiary reveals that the project was the concoction of Ralph “Von” Richtoven, a Bremen club DJ, and produced by dubmaster Dennis Bovell in Kraftwerk’s Cologne studios.

title: Fair
label: Prah
description: This six-track debut album from the Brooklyn-based producer Bryce Hackford might look like an EP on the surface, but it explores the trancey side of house music at great length, creatively mixing in rock dynamics along the way.

title: The First And Last Days Of Unwelcome
label: Southern Lord
description: Lumbar is the doom metal trio of Aaron Edge, Yob’s Mike Scheidt and Tad's Tad Doyle. They took their name in honor of the three spinal taps Edge endured for a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis, a diagnosis that may mean this remarkable debut is their last.

title: BOOT!
label: Thing
description: Swedish/Norwegian trio the Thing—who've covered the Cramps, the Sonics, and PJ Harvey and collaborated with Jim O’Rourke, Peter Brötzmann, and Merzbow—play free jazz you can stage dive to. Their sixth album, Boot!, is among the group’s finest efforts at pairing bludgeoning physicality with heady free jazz chops.

title: Rival Dealer EP
label: Hyperdub
description: Burial's new EP, Rival Dealer, arrives almost exactly a year after the release of Truant/Rough Sleeper, but the stylistic leaps made on this release are wider, more jarring and revelatory, than anything in Burial's catalog. It's unquestionably the strongest release of his since 2012's Kindred, and his most satisfying statement of purpose since 2007's Untrue.

title: Blue Rider
label: Electric Ragtime
description: On singer-songwriter Zachary Cale's fourth album, Blue Rider, you're forcefully reminded that acoustic solo music is only as simple as you make it. It's a misty, gorgeous collection, offering a space that feels wonderful to roam around in.

title: Patricidal Lust
label: 20 Buck Spin
description: On Patricidal Lust, one of the strongest metal releases of the year, the Bay Area death metal group Vastum deliver a record about sex that takes a grisly look at erotic tension at its most extreme.

title: The Love Champion
label: UNO
description: NYC singer Ian Isiah's The Love Champion features beats that would turn Tricky Stewart's head, guest spots from Le1f and Mykki Blanco, and charismatic vocals drowned in AutoTune. Backed by producers like Sinjin Hawke, Brenmar, and ShyGuy, it's hard not to see parallels with Kelela's Cut 4 Me.

title: Remainderer EP
label: Cherry Red
description: Despite the leftovers its title implies, The Remainderer EP is being touted by the Fall’s label as “a bridging point” between 2013's spirited if sloppy full-length, Re-Mit, and another new album coming in 2014.

title: Because the Internet
label: Glassnote
description: The onetime “30 Rock” writer and “Community” star Donald Glover's newest Childish Gambino album is a multi-platform project that includes guest spots from Chance the Rapper, Azealia Banks, Problem, Mystikal, Miguel, and Jhené Aiko, among others.

title: Omen Ex Simulacra
label: Debemur Morti
description: On their second album Omen Ex Simulacra, the Oregon/Illinois duo Ævangelist create an aural monster, a horrific re-imagining of black/death metal coupled with harsh electronic noise and industrial mechanization.

title: Spit
label: Hospital Productions
description: Ron Morelli has spent the last three years building his L.I.E.S. label into a paragon of noisy, Made-in-the-U.S.A. club music. Spit, the first music under his own name released on Dominick Fernow's Hospital Productions, defies the type of romantic, back-to-basic engagement L.I.E.S. inspires.

title: School Daze
label: Dark Entries
description: Sex was the thematic preoccupation of producer Patrick Cowley, reflecting the strong connection between disco and gay bathhouses in late-70s San Francisco. Fittingly, the first concrete attempt to canonise Cowley as an electronic music auteur is a compilation of his soundtrack work for gay pornographic films.

title: Nina
label: Graveface
description: Here Xiu Xiu takes on the Nina Simone songbook, offering covers of songs like "Don't Explain", "Wild Is the Wind", and "Four Women". While the concept looks intriguing on paper, the execution leaves something to be desired.

title: Live at the Cellar Door
label: Reprise
description: This 1970 solo acoustic set at D.C.'s Cellar Door catches Neil Young in a bleak, hollow mood, rudely awoken from the hippie dream his audience still wants to believe. Amidst an accumulation of dark, druggy vibes, Live at the Cellar Door shows Young peeking over the edge of the 60s into the dark chasm of the next decade.

title: Kok EP
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: Norwegian house producer Bjørn Torske builds enveloping shapes from the merest scraps of musical information and in recent years has been making loose disco edits of his own instrumental recordings. His new Kok EP feels like a concise alternate version of 2010's excellent Kokning mixed with headphones in mind.

title: Soundtracks for Takeshi Murata
label: Glistening Examples
description: Until now, Hair Police's Robert Beatty, who also records as Three Legged Race, has never released a collection under his given name. He made the abstract music on Soundtracks for Takeshi Murata to accompany the films of “digital video glitch pioneer” Takeshi Murata.

title: David Novick
label: God?
description: As a member of San Francisco Water Cooler, David Novick plays abraded, candy-colored garage rock. But last October he released a muffled, strangely beatific self-titled psych-folk collection that's now being reissued by God?, a subsidiary of Drag City.

title: I Heard The Angels Singing: Electrifying Black Gospel
label: Tompkins Square
description: I Heard the Angels Singing: Electrifying Black Gospel from the Nashboro Label, 1951-1983 collects important songs from the catalogue of the Nashville gospel label Nashboro, painting a picture of a scene that was vital both musically and financially.

title: Black Panties
label: RCA
description: R. Kelly's 13th solo album Black Panties tosses aside the classic soul of his previous two albums in exchange for a deep dive into the sounds of contemporary bumping and grinding.

title: Step Brothers 2
label: self-released
description: Two years after their collaborative debut Step Brothers, Southern rappers Starlito and Don Trip present the for-retail sequel, a release that reveals two of the most honest writers in rap working together at maximum comfort and confidence.

title: Obscure Verses for the Multiverse
label: Season of Mist
description: The Seattle black metal duo Inquisition's first album for major metal indie Season of Mist follows 2011's excellent Ominous Doctrines of the Perpetual Mystical Macrocosm. It's another impressive collection, one that's about as catchy as a pure black metal record has any right to be.

title: Syndrome Syndrome
label: Rvng Intl.
description: On Syndrome Syndrome, the debut album from Australian electronic duo Gardland, there's a freeform feel that has more in common with the more experimental FRKWYS work than RVNG's regular releases.

title: Blazing Gentlemen
label: Fire
description: Robert Pollard's 2013 included a fine Guided by Voices EP, an okay GBV album, an unfailingly sweet solo collection, and a public fight with drummer Kevin Fennell. He closes the year with Blazing Gentlemen, a headier, rockier solo offering*.*

title: 7 Days of Funk
label: Stones Throw
description: 7 Days of Funk is Snoop Dogg recording in laid back mode as “Snoopzilla” and Dâm-Funk revamping the classic synthesizer melodies, electronic basslines, and digital drums that coursed through funk both before and after they attached the “g-” to it. It was home-recorded and assembled quickly, and the easygoing nature shines through.

title: Within The Walls
label: BloodLust!
description: On Bloodyminded's first album in seven years, the Chicago raw noise collective plows through harrowing drones, feedback bursts, mutated screams, static blitzes, and circuit collapses. There are imprecations hurled in English and Spanish and floods of sound so caustic and strong they rattle both brain and core.
